March 2023 Scavenger Hunt #5:Watch a movie that takes place in Los Angeles.The characters here feel a little one-dimensional/flat and the movie itself feels a bit like an elongated excuse to show a Ramones concert, but it's a fun time anyway. (Mostly) good vibes.
March 2023 Scavenger Hunt #18:Go to a movie theater to watch a movie.Dumb comedy writing and a pretty forgettable action premise. Entertaining enough to watch play out.

March 2023 Scavenger Hunt #24:Watch a movie that David Dastmalchian is in.Really interesting concept with a few promising scenes but an ultimately disappointing execution. The humor doesn‚Äôt really work for me, especially when it hinges on being gross for a reaction. The funniest bit was the bug guy acknowledging the Bart drawing.Was genuinely left wishing that more of this movie had been about him actually playing Pac Man, even if that misses the point.

March 2023 Scavenger Hunt #22:Watch a sequel that is apparently better than the original.I believe the wording of this task was originally "a sequel that is better than the original" with no "apparently," but I didn't want to rewatch something. Ultimately went withCroods 2because my friend wanted to watch and it has a slightly higher average on here than its predecessor.It's a cute movie! I've never seen the originalCroods, but the world building and‚Ä¶

movietitle: Honk for Jesus. Save Your Soul.
review: In 2022, making a satirical film about public figures who were "cancelled" by the media and their community already feels a bit like retreading old ground. To specifically focus on a homophobic pastor under fire for having manipulative sexual relationships with young men feels doubly so. And yet, I do thinkHonk for Jesusmanages to rise above its somewhat tired premise and do something interesting with the concept. Its narrative is well executed, and its characters believable. The humor didn't really do much for me, but it's an enjoyable enough movie nonetheless.

March 2023 Scavenger Hunt #13:Watch a happy movie that takes place in high school.I'm probably pushing it a bit by calling this a "happy movie," as it's more of a true neutral, but not many purely happy teen movies appealed to me.Napoleon Dynamiteis pure strangeness as humor. Or, at least, an imitation of strangeness. It's comprised of connected vignettes of cringe comedy with very little substance otherwise. Sometimes they're okay, but mostly they just don't work‚Ä¶

I last sawGreen Roomseven years ago, so I was hopeful a rewatch would make me finally come around on it. Unfortunately, I feel pretty much the same now as I did then. I enjoy the film‚Äôs visuals, particularly its play with color, but the tension doesn‚Äôt translate for me. The film even has a solid opening and decent end note, but the middle just kind of bores me. A shame, because the cast is pretty great.

I appreciateThree Kings' critical, and occasionally satirical, approach but it still had a lot of the hallmarks of American war movies I just don't care for. I have no interest in its "protagonists." Some interesting editing though.For the military crowd: are the Uncle Remus /Song of the Southreferences they use in this genuine radio codes? Is this a thing?

The main character in this movie is realistic, and well acted by Theron, but that doesn't make my secondhand embarrassment for 90% of her actions any less intense. I did enjoy its play with/subversion of common romcom tropes though. Solid ending.

I haven‚Äôt been writing reviews for these stand-up specials because I haven‚Äôt had much to say and I‚Äôm watching/listening to them while working on art stuff but the fact that Marc did the entire hat joke TWICE just so he could frame it as a children‚Äôs book the second time actively annoyed me. There‚Äôs some decently funny commentary in the first half of the special but, come on, this thing is seventy minutes long why are you wasting time by telling the same joke again!!!

Fun little movie. The very nature of the premise means it gets a bit repetitive, but I really enjoyed the homages to different film genres/types.The costume designer went off, especially for MacLaine. (though honestly my favorite was the little plaidfarmer fitrather than any of the elaborate dresses. themusical outfitsare also cute.)

The narrative's execution is kind of dumb, but I like the idea of doing a supervillain origin story as a horror film. There's a few fun plays here with typical superhero tropes. Some gnarly scenes in it as well - the eye horror in particular is nasty.

I've been morbidly curious about this film since it released on Netflix in 2021 due to the short-lived controversy surrounding it both here and on Twitter. It was strange to me how many peoples' main criticism seemed to be that its director was a man. Even stranger to me is that the top review on here is straight up factually incorrect, implying that a man also wrote this, when in actuality both the film and adapted manga were written by‚Ä¶
thatunnamed crystalline druggoes crazy

movietitle: The Making of 'Fay Grim' or: How Do You Spell Espionage?
review: In case it wasn't clear from my lack of relevant logs over the past few months, I ended up giving up on my Parker Posey binge. It was a nice idea that I was really excited for in October, but which ended up being more of a chore than I imagined. Just felt like a waste of time to rewatch 80+ movies, some of which I've seen quite recently. I still plan on rewatching a handful that I haven't seen‚Ä¶

I have a lot of respect for independent filmmakers on small budgets putting themselves out there. It takes a lot of effort to create a feature. But a small budget doesn't really excuse obnoxious writing. Some of the line delivery (and, by extension, the fact that some of the lines seem dubbed) is funny at first, particularly in the film's opening, but the longer the movie goes on the less interested I was in anything going on in it.Edit:‚Ä¶

If I'm honest, I didn't go into this movie with very high expectations. Kelly Reichardt has been pretty hit or miss for me as a director, and I was mentally preparing myself for this one in particular to be a little boring because I'd heard as much from a few friends. ...Unfortunately, mentally prepping myself did not help. The movie is glacially paced to the point of making me antsy. Worse yet, there's not nearly enough shots of THE titular‚Ä¶

The murder subplot helps to elevate this a bit, but the narration is annoying and Emma Stone's dialogue feels so frustratingly false in both wording and delivery.Rewatched because both Parker Posey and Meredith Hagner are in it but I didn't remember it well enough to rank in either of their lists. ..Turns out Meredith Hagner is more of an extra than a character in this. Not even a single line.

There was allegedly aTank Girl"reboot" (re-adaptation) in the works with Margot Robbie, which makes sense because Tank Girl kinda feels like a proto-Harley Quinn. I think I generally like the aesthetics ofTank Girlbetter than Gotham though. Praying that they don't do Booga and the other mutated kangaroos as dirty in a new movie as they do here.All that said, this iteration isVERY90's, and it works well with the comic's and character's aesthetics. TWO‚Ä¶
Happy Valentine‚Äôs day to THEM.
never had any strong feelings about this one way or the other. really love its unique animation though.

Sorry about this one. I can't say I really get the appeal, personally. The shocking imagery has purpose, but the more it's shown again and again (...and again) with such little reprieve the less impact it has for me and the more it feels like just watching a series of intense, horrifying moments with little else to grasp onto.The moments of calm we do get are often dialogueless and at a distance, or of Kotoko doing routine, everyday tasks‚Ä¶

This has beautiful technicolor visuals and a haunting end, but I was kind of underwhelmed by everything else here. The dancing and set design are impressive, but those dancing sequences go on for soo long...
love that her mispronouncing meme was cause for suspicion

Last night I watched two Lifetime movies and a movie about a kid whose dog went to court for killing a sheep and all three of those were better written than this. Somehow boring in spite of its convoluted killer curse/conspiracy plot.
pretty typical lifetime stalker-thriller...except the stalker has a cgi shark he feeds bodies to. so it's better than the typical lifetime stalker-thriller.
Instead of saying the dog was going to be killed if it lost its trial / if it killed a sheep they kept saying the dog was going to be DESTROYED.

Maja Mais a film that is too long for what could have easily been a simplistic 90min story and, as an unfortunate side effect of its elongated runtime, it gets a bit messy both in terms of plot and tone.Nonetheless, I do generally like its basic story. It‚Äôs nice to see an older LGBT character (apparently played by a well-regarded actress), and it‚Äôs interesting to see an on-screen portrayal of the overzealous straight ally type. She does more‚Ä¶

movietitle: The Killing of a Sacred Deer
review: ‚ÄúCan I have your MP3 player¬†when you're dead? Please. Please. Please...‚ÄùYorgos Lanthimos has always been pretty hit or miss for me. I enjoyedThe Favourite, but I was never really intoThe LobsterorDogtooth. He really knocks it out of the park here though. Likely his best work - though I have yet to seeALPS.Darkly funny with an impeccable atmosphere and an offbeat acting style that works perfectly to build the film‚Äôs strange and terrifyingly vindictive world.
Cute movie. Fun concept. Not much more to say.

Little Fishis a film that easily invites comparison. To the more choice-driven relationship sci-fiEternal Sunshine of the Spotless Mind,to peoples' experiences with Alzheimer's, and, somewhat ironically, to the COVID-19 pandemic that would happen in between its conception and release.Nonetheless, in spite of its looming influences, and unintentional parallels, I was pretty invested in this film at its beginning. The depiction of helplessness is well-executed, as is its focus on the deterioration of a relationship through no‚Ä¶

Definitely a missed opportunity to playGoodbye Earlin this movie.There's a lot to love aboutWaitress. I really enjoyed the repeated visual motif of Jenna's pies as a means to tell where her head was at, and Jenna herself is an incredibly likable protagonist. Some funny moments too, in spite of how dark some of the narrative is.But... the majority of the men in this movie are sooo frustratingly awful to the point that it made the‚Ä¶

There‚Äôs some pretty fun sequences here with Miike‚Äôs usual visual flair - particularly the fight sequence and animation towards the end - but the narrative feels a bit too much like Miike going through the motions of a ‚Äúgood crime/action movie.‚Äù It‚Äôs simultaneously convoluted and full of clich√©s, resulting in characters who feel pretty bare bones and derivative against the hectic world around them. Still, enjoyable enough way to spend two hours.

solid reminder of why I told myself I was going to stop doing film gorge events. in a better world I turned this off after ten minutes. the narration (and the narration writing) is definitely the worst aspect, but nothing else here is much better. not even funny-bad.

Emotion-driven performances keep this afloat, but I still found it to be a little too overlong and awkwardly paced for me to ever truly invest in it. I did like the second half far more than the first though.Also - wildly missing the point - but I love the illustrations in Nic's journal. Curious what artist did them.

movietitle: The Boy, the Mole, the Fox and the Horse
review: the art style is immaculate but I wish they didn‚Äôt speak

I wasn't sure what to expect from this. Based on premise alone, it seemed like a film that could have easily gone south in a myriad of ways, but it managed to maintain both intrigue and respect throughout. I was surprised to learn, in looking at the film's Wikipedia page after, thatThe Miracle Workeractually released in Keller's lifetime and she was able to meet with the young actress who played her. I imagine the meeting, and the film's‚Ä¶

Refreshing to watch this afterLes Bonnes Femmeswhich, in spite of being made three decades later, feels stiffer and less authentic in its portrayal of female friendship.The Wild Party's portrayal of youth culture in general feels similarly natural and fun, and a lot more modern than its release date would suggest. A fun, cute time.

Kind of crazy that this is a first feature. It definitely has its flaws, but it completely nails creating the perfect on-screen atmosphere to get us in Jo's headspace. Ruby is infuriatingly loud and incessant in her screaming, but equally as innocent, and vulnerable, and worthy of protection.Added bonus for obsessively bisexual Meredith Hagner character. Let's make that a typecast.

Strange little short about a (very) unconventional love. I wish the embroidered aesthetic of the poster and thumbnail had been relevant to the film. Would have been cool to see some simplistic animated, or even still, sequences in the style.

movietitle: Remain Seated Please - The Hoot and Chief Story
review: Incredibly interesting (unofficial) documentation of Horizons, with a narrated story that serves as a testament to Hoot and Chief's friendship.The entire existence of this documentary and its footage is a bit morally ambiguous, but the only people Hoot and Chief everreallyendangered were themselves so it's hard to care too much. The footage they got, both in terms of still imagery and video, is amazing. Genuinely of historical merit, and full of revelatory ride details that Disney themselves‚Ä¶
when this started there were six or seven other people in the theater‚Ä¶ by the end there were zero other people in the theater

me seeing the top reviews:there's no way it could be that badme watching the movie:The dream sequences are stupid, all the characters are terrible, and the humor is often obnoxious. The soundtrack is okay.About forty minutes in I started watching every scene that Alia Shawkat wasn't in at 1.25 speed. (her character sucks too though, dgmw) At fifty minutes in I found out the director is the son of John Landis?!?!? What happened here. (Note: I‚Ä¶

Underwhelmed by the end. Everything ultimately feels so senseless in a way that‚Äôs more unsatisfying than it is powerful. I think more ambiguity would have helped this a great deal, but M Night doesn‚Äôt know when to end a movie.Enjoyable enough watch though. As much as I‚Äôm not into the ending note, the mystery and tension of the lead-up hooked me. Good cast of characters and some interesting camerawork/visuals as well.

man shoulda got his jet...This definitely falls into a similar trap as other Netflix docuseries in that it could have been cut down considerably and made for a better watch, but I applaud it for not feeling quite as repetitive as its predecessors in that regard. One of the more interesting asides is the series' exploration of the Pepsi Number Scandal in the Philippines and its relation to the case at hand - I'm honestly not sure the narrative‚Ä¶
Surprisingly dark (though melodramatically so) film about the life of a deeply troubled starlet. Has some great scenes, but as a whole it struggled to keep my attention. So many crossfades.

I've never read the short story that this film was based on, but got it as one of my three festival picks because of the pre-fest buzz and my enjoyment of Susanna Fogel's other projects (Life Partners, and the writing onBooksmart). I thought it was...fine? Certainly nothing revolutionary, but I'm glad that what I initially thought was going to be a strict, empty "men bad" movie did provide a bit of nuance by the time the credits rolled. Not‚Ä¶
everything happens so much... (should have been more about the walmart living, birth, and fallout)

Kind of baffling ending shot (don't really understand the logic behind ending on Carl rather than Abigail), but the insanity throughout makes for a fun watch. Often funny writing and line delivery as well. Not something that made any kind of deep impression, but it's an enjoyable movie with some decent (if a bit in-your-face and surface level) commentary. I'm only giving it half a star more, but I think this is far better than either season ofThe White Lotus.
"We have to do something about this damn global warming!"this movie has five original songs and all of them were snubbed for the oscar. not enough birds.

Alice Englert's first foray into feature filmmaking misses the mark for me.Bad Behaviourfeels like a collection of pieces that never come together to build a full puzzle, feeling interchangeably aimless and tonally confused throughout a runtime that often feels longer than it is. When the climax of the film happened I hoped that the fall out would eventually make the film's narrative more compelling, but it still continued to trod along a path to nowhere.Good performances and the occasional darkly comedic moment cannot support a film with no backbone.

What starts out as a nostalgic documentary about a New York video store becomes a tense, stranger than fiction mystery with unexpected twists and turns. The filmmaker clearly has a lot of love and passion for the subject (not only the video store, but for films as a whole), and it shows in not only his actions but his craft.The only thing holding me back from loving this more is that I found a lot of the narrated film‚Ä¶
Offers insultingly little in terms of original thoughts or content. Undeniably exploitative of the cast members of Glee who died. Don‚Äôt waste your time.

"It's the time and that place and that song. And you remember what it was like when you were in that place. And then you listen to that song and you know you're not in that place anymore and it makes you feel hollow. You can't just go find that stuff again."In 2012 I convinced my parents to drive me two hours to see this in a theater in my state's capital because that was the closest it was‚Ä¶
hope that guy raised his rate on taskrabbit. you deserve more for your time, king.

"What kind of nerd kills his whole family?"At times visually grotesque, with protagonists to match. A killer hyperbolic satire of a very specific kind of modern desperation - for fame, for pity, for any and all kind of attention no matter the cost. The ending feels a bit anticlimactic, and ultimately plays into me not rating the film higher, but it's hard to imagine where else it could have gone narratively. Any kind of "big" ending would have likely only fueled her delusions of grandeur.

The Whalefeels like a movie at constant war with itself. The lead performance by Brendan Fraser speaks to a sympathy and humanity that does not seem to extend to those behind the camera. The score of the film is tense enough to be at home in a horror/thriller, even in its opening moments. This may feel appropriate when Charlie begins to binge eat late into the film, but there are plenty of other times (walking to his bedroom, masturbating)‚Ä¶
Cute ending. :) Hard to argue against something so genuinely passionate and heartfelt.

Mixed on this. There were a few moments when I thought it was just a middling kid's movie with a fine plot ...and then there'd be some awful line of dialogue or weird delivery that soured me on it again. Regardless of narrative quality, however, the visuals are to die for and ultimately make the whole thing worthwhile. The use of color is particularly wonderful.

Guillermo del Toro's adaptation ofPinocchiosuffers a bit from the very nature of its original story - the pacing is inherently a bit wonky, with the whale sequence in particular feeling a bit overlong and forced - and I'm not a huge fan of the music... but I still think that del Toro's take on the subject may be the best I've seen thus far. The father-son connection between Gepetto and Pinocchio is unquestionably the film's heart and soul,‚Ä¶

When it comes to its visuals and editingAftersunflawlessly captures the "home video"/memory vibe, with an aesthetic that feels bittersweetly nostalgic. The setting and situations the characters are put in really help to hammer this feeling home, as does the film's ending note. Nonetheless, I never felt anything more than that surface level nostalgia over the course of the runtime.The characters feel a bit too vaguely characterized and "universally relatable" in a way that makes it hard for‚Ä¶

Child‚Äôs Play(2019) for the girls ‚Ä¶and without the weight of an established franchise on its shoulders.M3GANaccomplishes what it needs to and manages to be funny and entertaining in spite of some predictable moments. Might have packed a little more punch if it had kept it‚Äôs R-rating, but I think it‚Äôs good enough as is.

movietitle: Puss in Boots: The Last Wish
review: My favorite animated movie of 2022 is stillMarcel the Shell, butPuss in Boots: The Last Wishcertainly makes a convincing argument for itself. An interesting story with a great cast of characters and stellar, eye candy animation. I was genuinely shocked that the dog comedic relief character wasn't obnoxious. I actually liked him quite a bit!John Mulaney is definitely the worst voice actor here, just as he was inChip N Dale. His voice feels so awkward coming out of Jack Horner.

Consistently fun and high octane love letter to the movies, with the occasional light criticism of Hollywood's issues with class and race. The first half is a lot stronger than the second, and I wasn't entirely on board with the lengthy ending sequence post-Singing in the Rain, but I had a good time. Shockingly did not feel its length.As we were walking out of the theater a group of guys behind us said that this was the most confusing movie they'd ever seen.

Glass Onionis a fun enough follow-up toKnives Out, but it‚Äôs simply too long for what it is, with a stretched thin plot and an ensemble cast that never truly gets the chance to show off their chops.The characters here feel more like disconnected White Lotus guests than they do lifelong friends with apprehensions, and the attempts at social commentary are so flimsy that the film ends up saying nothing at all. The Among Us and Quiplash references‚Ä¶
Went into this with no knowledge of its subject and found it to be pretty interesting. The ‚Äúprank‚Äù phone call is truly one of those ‚Äòtruth is stranger than fiction‚Äô moments. Crazy stuff.

This is pretty much all mystery with very little character or world building, and you know the reality of what happened from the beginning, but the twists and turns are interesting enough for it to work.The visualization of Margot‚Äôs court case is a really great use of color/expression to convey mood in lieu of an actual court set piece, but I do wish there had been a few more unique visual decisions like it throughout the film.
incredibly predictable lifetime christmas movie but meredith hagner is so charming. the kid isn‚Äôt a great actor but even his scenes with her feel natural and fun. üíñ

Really fun movie!!I won‚Äôt deny this has its issues, but it‚Äôs still kind of baffling to me that this doesn‚Äôt have the same kind of cult following as other campy drag-centric films of the same ilk. Especially with the fun musical numbers, Debbie Reynolds cameo, and Toni Collette in a leading role!!I think thatConnie and Carlawould work a lot better without the love story between Connie and Duchovny‚Äôs character, because I found that most of the film‚Äôs issues arose from that dynamic, but it‚Äôs a good time regardless. Hard for me to hate in any capacity.
Conceptually interesting but stretched far too thin with an incredibly basic social message and a sequel bait ending. The humor never worked for me and the horror was too goofy to have any impact.

Apparently this was based on a book and ‚Ä¶you can really tell. It‚Äôs incredibly narration-heavy with some pretty minimalist animation. The art style works for the film‚Äôs simplistic story, but the constant narration quickly bored me. Sweet movie though. Just not something I was super into. Might mean more to me if I‚Äôd ever had a dog.

It took a while for me to get into this, but I think the apocalyptic midsection really sells it. There‚Äôs a lot going on in the narrative, and it doesn‚Äôt always feel connected in a fluid way, but I think it ..mostly works‚Ä¶?White Noisedeals with a myriad of heavy subjects - primarily apocalyptic fears, mortality, and misinformation - in a way that‚Äôs surprisingly fun and a little surreal. The dialogue has more than a few moments of genuine‚Ä¶

Likely the only Wes Anderson movie that isn‚Äôt immediately recognizable as a Wes Anderson movie, though his humor and quirky sense of style are certainly still there.I honestly wasn‚Äôt really feeling this movie in the first half, especially when it came to Anthony and Inez‚Äôs relationship, which just kind of consists of..Anthony harassing her at work? but.. it works I guess. She reciprocates, so it‚Äôs not entirely Weird. Still not really on board with them, but their relationship eventually fades to the background and I really liked the rest of the film. The failed heist in particular is really fun.

I was kind of shocked by what this movie ended up being. I had a completely different impression of it based on the poster (and the poster alone, as I rarely remember plot descriptions for movies in my watchlist..)The beginning of this showed some promise, but the longer it went on the less I understood the point of it all. Some cool editing/visuals here and there, but for the most part this feels all over the place in the worst of ways.

A Love Songis slow-moving and quiet in a way that is genuinely poignant, but I still felt that there was too little to grasp onto here. Even with its short runtime, it managed to lose me along the way.Dale Dickey gives a phenomenal performance based on what she‚Äôs given, completely carrying the film‚Äôs emotional weight, but a lot of my favorite scenes were when she got to interact with other people. The kid‚Äôs line delivery in particular is so funny and matter-of-fact.

Ending song is fun. Generally though I've never thought any live action DCOM watched after the age of 15 was anything more than 'alright.' It's cute enough I guess, and I can see how I would have liked it as a preteen, but as it stands I got nothing out of this.

I was admittedly a bit apprehensive about this rec after realizing that the director had also madeTetsuo: the Iron Man- a movie I wasn't a big fan of - but I'm happy to say I was (mostly) pleasantly surprised by this. I can't say I always understood what every scene was going for, but I found its play with ideas of class and human nature to be interesting nonetheless. "Cool" imagery as well, especially in the flashbacks.

I think my expectations for this were too high because I ended up feeling a bit underwhelmed by the end. It's ultimately just a little too long for me, and I feel like a shortened runtime could have made for a punchier, more impactful narrative. Thereisa lot here that's really good though. I don't usually have any strong opinions about her as an actress, but Cate Blanchett does an impeccable job at portraying Lydia's deteriorating mental state in this, and I think the story itself is pretty timely and well-handled.

Fun soundtrack and stellar editing (including a really great opening credits sequence) but I really hated the protagonist and found the dialogue/humor to be incredibly annoying. The protag‚Äôs opening monologue is kind of uniquely insufferable.

This is fine. It‚Äôs whatever. If you saw any of the trailers, or even looked at the titles/promo images, you can pretty much guess how each one of these will play out. The animation is feature quality though, and the stories are cute enough even if they are predictable. TheReal Housewivesparody is my personal favorite.I think this would have been a lot better had there been more narrative freedom and each short didn't have to be tied to a pre-existing scene fromZootopia.

movietitle: The Guardians of the Galaxy Holiday Special
review: Although theGuardians of the Galaxymovies are my favorite MCU projects, I was still kind of worried I‚Äôd hate this. That worry was doubled when I realized that Mantis and Drax would be the focus. Never been a huge fan of either of them, especially not comedically.¬†Thankfully though, this special was a pleasant surprise. It‚Äôs nothing revolutionary, sure, but I think it works really well for what it is.It was kind of crazy to watch this back to back‚Ä¶

Suddenly remembered that my Disney+ subscription is ending on Sunday (I cancelled earlier this month because of the price hike) so I binged all of this today. Complete morbid curiosity because I liked Tatiana Maslany inOrphan Blackand wanted to see how the show handled Daredevil. Needless to say, it wasn‚Äôt great!The humor never worked for me, and all of the show‚Äôs ‚Äúimportant‚Äù monologues and scenes about womanhood feel so false and paint by numbers. Even when She-Hulk‚Ä¶

Intriguing concept and ending, but it's too short and, honestly, amateurish (both in presentation/quality and in writing) to fully work for me. Assuming this is the starting point ofBeau is Afraid(formerlyDisappointment Blvd.) it'll be interesting to see it expanded with a better budget, better audio, and such a strong cast of actors.

This was fine! Really enjoyed the animation style and the animal character design.Got needlessly hung up on the species dynamics of this world given the fact that the only animal characters we see were major players in the story (but the bad guys disguises "work"? even though they're the only animals we see in the entire city? I know this is a kid's cartoon but come on. give me some animal background characters at least!)

"Come on, let's give it up for respecting women!!"Kind of messy and overlong, but ultimately entertaining enough. Unfortunately this doesn't gettrulyinteresting until the last forty minutes or so, but those forty minutes were crazy enough to get me re-invested. Almost considered bumping this up a half star as a result of those last forty minutes, but the dialogue throughout is too obnoxious for me to do so. It's quotable in the most annoying way possible - aka‚Ä¶

In an episode of the bad movie podcastHow Did This Get Made?, guest Andrea Savage told a story about the 2006 holiday filmDeck the Halls. Her friend, Gillian Vigman, was on the set of the box office dud and she witnessed star Matthew Broderick looking forlorn and muttering to himself, ‚ÄúI‚Äôve hit rock bottom." This was a man who was involved in a car crash that killed two people, butDeck the Hallswas his ‚Äúrock bottom.‚Äù‚Äù (x)that about sums it up.

Ladyworldhas a theoretically strong premise thatshould haveeasily worked for me, but ultimately just feels tedious and boring to watch. The tension works on occasion, as do the film's aesthetics, but we don't know much of anything about these characters or their relationship to each other prior to them being trapped together so everything just feels kind of ...pointless? I needed this to have either some actual emotional investment or way more explosive/interesting scenes earlier on in its runtime.

Interesting enough on a surface level, even if itisaggressively positive in its depiction of working for The Mouse. It's strange to me that they included theGood Morning Americastory at all as everything else here seems more classically "Disney," with even theStar Warsand Marvel related segments focusing on theme park additions.Would have liked to see more segments about less "exciting" Disney employees. (i.e. everyday theme park cast members) (definitely not just saying that because I was one of those everyday theme park cast members when this was filmed)

movietitle: Adventure Thru the Walt Disney Archives
review: Thetop reviewfor this short documentary does a pretty good job of explaining everything wrong with it and, by extension, the state of the Walt Disney Archives as a whole.Solely looking at what's presented on-screen,Adventure Thru the Walt Disney Archivesis a pretty empty fluff piece more about Walt Disney (the man) than it is about the Archive or Archivists. This was originally released for D23, an expensive fan subscription, and yet it plays as if it‚Ä¶
the best way to watch this is half awake at 2am

movietitle: Legend of the Guardians: The Owls of Ga'Hoole
review: I think the semi-realistic animation style works really well for the dark story being presented here, but I could never really get into that story.

Really love the animation and character design for the pets in this movie but I didn't really vibe with the humor at all. The joke writing is kind of all over the place - pee jokes one second and bleeped swear words the next. Lots of random pop culture references as well, but that's pretty par for the course. October 2022 Scavenger Hunt #8:Watch a favorite film recommended fromone of your friendsthat you haven‚Äôt seen.I'd say I'm not usually one for slow-burn horror, but when done right it can be incredibly effective. This is definitely true forResurrection,which has a kind of baffling ending but is otherwise a really strong and consistently intriguing thriller/horror, primarily about trauma, motherhood, and (toxic) relationships. Some really fantastic performances from Rebecca Hall and Tim Roth in this. Definitely a movie I'd be curious to read other peoples' thoughts and interpretations on.

October 2022 Scavenger Hunt #30:Watch a movie musicalThis is alright. Not nearly as bad as some make it out to be, but definitely not as good asRepo! the Genetic Opera, primarily because it doesn't have the star power and fleshed out narrative ofRepo!. The songs and visuals are fun though.

October 2022 Scavenger Hunt #25:Watch a movie from the 70‚ÄôsReally solid opening and ending, but it falters somewhere in the middle. This is fine. Kind of predictable with some weird pacing and characters I never really had any kind of strong opinion on. Very 90's banter. Not much to say here.

This felt a lot more focused and character-driven thanXand is ultimately better for it. The visuals often ride the perfect line between the ideal and the unsettling. Mia Goth is killing it. (literally!)

I wasn't always on board with this, but what does work works well.I personally found Ti West's earlier horror film,The House of the Devilto be kind of trite, and its reliance on common horror tropes (both narrative and visual) overbearing.Xis similarly referential, but is ultimately much better at expanding upon the tropes it uses and becoming its own unique thing. It's a clear homage, but not so much that you can guess every story beat.The ending lines and cut to the title are so good.

movietitle: Kate Berlant: Cinnamon in the Wind
review: Maybe one of the strangest stand-up specials I've seen if only because everything feels so genuinely off the cuff. Every new thought feels like a new character being put on. Which is admittedly pretty entertaining. I would be interested to hear from someone who saw one of the performances live just to know whether or not the show was more or less the same across the board. Worst bit here is definitely the uncomfortably long incest joke.
Not always for me in terms of its sense of humor, but overall - pretty good! The casual Susan Sarandon cameo is crazy (she‚Äôs just there watching the stand-up in the audience).

movietitle: Three Instagram Models Have a Picnic
review: The ending of this is kind of funny but a lot of this is just annoying random quirky girl humor. Which I guess I get is what they're making fun of, re: Instagram models, but...did not work for me.

I was hoping that the majority was wrong on this one and that it would live up to the promise of the first movie. Nope.Men in Black IIhas a weird, convoluted plot that I eventually gave up trying to fully understand. The action is kind of boring, and the fun worldbuilding that helped to make the first film so unique is nowhere to be seen. I guess they figured they established everything they wanted to there, so they‚Ä¶

Aggressively ‚Äúok‚Äù whodunnit story obsessed with proving how clever it is. It‚Äôs enjoyable, but in a way that‚Äôs kind of bland and far too universally palatable. I think it‚Äôs a shame I saw it so soon afterInspector Ike, because that film is definitely a far better, far funnier tongue-in-cheek twist on the classic detective story. The performances and editing do occasionally elevateSee How They Runfrom its mediocrity, but ..not by much.

I skipped watchingFinal Destination 2because the rollercoaster poster was too enticing. Sort of wish it happened at a big theme park rather than a little local fair (not as surprising to die on a local fair coaster), but I'll take what I can get.These are fun movies to watch play out, but ultimately way too silly for me to ever get invested in. The deaths are all likeHappy Tree Friendslevels of suddenness and blood splatter‚Ä¶

I initially watched this movie 6+ years ago in a film class and was completely enamored with it. At that point I hadn‚Äôt really explored film as a medium that much, and I was really into sitcoms likeCommunityandArrested Developmentand, most of all,Parks & Recreation. At that point in my life Tobey Maguire‚Äôs character, David, really resonated with me. The allegorical story mattered very little to me, I mostly just loved that I could see myself so‚Ä¶

Can't say I understand the hate for this one. The initial reaction can probably be chalked up to it coming out hot on the tail ofGigli, in addition to peoples' expectations for a Kevin Smith movie not being met, but today? I guess it is true thatJersey Girlis cheesy and predictable and melodramatic but I really love how much it wears its heart on its sleeve. It's a movie filled with such genuine love and sentimentality that it's hard for me to hate. The pure joy in the Sweeney Todd scene is infectious. One of Smith's best. (AfterTuskandDogma, of course)

Didn‚Äôt think this was quite as shocking as everyone made it out to be, but it was a good time nonetheless. Consistently pretty tense with some surprisingly funny moments. Not writing any more for this because even though I wasn‚Äôt as awed by the twist I do think it‚Äôs probably more impactful if you go in blind. Might write some more thoughts if I rewatch.

Writing this review at 2:30 am so my thoughts are a little jumbled, but definitely recommend seeking this out!Inspector Ikeis consistently funny with pitch perfect line delivery. It reminds me a bit ofAngie Tribeca, though it‚Äôs certainly dryer than that show was. The framing of the film as a Saturday night mystery special helps add a fun vintage flair, and immediately excuses any overly convenient plot developments.

Didn't have a ton of expectations for this going in, but I enjoyed it for what it was. Very 90's. Very edgy.Narration so often ruins the flow of a film for me, and even more often feels too on the nose, but it feels pretty well-executed here. Likely due to the fact that it's very tongue-in-cheek and meta about the protagonist's mentality versus the audience's expectations.

This is fine. Was expecting a lot more after seeing the high average on here. It‚Äôs cool to hear from the filmmakers but, as a whole, this feels like a very basic discussion of the highlighted films and about lesbian cinema as a whole. Lots of ‚ÄúOh my god, yes!! So important!!‚Äù And, like, they are‚Ä¶ but I assume most people watching this documentary are aware of that. Let‚Äôs delve deeper.

Interesting premise rife with promise, but the same three or four jokes get run into the ground for the entirety of the runtime. You‚Äôre in the know from the beginning, so it‚Äôs pretty easy to guess where things are going. Might have worked a bit better if his being a hypochondriac working off of a misconception was a last minute twist, as it would have forced more creative writing. Definitely still has its moments though, and the performances are good.

It's crazy that a movie like this can be made and released today by a first time director. It truly feels like it could be an indie production from the late 90's/early 00's that somehow got lost and re-found. Like whatGhost Worldcould have been like if it wasn't nudged towards a more traditional story structure by studio execs. There's a grime to the imagery and people of this film that feels almost tangible, and perfectly calls to mind‚Ä¶

Nuanced and wholesome, with characters who feel like real human beings with their own individual lives and issues outside of the main narrative. Never feels its length, and the few song and dance numbers are pretty fun. Peak gay/lesbian solidarity AND gay/lesbian dissension. It‚Äôs equality.
love the fortune teller cackling at the end. me when my faves are gay fr.

Surprisingly short runtime for an Indian¬†film, but still takes a bit too long to really get going for me. Nonetheless a decent romance story, as well as an interesting examination of the societal expectations for marriage and family versus innate human desire. Respect for being the first mainstream Bollywood film to feature a lesbian relationship.

"But sometimes I wonder, God who made this world which is so complex... so colorful... would that God be satisfied with merely creating man and woman? How could God have resisted making human beings more complex?"Daayrais not a film without its issues, but given the time period and culture in which it came from it feels shockingly progressive. Following a cis woman, who must dress as a man for safety, and a trans woman, the film deals directly‚Ä¶

movietitle: NOH8 Photo Shoot with the Cast of Search Party
review: no hate!!

thought they were just gonna go to a tatu concert..............gonna be real I didn't understand what was happening or why for half of the runtime so I can't imagine how this story made any sense as a book full of text messages
Sometimes comedy shorts have an overwhelming vibe of being "made for YouTube." This is one of those times. Occasionally vaguely funny because of Sennott's delivery.

Pretty torn on this and kind of uncertain of how much I truly liked it as a total film, but I had fun. Content with this (perhaps high) rating for now.Jeff Baena is so versatile in terms of the narratives he presents, but all of his films still maintain the same sensibilities regarding their direction, timing, and sense of humor. They're all undeniably his kind of weird, even if this particular one is a bit more conventional than something‚Ä¶
The ending sells it. The movieAssassination Nationwishes it was.

"She said I'm obsessed with Minkus fromBoy Meets World. I'm not thinking about him all the time, I just think about him when I'm in bed to help me go to sleep."This could have ended like six minutes in and been a little better for it, but it's fine. It's silly and dumb in a fun way.
This is an anthology of shorts by different filmmakers, so naturally some are better than others. TheSheila Ki Jawaanisegment is v cute. I support him.
Chaotic and meta ‚Ä¶in a fun way! It‚Äôs noReturn of the Killer Tomatoes, but I enjoyed myself.

Absolutely wild to cast Mary Elizabeth Winstead and Woody Harrelson and then give them such a bland and uninspired script. I‚Äôve definitely seen worse movies, but so much here just feels wasted or overshadowed by messy writing.It‚Äôs weird and discomforting in the current climate that ‚Äúwhite protagonist goes to Asian country and slaughters a bunch of people because‚Ä¶yakuza? I guess?‚Äù is becoming such a common trope. The fact that this is blended with white saviorism and a very stereotypical‚Ä¶

Knew very little about this movie going in beyond the scene with the boombox. I was surprised by how much was going on, plot-wise, and how serious it became by the end. Nonetheless I was still left a bit underwhelmed by the film (and romance) as a whole. Kind of forgettable beyond a handful of stand out scenes.
WatchingGleeso I'll make this brief: Lots of fun musical numbers. Explores its complicated dynamic pretty well. Julie Andrews is a national treasure.

Really enjoyed the first third of this before they head to Manderley, but it just keeps going and going. (and going.) It's not even that long of a movie, all things considered, but the glacial pace at which anything of note happens actively ruins the tension for me. The characters also feel pretty one-note, which makes it harder for me to care when things do start picking up.Call me when they make a prequel about the infinitely more interesting story of Maxim and Rebecca's relationship and Mrs Danvers' role in it.

movietitle: Zack and Miri Make a Porno
review: Slowly chipping away at Kevin Smith‚Äôs non-Askewniverse stuff. This is a mostly stupid, but surprisingly sweet, romcom. Has some pretty funny lines here and there as well. It‚Äôs not something I‚Äôd ever recommend to anyone, but it is enjoyable enough that I‚Äôd happily rewatch it if someone I knew wanted to see it.

Such a frustrating watch. About an hour of this is just the female protagonist dealing with transphobia (being outed, misgendered, publicly humiliated), and the worst part of it all is that we‚Äôre supposed to sympathize with the man being transphobic to her. Don‚Äôt get me wrong, this movie is definitelyalsosympathetic of its trans protagonist, and I understand trans rep is pretty rare in Bollywood films, but once you‚Äôve shown your male lead being so vile to the female‚Ä¶

Cute!I was actually pretty aware of this movie's plot/story beats prior to watching, but it didn't make watching it actually play out any less engaging. Julia Roberts and Richard Gere really know how to take a familiar, predictable romcom plot and elevate it to something special with charm and delivery alone.There's probably some iffy ethics stuff going on here to some degree, but I never got the vibe that the movie itself was truly looking down on Vivian.‚Ä¶

At no point in this film did I care about its characters. I did not care about their survival. I did not care who among them lived or who died. There are so many long sequences with no dialogue. There are so many scenes in general that do not need to be as long as they are. I could sit and talk about the themes or whatever but honestly I don't care enough. Film is a subjective art and this did absolutely nothing for me. I would have turned it off mid-banjo duel if I wasn't watching for a server event.

Such a weird movie.The narration is probably the biggest offense here, riding the line betweenAm√©lieandA Series of Unfortunate Eventsin tone and delivery. The issue is that, unlikeAm√©lie,The Age of Adalinedoesn't have the visual flair to back up the "fantasy story" narration and, unlikeASoUE, its dialogue writing doesn't quite tonally match-up with the narrated bits. So it just ends up feeling kind of...lazy and corny.I'm also left kind of shocked that‚Ä¶

I'm largely unfamiliar with the band this is about and unfortunately this is undeniably a fan film. Everythingmakes sensewatching as an outsider, but I couldn't help but think the impact of everything would be a lot greater if I knew anything more than the bare minimum about the people set to perform at the film's end. I liked the kid's story well enough, and the art accompanying the credits is cute. Not much more to say about this.

Crazy that this was a directorial debut. And not just any directorial debut, but the debut of a23 year old. There‚Äôs a lot of really great early performances in this as well. Cuba Gooding Jr, certainly, but also Ice Cube, Nia Long,¬†and Angela Bassett. So many of the people involved with this are so new to the film world, but that never hinders the final product. If anything, it just helps add an extra air of down-to-earth authenticity.

Ultimately a totally harmless movie full of incredibly predictable fluff, but one that frequently bored me and regularly demanded its audience to suspend their disbelief. Takes her like forty minutes of the runtime to get to Paris.

Really liked the beginning but as it went on the shifting perspectives kind of lost me. Not in a ‚Äúnot understanding‚Äù sense, but definitely in terms of interest. I never cared about the other characters quite as much as I did Ronna and Claire. The ending is pretty great though (and influenced the extra .5 in my rating), and I liked the overall vibe.
one of the people I watched with said "out of all the movies i've seen from the 90s this is one of the oddest ones. never knew people made shit like this."

I had no idea what to expect fromVengeancegoing into it, but it was surprisingly pretty good! Especially for the directorial debut of a guy primarily known for his minor role inThe Office. The film is certainly¬†a bit on the nose when it comes to hammering in its themes, but it has a good story and an interesting cast of characters that ultimately make its journey worthwhile. Also acts as a decent commentary on the current state of‚Ä¶

Kind of conflicted about this. I guess I just expected more out of it. I enjoyed the film's general themes and its clear love and care for online connections, particularly during COVID, but as a whole I felt like it was pretty disjointed.I also wish that this had taken a little more time to interview some close-knit friend groups with no specific ties to public groups (like the dance or sign language classes), though I get that that's a‚Ä¶

movietitle: Marcel the Shell with Shoes On
review: Super cute and surprisingly funny. Paddington is shaking.

This has some scenes that are genuinely pretty funny, and it's unique in its frank and unglamorized representation of lesbians, but it's ultimately far too slow-paced with a few too many comedic misses for me to fully enjoy it.In one scene one of the main characters is cleaning up a public restroom while the other is laying underneath the sinks in the same restroom, casually chatting to her. They act like this is totally normal and not disgusting. This‚Ä¶
this was such a moment in history

Did they actually playMiss Americana & The Heartbreak Princein this? Thinking back I don't think they did... hm. Kinda false advertising.Anyway, this was a nice little look into Taylor Swift and her rise to fame. A lot of stuff I was already aware of either from being friends of fans of hers' or just generally being alive when the stuff happened, but it was presented in an interesting enough way that I was never bored. Didn't realize quite how young she was during the whole Kanye VMAs fiasco.

Harrowing depiction of a black market abortion. The minimalist approach to dialogue and soundtrack helps everything feel more real and, at times, more urgent, even with its frequent long and uncomfortable pauses. This isn‚Äôt something I could see myself revisiting anytime soon, but its existence feels important both as a frank depiction of an unfortunate reality and as a warning. Keep abortion legal, safe, and accessible.

It was storming outside of the theater I saw this in and halfway through, when Steven Yeun was doing his outdoor horse show, the lights flickered and the screen cut out. 4DNopeexperience.They got it back up eventually. Really good movie.
Conceptually really interesting, but it went on a little too long for me.

movietitle: Beavis and Butt-Head Do the Universe
review: Honestly the best iteration ofBeavis and Butt-HeadI've seen - although I'll admit I've only seenDo Americaand a handful of low quality episodes on YouTube.The jokes here are pretty consistently obvious low hanging fruit, but it works more often than not... primarily because Beavis and Butt-Head are the only two in-universe characters who find them funny.Not a bad way to spend an hour on a Saturday night.

There are some genuinely funny lines and visual gags in this - like, intentionally so - but any scene that attempts to portray any kind of real emotion just doesn‚Äôt work for me. Primarily because of the rudimentary animation style, but the attempts at ‚Äúemotion‚Äù also just feel pretty at odds with the specific brand of comedy being employed in the rest of the film.¬†The extended action sequences are similarly a chore to get through.There‚Äôs definitely a good basic concept here, and a clearly skilled cast. Just didn‚Äôt all come together. Also Twitchy is annoying.

Sad to say that this was, at best, mildly amusing and, at worst, awkward in a way that gives you secondhand embarrassment instead of making you laugh. Even though I‚Äôm sure every joke was rehearsed and prepared long before this special, it all feels very off the cuff and random in a way that rarely lands for me.The best bits were consistently the documentary sequences, which had some cute/funny anecdotes. Never felt that those segments ever truly gelled with the stand-up though.
I can‚Äôt believe Andy wanted an action figure of Buzz (lame) instead of his own Sox (cool)
Absolute best part of this is the main character ‚Äúlearning‚Äù nothing from his dream. Really said ‚Äúwow that‚Äôs crazy‚Ä¶ anyway‚Ä¶‚Äù and went right back to living his truth. Gotta respect it.

Apologies in advance if this reads as incoherent. Watching Big Brother as I'm writing it.I'm not a big fan of the high-octane, nonstop visuals ofMoulin Rouge, so I was a bit worried going into this that it wouldn't work for me either. I was expecting something more in-line withFrances Ha's depiction of a directionless adult character. I was also, admittedly, expecting this to be more female-focused and was surprised to see it largely follow the emotional journey of its male lead (in spite of the fact that the description is pretty clear in that regard). Fun, cheesy movie. I don't think the emotional / romantic angle of this film ever works for me, but it's an entertaining watch nonetheless. Obsessed with whoever decided that the vampires should have cartoonish glowing green/red eyes, and make a LOUD generic big cat noise before attacking.

I originally hadThe Sixth Sensefor this scavenger hunt task, but then I ended up watching that in late June. This was recced to me for roulette, and was the next popular movie afterSixth Sense, so I went ahead and substituted it.Pretty good! Given the fact that I've seen so many derivatives of this movie's concept in recent years I was expecting it to feel a bit "stale" in comparison, but I think it works well regardless‚Ä¶
still hits.

Peak Hal Hartley dialogue.Very 90's (in a good way).Not fond of the fact that the core dynamic is between a high school dropout and an adult man, but I also don't think he's portrayed incredibly positively so it ultimately works better for me than other films of the same ilk. Really my only real hang-up with the film. And I guess she could be eighteen. Could be that I was just prepared for the characters to be The Worst afterHenry Foolthough.
Pretty fun movie. Very silly premise. Would beconsiderablybetter without the weird racism going on, particularly in regards to the repeated use of a slur to refer to one of the characters.
Just shy of being Lifetime movie material, but elevated considerably by the film's unique narrative structure as well as Martha Plimpton's stand-out performance as Ainsley.

Laughably bad. Definitely trying to be the nextItin some fashion with its awkwardly written and acted preteen dialogue interspersed with the occasional swear word because it‚Äôs an R-rated movie.Literally nothing is explained in this thing, and not in a way that ever makes for a compelling mystery. And getting that good performance for the leading role was really make or break for this film.. because otherwise it‚Äôs pretty typically written and shot for what it is. movietitle: Would It Kill You to Laugh? Starring Kate Berlant + John Early
review: so fun. so silly. :)

The front half of this film is pretty fun, but around the midpoint it falters and never really finds its footing again. Jennifer Jason Leigh is consistently the saving grace and should have been given even more to do. The narration was kind of a weird choice. Coens remain hit or miss for me.

movietitle: Ghost Dog: The Way of the Samurai
review: Pretty good! I like a lot of the aesthetic choices made throughout the film. The through the sink shot is a very original and fun idea, and I enjoyed a lot of the cartoon analogies as well. This did nothing for me. The parts without the leprechaun are surprisingly boring, and the parts with him are mildly annoying. The leprechaun design/makeup is pretty good I guess.

Knew the twist long before watching, but this is probably one of the kindest ghost movies I‚Äôve seen. Strikes a nice balance between paranormal horror and total ‚Äúfriendly ghost‚Äù territory. Also much love for Toni Collette üíñ

Thematically kind of corny and fear-mongering about new tech, particularly in its ending sequence, but the horror is cool and the narrative is compelling even if i‚Äôm not always on board with its underlying message. Needed more Christopher Eccleston.

Cute movie. Can't say I related to this as strongly as others seem to have, but it's light and fun. The runtime occasionally feels a little bloated for what it is, but it's hard to mind too much when the boys start singing and playing their music.

That Thing You Do!is just like every other film about a band making it big after recording a hit song, but without any twists or engaging characters to make it stand out from the crowd. In true Tom Hanks fashion everything feels incredibly safe and clean cut, with a completely uninteresting and predictable romance at its center. There‚Äôs admittedly nothing too terrible here, but it all feels like a bland waste of time. Liv¬†Tyler is cool though. And the‚Ä¶

A fantastically interwoven narrative with a collection of complex characters at its center. It‚Äôs not always immediately clear what the purpose of some scenes and characters are as the events of the film unfold, but by the end everything is tied up in an incredibly satisfying way. There‚Äôs a really excellent atmosphere created by the film‚Äôs soundtrack and visuals as well. Good stuff all around.

Wish I liked this one more. Romcoms, particularly straight romcoms, have to hitjust the right wayfor me to really enjoy them ...and I can't say this one did it for me at all. Even if it isn't necessarily a traditional romcom. The physical manifestation of the protagonist's anxiety-induced inner voice is an interesting added angle, and the film is nice to look at more often than not, but ultimately this film is just too disjointed andfartoo long for what it is. Airplane sequence cool though.

Most people think when you die you...feel nothing.How do you know?From Reddit.I was admittedly a bit nervous about getting around to this film, as mortality and death as concepts kind of freak me out. As a result though I guess I ended up being kind of underwhelmed by the end product. Because I didn't really have any emotional reaction whatsoever.Die Tomorrowtreats death as mundane. Facts and figures contrasted with seemingly normal moments in peoples' lives‚Ä¶

One of the more consistent anthologies in terms of segment to segment quality. It can occasionally be a bit blunt to a fault about its messaging, and I'm not always a fan of its sense of humor, but it has some really great moments of horror and the messages are still worthwhile ones even if they are presented in an incredibly straight-forward way.The body horror-based kill in the second story, "Boys Do Get Bruised," is kind of amazing for a 90's film.

Probably one of the best, most deranged, depictions of fan culture and the modern desire to go viral with A Cool Story. Completely unintentionally.For those unaware, Disney World has this thing called ‚Äúmagical moments.‚Äù Basically cast members can choose to give a kid a free ice cream when they order it or allow someone to ride a ride two times in a row. Sometimes these are set daily things, for example, at one of the resort hotel shops they‚Ä¶

movietitle: Marina & The Diamonds: Live at House of Blues
review: I love Marina‚Äôs first three albums, but kind of fell out of favor with her after she dropped the ‚ÄòDiamonds.‚Äô Notbecauseshe changed her stage name, but that change also sort of marked a change in her music I wasn‚Äôt a huge fan of.¬†Fortunately, this live-streamed concert just focuses on those first three albums I love! Unfortunately, she‚Äôs kinda bad live!FROOT (as an album) fared the best in terms of live performances here. Probably because they‚Äôre slower songs. Lies from Electra Heart is similarly good for this reason, but the visuals for that song are aggressive strobe lights so. You win some you lose some.

Fun, fresh take on a Jane Austen work. Admittedly this film took a little bit of a hit for me for reasons outside of its control (Hulu kept stuttering and crashing) but it has a pretty likable cast of characters, a banging soundtrack, and a good heart. It‚Äôs a comedy above all else, but one that isn‚Äôt afraid to dip into moments of welcome sentimentality to celebrate love and community.

Kind of conflicted about this one. The first half is something I definitely vibe with. I like the visual aesthetics of Connie and her friend's frequent trips to the mall, and really enjoy the realistic dynamic between she, her mother, and sister. Laura Dern is undoubtedly giving a great performance here as well, really selling the natural curiosity and naivety of teenagehood.All that said, I can't really shake my discomfort with how the film ends.Some spoilers ahead...It's‚Ä¶

(Watched weekly as it released)I imagine it‚Äôs hard to follow-up a critically acclaimed ten hour documentary project with a fictionalized account of the same story. On one hand, there‚Äôs a plethora of material there for performances - reading between the lines of delivery and facial expression not only in the courtroom but in private - but the flip side of that advantage is that everything has already been seen. Theoretically, anyhow.It‚Äôs clear from this version of Michael Peterson‚Äôs‚Ä¶

movietitle: Raggedy Ann & Andy: A Musical Adventure!
review: Pretty cute, but a lot of my appreciation here is more for the animation than anything else. I was really vibing with it narratively/thematically for the first third, up to and including the depressed camel sequence, but I was far less enthusiastic about the characters and songs that came after. After a while it all feels a bit aimless and meandering. The ending is sweet though, and I do really love how great the animation looks. It's so unique and‚Ä¶

Really sweet short film navigating the reality of realizing your gender identity while in a relationship. Uniquely hopeful in its outlook, but not sugar-coated to the point of disbelief. It‚Äôs not immediately clear what the future holds for either character - not to the audience or to themselves - but it is¬†clear that both are willing to work together to work things out.I would love to see a similar narrative expanded into a feature length film where we can‚Ä¶

Believe Women: the Movie. Noble enough premise, but not much more going on here. Also kinda weird to make this movie about the horrors of womanhood center on an American woman in a foreign country, primarily othered by the fact that she does not speak the native language of said country. Seems like a personal problem.Also what was the point of her buying her husband a carved Dracula at the beginning if the killer wasn‚Äôt going to be a vampire/supernatural? The neighbor teaching her the phrase in Romanian never came into play either. Come on now.

Beginnersis incredibly sweet and poignant, but aesthetically very of its time in a way I find difficult to connect to on any meaningful level. Its use of narration over still photos feels very twee in a way that's reminiscent of predecessorsAm√©lieand500 Days of Summer(andSubmarine, which ironically released the exact same day) - but what I think works about those films' use of similar visuals is that the narratives are very low stakes and casual.‚Ä¶

Wanted to like this a lot more than I did but it just didn‚Äôt click with me in the way that it seems to have clicked with so many others. The animation is definitely cool, but the dialogue doesn‚Äôt feel particularly revolutionary to me and the line delivery / voice acting consistently reminds me that this was originally a podcast project.All that said, I find it strange that this was meant to have a second season and only doesn‚Äôt‚Ä¶

Wanna preface this by saying that the English dub of this film is all I had access to at the time of watching ...and the translation feels a little hokey. The basic plot here also feels a little too convenient and rushed at its most pivotal moments though, and I don't know if that can be blamed on a dub. I really enjoy seeing modern 2D animation though, especially when the animation and character design is this good. Looovvee seeing all of the different animal species on display here.

Was NOT expecting Ellen to play a major role in this movie. Kind of a jumpscare. Otherwise, this is...fine. It's a pretty surface level satire of reality television and celebrity culture. Kind of wastes Woody Harrelson, and the romance at the film's center is largely uninteresting. Everyone in this film is "real" to a fault - because they're "real" and "down to earth" in a way that just feels boring and, ironically, inauthentic.Mission Hilldoes a similar plot to this but better with theirReal Worldepisode.

I'd be lying if I said I fully grasped what every frame of this meant on a first watch, but I really enjoyed watching it regardless. Pretty good coming of age drama, but one that is almost instantly forgettable. I enjoyed it, but wish it did more to set itself apart.. or that its characters had more unique personalities to draw me in more fully to their story.

Not much to say about this one. It does what it sets out to do very well - which is to make a compelling heist thriller with relevant sociopolitical commentary. movietitle: The SpongeBob Musical: Live on Stage!
review: This is cute! I personally wasn't a huge fan of the original songs in this, but as a musical I think it works regardless. I'm curious if the "world is ending" narrative played differently to the show's target audience (children) during the start of the pandemic. It's not exactly a new angle for a kids' show to take, but it seems strangely prescient that the show was released to a wider audience only a year before an international pandemic. Relevance‚Ä¶

The Descentpretty effectively builds tension to an explosive finale with some pretty gnarly visuals but ultimately I could not care less about any of these characters or what happens to them. They all feel so one-note, almost immediately thrust into danger, with 75% of their dialogue amounting to crying and screaming. Understandably so, I suppose, but when the majority of the film is just living in fear with these characters I'd prefer to have some kind of attachment to them.The more overt horror elements, when they make an appearance, are pretty fun though, and the scene the header image comes from looks fantastic.

The ending here is pretty great, but the lead-up does very little for me. Maybe I was just expecting more out of it because I'd seen the reactions of those who loved it, but a lot of it just felt so slow-paced and drawn out for very little reward.

A series of exceedingly baffling decisions in terms of both narrative and visuals. I initially wasn't as into this as I was the other Hawks movies I‚Äôve seen, but I came around to it in the end. Dorothy and Lorelei kinda gay for all that honestly.

This is trying to do too much in too short of a time period to be really impactful, but it has some really great animation and sound design - especially for the period it was released in. I‚Äôm kind of surprised this doesn‚Äôt have more of a cult following if only for its unique aesthetics and more mature themes.

movietitle: The Girl Who Leapt Through Time
review: Had no idea going in that this was adapted from the same story asThe Girl Who Leapt Through Time. Contrary to popular opinion though I actually liked this version of the story slightly more. The human element and Obayashi‚Äôs charming visual style / effects help to add a layer of likability to the film that the anime lacks. Although I‚Äôm still underwhelmed by the story, it doesn‚Äôt feel quite as generic here. Ending song is a cute touch too even if the version I watched didn‚Äôt sub it.

I have to say‚Ä¶ Shawshank Redemption is pretty good! Controversial opinion, I know. The ending feels a bit hokey, but I otherwise thought it was a really engaging prison story with a cast of instantly likable characters portrayed by actors who are great at what they do.What keeps me from giving this a higher score, as much as I did enjoy it, is just how palatable and ‚Äúlikable‚Äù it is. To a degree to which it all feels a‚Ä¶

I don‚Äôt know if it was the film or if it‚Äôs because I‚Äôm fourteen movies deep into a gorge but I‚Äôm left feeling so empty and confused about this film. Feels like a situation where everything and nothing happened. Definitely feels considerably longer than its ninety minute runtime. Wish I had more to say about this. The visuals and shot structure were often fantastic.

The poster and plot summary forVarietyare pretty great. They seem like a real recipe for a successful, intriguing female character study. Once you‚Äôre actually in the world of the film the coloring and score easily draw you in, being as simultaneously sensual and seedy as the film‚Äôs subject - even if the film itself very rarely shows any actual nudity or sexuality. So‚Ä¶ all that said.. I‚Äôm left kind of puzzled by just how Ok it all was.‚Ä¶

Kind of mixed on this. I think the dystopian concept presented here has potential for a really strong film‚Ä¶ but I don‚Äôt think this is that film. There‚Äôs far too much focus on the love triangle, and the protagonists honestly seem far too complacent about their eventual fate. I mean, I get it! What are you supposed to do? If put in the same situation, tons of people would just live out their lives as best they could. ‚Ä¶but is‚Ä¶

It‚Äôs been said a hundred times over in reviews for this film, but it really is so depressing and infuriating to see just how relevant this film STILL is to current events around the world over two decades after it was released. A film filled with so much justified anger that every minute feels like a bomb counting down the seconds til it explodes - even the minutes spent doing ‚Äúnothing.‚ÄùI‚Äôm not usually a fan of black and white in modern film, but it works really well here. The contrast creates some really striking imagery.

Have to agree with the reviews on here saying this runs a little too short. I'm not a huge fan of a lot of slowburn horror if I'm honest, but this is kind of a speedrun horror. Could have used a bit more build-up once they got to the town. There‚Äôs just so much thrown at the protagonists the second they step foot in there. What's hereiscool though! Solid horror concept and some pretty great visuals to go along with it.

I wish I liked this more. I‚Äôve always been drawn to and intrigued by the poster, but unfortunately I am once again left feeling underwhelmed by a Kiarostami film ‚Äî my first attempt with him beingClose-Up.Although I like the general concept ofLike Someone in Love, and find some of its themes and situations interesting, the execution just doesn‚Äôt do much for me at all. It‚Äôs all a bit too slow-paced and empty. Generational gaps, loneliness, possessiveness‚Ä¶ it‚Ä¶

On some level I get why this did well and launched a franchise, but it‚Äôs not for me. Some special effects that I assume wowed crowds in ‚Äò87 just feel cheap and laughable today, and I don‚Äôt really care for any of the characters here at all. Not at all what I was expecting from this movie. Best Sono I‚Äôve seen so far and it‚Äôs not even close.

First Reformedis strikingly original in some of its visuals and technically well-written and acted. I've never been a huge fan of these multi-movie parody movies but I know a lot of people enjoy this one, and it certainly has more of a cultural impact than something likeEpic MovieorDisaster Movie, so I thought I should eventually give it a shot. Turns out I should have just stuck to knowing this movie through GIFs and minute long clips. The best thing I can say about it is that it is mercifully brief.It‚Ä¶

I don‚Äôt know if it was a great choice to watch this movie at 1 AM. I was kind of expecting a melodramatic romance with a dash of cultural appropriation but the reality is much, much stranger. Guess it was pretty good even if I‚Äôm not completely sold on it at the moment.

Cowboysis such a sweet, warm-hearted movie that nonetheless isn‚Äôt afraid to show some less appealing human complexities within its characters. Joe‚Äôs mother is unaccepting but provides much needed stability, while his father is a little less reliable as a parent but a very good dad when it comes to accepting and trying to understand his son.There‚Äôs a few convenient moments here and there to move the plot along or create conflict where there initially wasn‚Äôt one, but as‚Ä¶

A David Lynch movie that doesn‚Äôt really feel like a David Lynch movie save for the casting and a few background elements. If anything,Dunefeels like an attempt to piggyback off of the success ofStar Wars,but its complex, convoluted plot makes for a less successful film than Lucas‚Äô Western-influenced space saga.Some of the dated CGI is charming, and some of the imagery well-executed, but otherwise this is kind of a confusing bore.
This is such a wild ride‚Ä¶ came for Avril Lavigne competition and stayed for the evil wish doll.

This is entertaining enough for what it is, but ultimately pretty forgettable and bland in its narrative writing and presentation. It didn‚Äôt help that the pre-screening I saw through Netflix was riddled with technical errors - having a late start and cutting off right before the end.Because I just won the screening for this through Twitter and had no plans to review it professionally I don‚Äôt know that I‚Äôll be finishing the five minutes or so I missed when it eventually premieres on Wednesday‚Ä¶ I get the gist. I saw enough.

Halloween Killsis an interesting, and often entertaining, installment to the Halloween franchise, but one that suffers from being a filler entry in a series already known to be a trilogy. Started this on a plane yesterday and just got some downtime to finish it. It‚Äôs cute, if a bit of a mixed bag humor-wise. It certainly gets better as it goes along though. It‚Äôs a nice marriage of muppet hijinks and theme park in-jokes. The use of the downtime spiel is especially great.

Works until it doesn‚Äôt. There‚Äôs a lot about this I vibed with, but almost just as much that left me baffled by its inclusion.I think my biggest criticism here is that I was expecting the car angle to play a bigger role in the story (based on the trailers) and, when it didn‚Äôt, those elements of the story sort of felt like unnecessary shock value layered on top of an otherwise pretty interesting study of identity through complex characters. I‚Äôm sure this was fun to see for diehardSopranosfans years after the series end, but as someone who‚Äôs been binging the series these past two or three weeks it just sort of felt like an overlong episode rehashing stuff we already knew with modern actors.

movietitle: Shang-Chi and the Legend of the Ten Rings
review: Definitely one of the better installments in the MCU in terms of both story and structure.The mix of CGI and martial arts in the characters‚Äô fighting styles made for unique and entertaining action sequences, and the humor never really felt overbearing like it does in some other Marvel films. review: Surprised to see a mostly middling response to this on here.Bob Ross: Happy Accidents, Betrayal & Greeddefinitely has an agenda to put forth and does so with some occasionally pointed music, but I found it to be a pretty well executed documentary nonetheless. I especially appreciate this for not being a fluff piece, even in its representation of its title subject.In a similar vein toWon‚Äôt You Be My Neighbor?, this documentary encompasses both the good and the‚Ä¶
This is a pretty fun time! It feels like a modern screwball comedy in a lot of ways which is cool to watch play out. Not perfect in the writing department, but I enjoyed myself.
