this is pretty much exactly what you‚Äôd expect from the premise. mindless summer comedy movie with lots of predictable jokes and over the top antics with a quickly resolved ending. glad meredith hagner is getting that coin tho.

movietitle: Prom Wars: Love Is a Battlefield
review: This is one of the few movies that I think would genuinely be better if it had been restricted to a PG-13 rating instead of an R. It‚Äôs actually kind of baffling that it isn‚Äôt aiming for a younger demographic because its plot seems custom made for a preteen/teen audience. As it stands though the final film is some weird combination of 2000‚Äôs comedy and Wes Anderson-wannabe prep school characters. Also Phil of the Future is here. ‚Ä¶uh. yeah.

I was surprised by just how much I enjoyed this! The premise feels a little silly in concept, but its serious performances matched well with its darkly humorous writing and helped to set a good tone for its dark ending note. The clues dropped throughout the film make it fun to try and unravel the core mystery, but aren‚Äôt obvious enough to make its solution an easy guess.The little world building moments and townspeople quirks are some of my favorite scenes.. love the gang leader with the peanut allergy where the pat down to see him includes confiscating any peanut candy.

movietitle: Sweets to the Sweet: The 'Candyman' Mythos
review: if i was deathly allergic to bees i simply would not take a job where bees would be all over my face and body but that‚Äôs just me. virginia madsen allowing that to happen (and acting through it!!) kinda makes her a better actor than people who make a big deal of being method though.

Cult of Chuckyis absolutely bonkers. Certainly more reserved thanBrideorSeed, but it nonetheless feels like a complete tonal departure from its most recent predecessor,Curse of Chucky. As much as I'm glad that the absurdity has been injected back into the franchise with this installment, however, I can't say I was completely on-board with its madcap narrative or its uncomfortable displays of psychiatric abuse in what is largely a comedic horror film. I am a fan of posessed!Nica and Tiffany though...wish that that concept had played a bigger role in the film.

Not entirely sold on the ending here - I think the ambiguity works up to a point, but there are a few too many loose threads that don't entirely make sense to me personally. I'm mostly hung up on the bookstore girl, although I could see myself caring less about specifics if I ever revisited this with the knowledge that there wouldn't be any concrete answers in the end. The writing and mystery of the film's first half are really‚Ä¶

Bunionis competently shot and has the benefit of having some good performers in its cast but its narrative feels so aggressively average - particularly the ending note. Also you never see the bunion (lame)

movietitle: The Naked King: What a Beautiful Life
review: I was kind of underwhelmed by this short in spite of its stellar animation and character design. It feels like a teaser for an anime series rather than a one-off short - there‚Äôs just too much story for the less than five minute runtime. The protagonist being gay feels especially glossed over given its apparent relevance to the short‚Äôs rushed plot. The only explicit reference to his homosexuality I can parse is the pink triangle collar - and even that‚Äôs sort of blink and you‚Äôll miss it.Ultimately a case of a decent idea with good art but poor narrative execution.

movietitle: Batman Is Just Not That Into You
review: lego joker is the only modern joker interpretation I want to see more of.can‚Äôt say I understand the hatred people seem to have for this short. yeah, it‚Äôs silly and inconsequential, but I don‚Äôt think it‚Äôs necessarily meant to ‚Äúfit into the canon.‚Äù it‚Äôs just a fun short playing off of the joker and batman relationship in the main film. nothing groundbreaking or hilarious, just inoffensive and easily likable.

Curse of Chuckyisn‚Äôt great, but I also don‚Äôt know that it‚Äôs deserving of the extreme hatred it gets. I will say though that itispretty damning that the best scenes here are post-credits. Those little call backs to the films that precededCursejust work so much better than the weird new lore they tried to insert into this film. Serial killer Charles Lee Ray hopelessly in love with some woman to the point of regularly bringing her‚Ä¶

It‚Äôs unfortunately a little overstuffed, skimming over sections of Franklin‚Äôs life through sheer necessity, but it‚Äôs a pretty solid biopic that manages to adequately address her home life, activism, and career.

Even as a so-called ‚Äúanti-villain‚Äù The Blind Man just ultimately does not work as a co-protagonist following the events of the first film. review: "Folks, we live in a very spooky-style world,"Live Forever as You Are Nowis definitely my favorite of Alan Resnick's short films for Adult Swim. The sick kid with an avatar really helps to sell the creepy factor of this short even though, as a whole, it's more darkly humorous than it is genuinely discomforting. The repeated bit about digital Alan Resnick's wife brings this down a bit for me, but as a whole I really enjoy this.

movietitle: Judge Not: In Defense of Dogma
review: Judge Notis more of a glorified DVD special feature than an actual documentary, but is nonetheless pretty interesting in its exploration of the controversy surrounding the release ofDogma. It would have been cool to actually see and hear more of the actual words of the film's dissenters to see how wild their arguments got but I assume there just wasn't much footage of the protestors to work with. Pretty sick poster for what amounts to forty minutes of people saying "the backlash was weird and unfounded" though.

Really great concert performance by Liza Minnelli. Enjoyed 'Liza with a Z,' theCabaretmelody, and the cover of 'Son of a Preacher Man' best. Not sure about the choice to sing 'My Mammy' even if it was for her literal mother...

What a wild, yet incredibly human, story from start to finish. There are some moments where it feels like the film briefly meanders off topic, dragging down the narrative as a result, but as a whole I think this is something pretty special.

Crip Campis a wonderful piece of history on film with a very human angle. It's a heartfelt documentary about a summer camp for disabled teenagers, narrated primarily by the words of the campers themselves. The camp gave these people their first taste of freedom and agency, a feeling which would carry over into a penchant for activism as many of them pushed for the guaranteed rights of disabled people within America.

As a concept film entirely about the "first ever Animalympics," the Olympics-inspiredAnimalympicscan feel a bit repetitive at times with sequence after sequence of animal sports situations. It does a pretty good job at attempting to remedy the film's natural repetition with a few beautifully animated abstract dream sequences though, and there's a lot to love about the film's wide array of animal-based character designs. It's definitely not a movie that's going to appeal to everyone, but it still feels pretty criminally overlooked and underrated as an art piece.

Movies that use body swapping or transformations as a means for one character getting another to fall in love with them always comes across as strange and a little bit iffy in terms of morality. The mystery plot here is actually pretty decent, but it's so buried by the romance subplots between Daphne and Fred and Shaggy and Velma (with bonus jealous Scooby Doo) that it's hard for the film to really redeem itself with it.Even worse than the teenage romance stuff though is the tacked-on ending song "I Can Be Scared With You" that's sung by the main cast and switches from pop to rap to disco before it's over. Whoever came up with that idea...I just wanna talk.

movietitle: Alvin and the Chipmunks: The Squeakquel
review: Ok, yeah. This one‚Äôs worse. Whereas the first film had some heart, as well as some clear call backs to the chipmunks‚Äô origins, this one just feels so empty of...well, anything really. This is intensely personal in a way that occasionally made me feel like it was something I shouldn‚Äôt be watching. It‚Äôs a very frank depiction of processing the loss of a loved one with Sophy Romvari playing the role of both subject and storyteller. I was on-board with the mystery of the first half, but the last act‚Äôs twist and its outcome really seal the deal on the masterful storytelling at work here. So many elements fall into place perfectly, resulting an ending that is somehow equally as satisfying as it is frustrating.Mothercan also boast some stellar acting from its lead, Kim Hye-ja, whose performance really drives the film and its complex emotional arc. Great stuff.

Central Stationis a really wonderful film - incredibly sweet at its core while not shying away from some very harsh realities. The traveling sequences from Rio de Janeiro to Northeast Brazil also occasionally allow for some really beautiful landscape shots. Not much else to say. Enjoyed this a lot.

I adore the camerawork and super saturated colors in this, and found the club "musical numbers" to be fun, but its narrative failed to hook me despite the fact that similarly cynical films have worked for me in the past. I also just feel like this film calledLolaseemed pretty lacking in scenes with...well, Lola.

movietitle: We're All Going to the World's Fair
review: If I'm honest I'm not sure I'mcompletelysold on this, but it's a pretty one-of-a-kind film. It really leans into the internet culture it draws from, both in its visual presentation and its writing, which works well for the film's overall vibe. There's definitely a bit of weird/slow pacing at times, but for the most part this feels like a deep-dive into some weird, ARG subculture of YouTube. It's "amateur"-looking in a way that feels authentic to its story‚Ä¶

Parts of this....looked nice? With an intriguing premise and promotional image (the all red one), I was excited to watchThe Blazing Worldthis weekend, and was interested to see what Carlson Young could do as a director after seeing her inScream: the TV series. Needless to say, I wasn't very impressed.Although I was initially drawn in by the introductory scenes ofThe Blazing World, the plot goes downhill pretty fast and a lot of the acting leaves‚Ä¶

Knockingis a pretty compelling psychological thriller, building tension not only through the intense acting of its lead actress, but a largely minimalistic soundtrack that elevates the titular knocking, and some pretty interesting camera angles / shots.I think casting its main character as a sort of unreliable narrator plagued by guilt and grief of a lost loved one sort of undermines the core message of women not being taken seriously - because it‚Äôs occasionally hard to tell, even as a viewer, whether or not her concern over the knocking is founded, but the ending is strong even if the lead-up is sometimes frustrating to watch.

This was unironically one of my most anticipated films of the festival. More thanStreet Gang, and more than any of the films by well-known directors or starring well-known actors. I chose the midnight premiere showing of this film at Sundance because I wanted to recreate the feeling of looking at the Glitch in the Matrix reddit sub when I couldn't sleep at 2 am. In spite of my low rating here, it did NOT disappoint in recreating said feeling.‚Ä¶

I really wish I had enjoyed this more than I did because I really loved the aesthetics. The set design, costume design, and just general use of color in this film were wonderful and really helped its characters to pop on-screen. Unfortunately the plot is largely a meandering, disjointed mess that rarely feels like its going anywhere and, even as the credits rolled, I'm still a bit confused as to what..the sister was actually involved with and what we were‚Ä¶

This review is for the Sundance edit / cut.If I'm honest, I wasn't really aware of theactualplot of the film going into it, but I thought that the Letterboxd blurb for it was intriguing enough, and I was interested in seeing both Tessa Thompson in a leading role and Rebecca Hall direct. I'll also be the first to admit that I'm not really the person to be critiquing this film, nor am I the person to be‚Ä¶

Prime Timestarts out about how you'd expect it to from the premise. It's a tense, seemingly high-stakes, thriller that jumps straight into the action. Very soon after, however, it becomes clear that actually getting on air won't be as easy as Sebastian thought it would be. Those at the station have to go through a number of channels and protocol in order to allow him to be on-air, some of which require people who aren't immediately in the building‚Ä¶

I seem to be in the minority here, but I actually really enjoyed this. I think it really nails the aesthetics of the low budget 1980's horror films that it draws from and, even though it had less horror elements than I initially expected it to, I think its focus on psychological drama for the brunt of the film actually ends up working in its favor in its lead up to a no holds barred final act. The protagonist's guilt-fueled‚Ä¶
I wish I was half as smart as whoever wrote the kills in this movie.

Wow the new season ofDexteris pretty crazy...John and the Holeis so frustrating to watch because it has such a good framework built-up only to completely squander the execution.Nothing happens in this movie.Or, at least, nothing of consequence happens in this movie. It has a solid premise, and Charlie Shotwell's performance as John is adequately creepy, but I struggle to find any meaning in this film - least of all its subplot about a little‚Ä¶

Fun movie. I feel like I've seen some people regard this as a lesser Ghibli movie but looking at the average here that doesn't seem to be the case - which is good! It's definitely more grounded and has a more simplistic story than a lot of the stuff Ghibli has put out before and after it, but it's a well-done movie with a great cast of characters. The ending feels a bit lackluster in terms of wrapping things up, but overall it's a good time.

I am a simple woman, I see a movie about two female friends growing apart that can be read as gay if you squint and I give it a positive score and a like. I read another review here that described this as "Frances Habut if the characters were hornier and perpetually drunk," and that's a pretty good summary of it even if the writing is never really up to par withFrances Ha. The wardrobe department kinda went off here.

Taipei Storyis a largely slow-paced drama film following the lives of detached, lonely people at a loss for what to do in the newly bustling Taiwanese cityscape they call home. They cling to their nostalgia-washed pasts, fumbling to maintain their current jobs and relationships. My lack of connection to this film is honestly largely my own failing rather than the film‚Äôs.. I admittedly wasn‚Äôt really in the right mood or headspace for something of this nature but I had‚Ä¶

I really enjoyed this even if I'm not quite sure what to make of all of its parts. It's definitely something I want to revisit sometime in the future. The animation style and character design are really stellar though.

A lot of films attempt to depict the deterioration of the mind with age, but few that do are as visually impactful asMemorable. The changing styles of the stop motion figures work incredibly well to represent the increasingly abstract real life figures in the protagonist's life. The final sequence is one of the best, perfectly capturing a half finished painterly style that miraculously works in the world of three-dimensional figures.

This place is full of sad people so I really like it! Look at how sad they are!I really love the experimental, glitchy aesthetics of this short. You can definitely tell that it had a low budget in some of the effects / costuming, but I think Meisekimu Genshi really made the budget work in their favor to add to rather than distract from the films vibe. The pieces we get of the narrative are interesting, although it is‚Ä¶

I loveUp, butUpwants whatThe House of Small Cubeshas.The core story of this film is one that has been done a hundred times over, but the vehicle of how the story plays out is very unique - as is, I think, its distinctive, sketchy animation style. The soundtrack is appropriately sentimental and the color palette very warm and nostalgic. A lot to love.

This is cute, and thankfully never tries to be something it's not. There's no air of seriousness or pretention, just a man working through the loss of his brother with the help of some neighborhood kids "kidnapping" him.I see a few reviews here mention wanting it to be longer, but I think the short form works well for the subject. It could definitely have a bit more of an emotional impact with further character development, but at its core it's a pretty simplistic concept and I think we know as much as we need to for the film to work.

I feel like the narrative of this short could have been a bit better told in a feature. As is, it feels like there‚Äôs a few too many elements at play and not enough time to really establish the characters and their relationships well enough for its ending note to make an impact. The acting is also a bit lackluster, particularly in some of the junkyard scenes. Really nice visuals and aesthetics though, and I like the general idea and themes the short explores.

I was scrolling through some of the other reviews on here and apparently this was made by a fourteen year old??I mean, with that knowledge, I think it definitely shows in some aspects - the initial moment of the two girls together has some awkward dialogue and acting that admittedly gave me a bit of secondhand embarrassment - but there‚Äôs so many other aspects of this film that are beyond impressive. I think more than anything else I really‚Ä¶

I knew absolutely nothing about Blaze Foley, the subject of this film, prior to watchingBlaze, but Ethan Hawke's biopic of the man is a multifaceted, and often sympathetic, portrait of the Texas born singer-songwriter. The film's warm, sepia-toned color palette might have felt cheesy in another context but I think it works perfectly here, married with Foley's melancholy country music, and the film's three separate storylines interweaved into a single narrative make for a nice departure from the typical‚Ä¶
Very strange.. not quite sure how to interpret this one, but I like some of the attempts to do so on here. The art style is incredibly unique and equally as unsettling.

I was going to say that the majority of this feels like an AMV, but I saw some reviews here mention that it's a music video so apparently that's basically what it is. It has a decent story concept though, and some nice animation.
The girl rubber band figures have dresses and hair so you can rest easy knowing that the protagonists are in a heterosexual rubber band person forbidden relationship, not a gay one.

I think it would have been a little cooler had the mecha mutt controller's motivation been that her own work was getting overshadowed by her dad's fame rather than that she felt ignored by him in general, but this is a pretty fun Scooby-Doo story nonetheless.

There were a few moments while watching this where I felt it was going on a little long and becoming a bit repetitive in some areas, but as a whole I really dig Cecelia Condit‚Äôs style.Suburbs of Edenfeels so ahead of its time in its content and presentation while maintaining a visual style reminiscent of amateur home videos. Adult Swim‚Äôs shorts serieswishesit had what Cecelia Condit has.

Really charming stop motion animation from the director ofMary & Max. The characters are all a bit off-kilter with their individual quirks laid out by the short‚Äôs narration, but the script never really feels like it‚Äôs mocking them for these quirks. There‚Äôs certainly bits meant to be darkly humorous but these moments, more often than not, poke fun at society and unfortunate situations moreso than they do the characters themselves. The animation style, character design, and sets perfectly match the short‚Äôs simultaneously dark and whimsical tone and easily endear the viewer to its big-eared and wide-eyed protagonist.

movietitle: Euphoria: F*ck Anyone Who‚Äôs Not a Sea Blob
review: Man,Trouble Don‚Äôt Last Alwayswas a nice add-on toEuphoriathat gave Rue more depth and allowed for some nice insight into her worldview,¬†but this special feels absolutelyvitalto the series and I honestly can‚Äôt imagine the alternate universe where they just jumped straight into the second season.As the series is told entirely from Rue‚Äôs perspective, we hear much of Jules‚Äô story - past and present - secondhand.F*ck Anyone Who‚Äôs Not a Sea Blobgives us‚Ä¶

For as long as I've known aboutSaw's existence, I've heard people equate it to torture porn - so I was surprised to find out that the majority of this film is told in flashback to establish the lore of Jigsaw and the two trapped men. If I'm honest, it probably could have used a little bitmorehorror ..and a little bit less of the erratic editing. The ending does attempt to make up for the elongated exposition though, and I'm thankful for it. Lots of last minute twists and rash decisions always makes for a fun time.

I love the character design in this. It's a very different aesthetic from the creatures inAllure, by the same director, but it works perfectly for the short. The human teeth in particular give the characters a weird, eerie edge to their otherwise friendly, rounded figures. I'm not sure I'm totally on board with the execution of the concept here, but it's definitely a unique idea and I like what it's going for.

This has some cute critter designs. I especially like the way they blink. It seems like an overcomplicated little detail for a stop motion/puppet, but it definitely gives them more life. The angler fish-like concept from the perspective of the prey is neat as well. Fun, cartoonish short.

Pupariahas some really beautiful, intricately detailed animation, and plays out like key sequences from a feature film that exists in some alternate universe. The soundtrack helps to add to this haunting, otherworldly feel, as does the superb character design of the white-haired alien(?) being seen at the end of the short. Their multicolored eyes in particular are magnetic..

I sawDancer in the Darkin 2016 and loved it. Two years later I sawAntichristand found it to be pretty boring in spite of its shock content. Did not enjoy it at all. These two polar opposite reactions to Von Trier's work meet somewhere in the middle forBreaking the Waves.To some degree I can admire this film's craftmanship. Tapeis really a quintessential low budget, late 90's/early 00's indie play adaptation, featuring three actors confined to a single motel room having conversations. I think it mostly works for me. movietitle: The Orange Years: The Nickelodeon Story
review: At a time when most cartoons played like toy commercials and a lot of live action children's programming was either aimed towards a preschool demographic or thought to "talk down" to kids, Nickelodeon aimed to be a networkfor kids- a network with strong values that took children and their needs seriously and represented the wide breadth of what being a kid in the modern age could mean.The Orange Years: The Nickelodeon Storyis a documentary applauding these‚Ä¶

The story ofMinariis the story of the American dream, following a family of Korean immigrants intent on making a living for themselves in the rural U.S. Unlike many stories of the same ilk, however,Minarinever feels too melodramatic nor blandly patriotic. Love & Saucersis surprisingly comprehensive in its presentation of its subject‚Äôs alleged alien experiences and artwork depicting them in spite of its short runtime. It‚Äôs an interesting alternate perspective about the universe, and a really kindhearted one at that. Whether this guy was really visited by extraterrestrial beings or not, I‚Äôm glad his son and neighbors support him wholeheartedly in his life and artistic pursuits.

movietitle: Tell Me That You Love Me, Junie Moon
review: Very warmhearted indie drama film with an interesting cast of "misfits" that just misses the mark for me in terms of story and execution. There's a lot of elements ofTell Me That You Love Me, Junie Moonthat are very charming and likable, particularly the film's characters / performances, but the largely plotless narrative doesn't really work for me here. The folksy guitar ballads that bookend this film really give the film as a whole a sort of "quirky" vibe, but I think it's one that's more endearing than it is cringey. Altogether a likable but forgettable movie.

movietitle: Scream, Queen! My Nightmare on Elm Street
review: A pretty good horror documentary exploring the legacy ofA Nightmare on Elm Street 2and the impact that its legacy had on the film's star, Mark Patton. Alongside its discussion of Patton's life and personal battle with AIDs, the film dives in to some of the homophobia within the horror fan community - which is a subject I personally haven't really seen discussed a lot in "fandom" documentaries like this.The film isn't anything groundbreaking, but it's an interesting look back at an iconic horror film and how outside interpretations of it temporarily ruined the career of its lead.

movietitle: Bazaar Bizarre: The Strange Case of Serial Killer Bob Berdella
review: This is an incredibly absurd documentary with amateur editing and a baffling narrative structure. Reenactments of Bob Berdella's horrific crimes are intercut with talking heads of his neighbors saying they "couldn't believe he would do such a thing" and, strangest of all, music video segments of The Demon Dogs Band performing songs related to the documentary.The most interesting segments are of Berdella himself and of the prosecutors involved with his case - though neither are given quite enough attention in comparison to everything else at play here.

dark lego movie with terrible characters and laughable dialogue. it tries to shoehorn in some emotional plotline at the end but it doesn't work at all for me. on the plus side, this is probably the only movie you'll hear the phrase "hooker who can't afford any hooks" in.a full star instead of a half star just because they had the audacity to release this thing and cast big name actors trying their best with what they're given.

When I watched this for my personalDisney challengeI was watching it in the context of the films made before and after it and really only focused on the fact that it was a bunch of different stories working well together in contrast to the package films that came before it but, watching it more for story now, it‚Äôs amazing how much this plays out like a dream. This tries to be a lot of things at once and...weirdly succeeds? movietitle: Your Light: Kase-san and Morning Glories
review: This is sweet and visually stunning, but I feel like it‚Äôs lacking in story. Although I get the gist of the characters and their relationship I feel like some of the seemingly disjointed scenes could have been better weaved together. Dialogue may help, though it‚Äôd ruin the overall montage aesthetic.
anyone who thinks the ending ofToy Story 3is dark needs to watch this movie immediately

An entertaining documentary about a group of film buffs obsessed with consuming cinema to the point that they go to the theater 2 to 5 times a day and structure their diet around making sure they don't have to use the bathroom during a film. I especially loved the MoMA stories about Roberta Hill. All of these people are a little unhinged, but also maybe a little charming..?I would be interested to see a similar film made today after‚Ä¶

The art style and concept are both fun but the short itself is just sort of okay. Although it's lengthier than most amateur animation, in story it feels more like something I would watch from an artist graduating college than from people established in their field. Some funny jokes here and there but overall a pretty overdone cartoon concept.

I really wanted to like this but I think, as a narrative film, it doesn't work. Although it advertises itself as a murder mystery story,The Owlsspends more time on talking head bits in which the actors in the film talk about their personal history with being queer and/or lesbians and about their characters motivations than it does on actually expanding its fictional characters and their stories through the film's story or dialogue. This film is interesting for the sole fact that it's a look at what Disneyland was like when it initially opened, but it's unfortunately a little dull in its presentation of that footage. My favorite part is when they show each member of the family learning they just won a trip to Disneyland and promptly "passing out."

Eh.Layer Cakehas really nice cinematography and the writing/dialogue is technically good, but I could not have cared less about the characters or their lives. I've seen other reviews on letterboxd that say basically the same - that it looks nice but the story was dull - so I know it wasn't just me, but I'm sure the fact that I don't necessarily care for the genre to begin with didn't help matters much. Beyond its visuals, the film doesn't really bring anything new to the table.

movietitle: Women on the Verge of a Nervous Breakdown
review: I thought the story could have been a little better, but this film was very stylish and had a great sense of humor. I loved the wardrobe, set design, and coloring a lot. A fun watch.

the absolute drama of it all...As others here have said, this is definitely the natural film predecessor toOrange is the New Black, but with a narrower focus on family dynamics and personal relations. Although not nearly as strong as Dunye's first feature length film from a visual or character perspective,Stranger Insideis a solid prison drama that continually kept my interest throughout its quick 97 minute runtime. The twist is also devastating, and entirely unexpected.
This had no right to be as good as it was. The cinematography? The early reveal instead of doing a typical shock ending? Lifetime snapped.

Some of the songs and framing narrative could have been cut for a more concise (and better told) story, but overall this was a very cute little animated film. I like a lot of the set and character design - very loose/sketchy and whimsical. It fits well with the "point" of the story.

love the polaroid visuals here. the concept works really well with the film's short runtime. not all of them directly relate to the casual conversation about differences in slang terms going on in the narration, but none of them feel out of place either. a nice change of pace from a more typically shot film.

about MY PROBLEMS !!!!Talking frankly in front of a camera about a high school friendship seems like a weak idea for a short film, especially when it's your first short film, but Cheryl Dunye makes it work. She's great at storytelling, and makes even the most seemingly average conversational topic interesting and impactful.

Some of the acting and line delivery in this admittedly isn't that great, but for an independent director's first feature length film it's pretty amazing. The subject of finding out about an actress from a single film and immediately going to research them and all of the work they've done is ..extremely relatable and I love how this film handles the idea of lost and buried media through its main character's fascination with "The Watermelon Woman" Fae Richards. Wasn't terrible, but also wasn't very good. I liked some of the stylistic choices even if the coloring was a bit of an eyesore. The big fight scene towards the end of the film is a ton of fun. Only knocked down half of a star for the strange behind the scenes choice to make Don Shirley unaware of his own culture and (according to his family) unlike how he actually acted in real life. movietitle: Disneyland - My Good Old Native Country
review: When it opened in 1992, Disneyland Paris was a tremendous failure - due in part to the massive clash between American and French culture. People against the park's opening claimed that its existence was an "invasion of American culture" and a detriment to the French national identity. Protests were held outside of the parks gates, and noise complaints were filed against the park's nightly fireworks displays. Even some interested in the theme park would eventually be dissuaded by advertisements boasting‚Ä¶

review: Early on in the film,Lilo & Stitchco-director Chris Sanders mentions that he would often watch "making of" documentaries for animated films and be disappointed in their content - or lack thereof. A by the books biopic on Ruth Bader Ginsberg.Felicity Jones does well in the lead role, particularly during Ginsberg's final rebuttal in the highlighted case, but the film itself is very bland in its presentation of the story. You would get more out of watching theRBGdocumentary, whose use of actual court footage and sound bites showcase Ginsberg's story and achievements better than any reenactment could.

This is a super cute animated short, but I think it would have worked better and been more impactful as a feature length film.It would have been nice to see more of the two main characters' personalities, and interesting to see more of their lives beyond the quick montage of joke-y running sequences we get.

Wonderful concept and wonderful animation style. I love the weight the characters seem to have as they walk/run across the floor and the simplistic designs work very well with the realistically textured crochet.

The coloring and composition in this are so enchanting - at times it's almost like a painting. A wonderful romantic drama with stellar acting from its two leads.I'll admit that I don't watch a lot of romance films in general, especially films where the romance itself is the main focus, but this is probably the best I've seen of the genre. The characters and their story is so well done and well handled by Jenkins.

First 2019 movie! This was definitely a lot of fun, but it sort of lost me towards the end. I'm also not sure that this was a film where showing one of the ending scenes as the first scene worked. It spoiled who would survive and felt like it was preemptively shown exclusively so we had time to focus on other things when we eventually got to the scene in question.
What a crazy story. If this was the plot of a narrative film people would claim that there were too many coincidences for it to be believable. Sometimes life really is stranger than fiction.

I'm not sure if this film wants to be an edgy/dark satire or oscar-bait inspiration porn but it never fully commits to either and instead lands somewhere awkwardly in the middle. A tonally confused and horribly misguided mess.

It's a little shocking to see a somewhat ambiguous ending in a children's film knowing that there was never a sequel made that resolved the ambiguity. It's..a little refreshing, honestly.It's refreshing to see the sheer amount of originality and creativity utilized within this film. Just the core idea of following the lives of the monsters who "live under kid's beds and in their closets" is such a cool concept. I love a lot of little details of the world‚Ä¶

I'm not a huge fan of Jack Black, but this is by far the best acting I've seen from him. His character is funny to watch and full of personality, but the performance never feels too over the top. Everyone in this feels and acts like a real person would - something that I'm sure is helped by the fact that some of the "actors" are actual townspeople who lived in Carthage, Texas at the time of the event.Would have liked for this to have a few less talking heads and maybe some more of the trial/resulting press, but what is here works well.

I knew very little about this movie going into it and was sort of under the impression that it would be lighthearted and quirky despite the fact that there was no solid reason for me to think that. An alright film about an aging punk rock singer and her band. Nothing spectacular, especially in terms of dialogue, but it has a decent story and soundtrack. A slow burn horror film that never really goes anywhere interesting until its final moments. I liked the soundtrack/atmosphere and Mia Farrow worked well with what she was given, but for the most part I found this too dull to enjoy. Some of the dialogue and editing is also ..really strange - the dialogue is more often than not a little too forced/fake and the editing consists of more than a few awkwardly timed cuts.Ending was pretty solid. An overly melodramatic film with flowery, romanticized writing. A bittersweet and sentimental animated short. I love a lot of the unique visual choices here, especially in terms of the blending of photography and animation. Safeis the third Todd Haynes film I have seen, and definitely my favorite. It's not quite as abstract and all over the place as I foundPoisonnor is it as straightforward and by the books as I thinkCarolcan be - instead it's a happy medium between the two, benefiting from both its air of mystery as well as its firm grounding in reality.As an analogy for the AIDs crisisSafeis especially interesting, but even devoid of this context it's an extremely engaging thriller/drama about illness, uncertainty, and the suffocation of daily life with some fantastic visual framing and cinematography.

movietitle: The Diary of a Teenage Girl
review: Minnie is such a great character andDiary of a Teenage Girlis such an incredibly unique coming of age story despite being based on themes that have been done a hundred times before. I love the ending, I love the letter correspondence between Minnie and Aline Kominsky, and I love the little art/animation inserts throughout the film...I wish I didn‚Äôt have to sit through the Minnie and Monroe relationship to see all of the things I love about this movie, but I understand its place in the story.

If I'm being entirely honest, I probably wouldn't have finished this movie had I not been watching it with other people. The exposition is incredibly tedious, all of the characters are either extremely unlikable or vapid and one-dimensional, the rape scene is long and uncomfortably pornographic just for the protagonist to not even find out about it, and the ending violence was barely entertaining or cathartic for me. It somehow manages to simultaneously bore me and disgust me - and‚Ä¶

This is...fine. Basically "what if cartoon characters were actually depressed and hated their job?!?" aka an edgierWho Framed Roger Rabbit?I think I would have liked it more if they had pushed the concept a little and not just fallen into a monotonous repetition of cartoon life versus real life. The mid-credit scene was clever and probably one of my favorites of the short.Visually, the 2D animation worked really well to emulate older Warner Bros. cartoons but the CGI could have been a little more polished.

I'm into sunshine, awareness, good karma, vibes,..and witchcraft.Based on everything in this film's letterboxd page I sort of expected it to be an exploitative and violence-driven torture horror but, as I've found true for more than a few small films of the VHS era, this film doesn't really live up to its color-soaked poster. In fact, until the literal last minutes of the film I don't know that I'd even classify this as a horror movie at all.‚Ä¶

I've known about this movie for a little while now but kept putting it off because I could never decide if it seemed like something I'd like or not. Now, even having seen it, I have the same dilemma. My rating teeters on between a 3.5 or 4, but ultimately I'm left with the feeling of it notquiteconnecting with me.The concept, though it is a simplistic one, is handled very well. The moments in which Sandra wrestles‚Ä¶

I really wanted to like this but it just ended up feeling kind of ...empty. For lack of a better word. Though I understood the motivations behind all of the murders in theory, the logic behind it all seemed very flimsy to me.There were moments of this film that were very powerful both in the way they were written and the way they were shot. I really loved the "Family" section of this film and how it dealt with‚Ä¶

It was nice watching this directly after watchingHalloween(1978) for the first time because it forced me to notice all of the little references sprinkled in throughout. There's a lot of attention to character and detail here that shows the people working on this movie clearly have a lot of love for the original movie.That's not to say this is entirely an homage/screen for screen remake, however. I loved what they did with Laurie Strode and Michael Myers‚Ä¶

Watched in preparation for the new Halloween.I end up feeling meh about a lot of slashers primarily because the lead up to the killing spree is often boring and the characters often underdeveloped but, while the characters here aren‚Äôt the most complex, I actually cared for them and I enjoyed the dialogue/lead-up sometimes more than I did the actual horror elements. Jamie Lee Curtis‚Äôs character is especially great.The confrontation between Jamie Lee Curtis and Michael Meyers is sort‚Ä¶

This isn't over yet, but I feel like I've seen enough of it to give an opinion. It's pretty much exactly what you'd expect. Mostly just background noise to me checking up on other websites - a fashion show halloween costume contest, some musical performances, etc.Only really worth watching for the commentary and appearances by the original cast ...which could have easily been played during the commercial breaks of a rerun of the movie.

This should really be a half star movie but I dolovethe meta concept of the sequel protagonist getting inspiration from the first movie and I enjoyed the scene of Ashlynn Yennie playing herself. I also guess I'm glad that it was shot in black and white, if only because I'm thankful not to have seen some of the more graphic scenes in detail.Whereas the first film had the decency to give its protagonist purpose and motivation, this‚Ä¶

Bursts of this are super fun - the action scenes are full of insane vampire ridiculousness - but for the most part it falls victim to a lot of pacing issues. A decent introductory movie to the character.

My opinions on this are pretty muchunchanged, but if I could log the alternate ending separately it'd probably have a 2 or 2.5 instead of a 3.Apparently after the release of the DVD there will beTHREEendings and they'll have convinced me to watch the same movie three times in one year. The creators ofUnfriendedtruly are innovators.

I‚Äôm very mixed onMay, especially on its ending. While part of me wants to like the end scene because it fits so well with the tone of this movie and with its main character, another part of me feels like it‚Äôs a littletoocheesy and ridiculous.While I did love a lot of this, so many scenes feel just one or two degrees away from being perfect to me. I‚Äôm not even sure what I would change nor‚Ä¶

movietitle: Izzy Gets the F*ck Across Town
review: I feel like it's been almost two years now that I've been waiting to see this movie. And it's...fine. I probably hyped it up too much in my head and I admit I may be being a little bit too hard on it because of that. This seems to have all of the different components of a movie I'd really love but it just doesn't connect. The side characters are just a little too quirky and the dialogue notquite‚Ä¶

I'm genuinely surprised by the high rating this has on letterboxd and by how many people have given it 4.5-5 stars. While I thought that the performances were phenomenal and Lady Gaga's acting will probably earn her some nominations (she wasgreatin this) I felt that overall it was just sort of an alright movie.This is partially because of the script, which I think probably needed another rewrite or at least another pair of eyes on it before‚Ä¶

I'm very mixed on this movie. It has a very character-driven, loosely plotted sort of feel to it but there are a few too many characters to focus on. Even characters who were unquestionably more "main characters" than others are lost in the sea of partying and punk rock music - I don't get any strong feelings of individual personality from any of them. I feel similarly to it as I do toDazed and Confused, but withDazedI‚Ä¶
sweet little animated short about a dog and his overworked owner. really cute art style + character designs. love the concept ‚ô•üê∂

movietitle: Billy and Mandy in: Trepanation of the Skull and You
review: Surprised that the few reviews on here for this short say it's "super dark" and seem surprised that Cartoon Network would pick it up. I feel like this is incredibly in line with a lot of 90's cartoon shows on CNandNickelodeon. If this exact scene played out inRen & Stimpyparents might complain, but I honestly don't think many would have been surprised.The short itself is fine. It reminded me a lot of some of the short‚Ä¶

I liked the concept behind this film and the differences in each of the segments' styles but I just couldn't connect with any of it and bouncing around from story to story didn't help my case at all, especially in the first part of the film when the segments took a longer time to move from one story to another.'Hero' was my probably favorite visually and, at the beginning, conceptually, but after a while I ended up growing tired‚Ä¶

movietitle: Night Is Short, Walk On Girl
review: I don't know how I feel about this as a whole, but I really loved certain segments/moments of it and the animation was consistently beautiful. Likely would rate a 3 or 3.5 based solely on the film itself - bumped up to a 4 for the visuals.From an animation standpoint this definitely became one of my all time favorites in terms of anime films and likely in terms of animation in general just because of how bouncy/lively it is.‚Ä¶

Disappointing. A lot of the horror elements don't feel earned and, keeping in mind that I don't know anything about the creator of this short, the sexual fantasy felt exploitative and out of place. The inciting incident happens and then we're just sort of hit over the head with horror cliche after horror cliche before coming back to an unexplained reality in which two characters are gutted and it's assumed the protagonist is to blame.While I'm a fan of‚Ä¶

[I did it] for the LOLsGod this movie is soSTUPID. It's visually very impressive and there's a lot to love about the cinematography, the editing, the colors... even the main house set is pretty incredible, but the dialogue leaves a lot to be desired. So much so that the film's beginning is a little hard to get through.The parts of this film I liked the most were those that leaned more towards thriller/horror than teen drama/comedy. After‚Ä¶

Pretty incredible stop motion composed entirely of paper crafts. A very simplistic and fun on-screen interpretation of fears surrounding industrialization and its effect on the home and family ending with fox and mole deciding that they should just move to space to avoid modern issues altogether.

Although I couldn't find a subbed version of this short, from what I could find online it's apparently a music video for a song by Taeko Oonuki and the story is meant to follow a child's dream of what the neighbor's dog does during the day. I'm still uncertain about the Sherlock Holmes-esque human character who features at the beginning of the short, but what I do understand is that this is incredibly cute and charming. I'm in love with these character designs and this animation style.

I wish that this had been better. The "child" voice at the short's beginning and end is obnoxious and the dialogue between mother and child so tonally awkward when matched with the story itself. If it had been played straight as a vaguely unsettling tragic romance kind of thing I think I would have enjoyed it more, but I know that wouldn't have really matched with Babbit's usual style.The soundtrack is great though and is pretty much this short's main saving grace.

I was really shocked by this when I saw it earlier this year at a documentary film festival and the shock value alone made me really enamored with it but unfortunately it doesn't really hold up as much on rewatch. Despite it still being a revelation of a shocking moral dilemma, even knowing that something "dark" happens (as opposed to just knowing three twins found each other) is already knowing too much.The editing is very much so THIS IS‚Ä¶

I took a while to finish watching this after starting it which is entirely my own fault but I already feel like it's due for a rewatch in the near future because of it. Having only been exposed to the poster/still on the letterboxd page,The Lureisn't anything like what I expected it to be but what it turned out to be was initially a ton of fun and then ultimately a very bittersweet fairy tale. I can't say‚Ä¶

I watched the new episode of AHS in between finishing this and logging it so my thoughts are sort of jumbled but I did enjoy this.I sort of wish this movie was longer because I feel like we could have known more about the world/town, but what is here is all that'sreallynecessary to make the film work.The visual style, presumably inspired by Refn, is pretty great - I especially loved all of the scenes/performances in the‚Ä¶

I'm so conflicted on what to rate this and keep mentally bouncing between a 3 and 3.5. The cinematography and just the general richness of the colors in this film are beyond amazing and the interviews featured are so fundamentally human and personable ..but the editing sort of ruins it all for me.While I understand that the way this film is edited is revolutionary for a documentary and its blending together of people, voices, and locations helps to build‚Ä¶

I'm surprised to see that there seems to be a big divide with this movie on letterboxd. While I definitely felt it had its narrative issues, I loved a lot of the cinematography and the performances by Matthew McConaughey and Bel Powley were really great. An interesting albeit far from perfect biopic with an unconventional lead/story.

movietitle: Dear Zachary: A Letter to a Son About His Father
review: Despite correctly guessing what would happen before it did, I was no less devastated when the revelation finally came. I kept hoping that itwouldn'tbe true and when it was I could feel myself tearing up despite the fact that I rarely cry at movies. The editing in some parts of this documentary is very abrasive and can definitely come across as emotionally manipulative if not just generally manipulative but, given the circumstances, such a thing is very understandable.‚Ä¶

I haven't seen this in over five years and this watch was the dub so I guess criticism of the writing/dialogue should be taken with a grain of salt but it definitely could have been better than it was. Francis's English voice actor was also....Not Great at all which is a shame because the rest of the cast was actually pretty decent for an independently made German animation.Despite the awkward dialogue issues though the story is a really unique‚Ä¶

The "I Ain't Got No Body" visual gag that's held on screen for a minute or two is pretty funny, but otherwise this feels like a cheap re-use of the animation/concept fromRed Hot Riding Hoodwith the addition of Droopy and gun violence and the removal of the grandma bit.

A blown up game of cat and mouse ...and dog..and canary. While this short film was likely created as a satirization of the Cold War arms race when it was initially animated it ended up birthing hundreds of weirdo artists in the age of the internet. Funny how art grows and is interpreted in different ways by different people and eras...The short itself is pretty standard cartoon humor/antics. Nothing too spectacular here, but still has a very distinctive Tex Avery charm.
Very simplistic plot/joke done well. Love the introduction of Bugs reading the title card and tearing it apart before trying to disprove it.

I thought I had seen this before but I think I had somehow just seen the performance/wolf whistle scene. I love the self referential nature of a lot of Tex Avery shorts and this definitely succeeds in that light; the animation is pretty great too. I love how far the expressions are pushed without being awkward, especially in terms of "Red Hot Riding Hood"'s reactions to the wolf.

movietitle: She Had Her Gun All Ready
review: I have no idea how I feel about this and I'm uncertain about what to rate it. I think that while the narrative was minimalist enough to work in the way that it was presented, the emotions could have been less subdued and the runtime shorter in order to convey a more powerful message. The concept is good, but the way it's ultimately presented could be better.

From an art perspective this is really amazing. I love the changes in aspect ratio and the inter-cutting of real life forest footage with the animation/artwork, and the character designs and drawn backgrounds are really well done. I wish the music in the first half hadn't been so overwhelming that it masked some of the dialogue, but I understand the effect it was intended to have.All and all a pretty great and innovative little short which can be watched in fullon Youtube.

If you know me at all you shouldn't be surprised by this rating and you should also know that it's not a meme/joke rating. This is real and I love this stupid movie! From the darker side of Paul Feig babie!!!!The ending of this movie is a ridiculous, no holds barred whirlwind of information and plot twists but not in a bad way. AlthoughA Simple Favorstarts pretty normally, the dip into complete madness was gradual enough that‚Ä¶

This didn't have as big of an impact on me as it seems to have some of the people I follow on here, but I still really enjoyed it. The scene shown from security camera footage and the underwater scene were really well done and there was some fantastic acting from Joaquin Phoenix throughout. Wish I could have liked it as much as I didWe Really Need to Talk About Kevinbut some aspects of it didn't really click with me, even though it is masterfully done from a visual point of view.

The concept of this is great and some of the editing/camerawork looks amazing but the weirdly written dialogue and unnaturally mechanical movements (which I know were purposeful) just made everything too cheesy and over the top for me to enjoy. The ending was also a little ridiculous even though I guessed a third of it would happen from the beginning.I understand why people enjoy this as it is a fun movie - it's notbad- I just think I would have enjoyed it more if I had been able to take it a little more seriously.

This felt like obvious set-up for the coming Cloverfield universe and prequel lore for the first two films and ..not much more than that.The rules of what could and couldn't happen in the alternate world were pretty murky and despite all of the scenes of gore and death and apocalyptic survival I never really felt like anything was actuallyhappening. It was entertaining to watch, but I didn't feel anything about any of the characters or situations.

With no power, a dead computer, and three movies downloaded to Netflix mobile I was finally forced to watch this. I was surprised by how much Ididn'tknow about what was going to happen. It was cute.I don't really have much to say about this tbh, but I do think that the Andrew and Allison relationship (that I knew was going to happen) was sort of shoehorned in at the end. The conversations they did have were pretty minimal and there wasn't as much "chemistry" as there seemed to be with Claire and Bender.

This was unfortunately a huge disappointment. Although the description sounded interesting, it ended up being too "quirky" for me - which is saying something because I'm usually a fan of slightly off-kilter coming of age stuff. I'm actually shocked that this has a 3.2 average here and a93%on Rotten Tomatoes.I genuinely think that if this movie had been played straight with more seriously written dialogue and maybe even without "the ghost of Andy Warhol" (who ended up‚Ä¶

I've been dealing with hurricane Florence, so please bear with me while I sit and log everything that I've been watching since my power went out on Thursday.I've wanted to rewatch this for a while because even though I rated it four stars and liked it I couldn't remember much at all about it. I think I was right in my rating and might even consider bumping it up to a 4.5 at a future date.Toni Collette and‚Ä¶

It's weird to me that some reviews complain about the fact that some of the audio/interviews and tour footage were already available prior to this short film. I personally loved the weaving of artistic interpretations of her struggles with the actual tour/interview footage from around the time the "mental imagery" is taking place. It made the interviews etc. more moving to me.Ilovedall of the editing/visuals in this. I wish this was an entire visual album or feature length documentary.Nothing is real, love is everything, and I know nothing.

Always leave the party while you're still having fun.Marketing for independent films is really insane. Even though the description of this mentions that it's an "intense relationship drama" based on the lighthearted poster I assumed the element of mystery would mean it was more of a whodunnit among friends and lovers instead of an incredibly emotional film about AIDs and assisted suicide.In terms of construction,The Eventis fairly average. The concept of telling the majority of the‚Ä¶

Although I glanced at the plot when I was recced this for roulette I forgot most of it by the time I actually got around to watching it and went in pretty much completely blind - and I'm glad I did. I don't have much to say about this, but it's such a super fun and interesting concept/idea and the acting from Sam Rockwell (and voice acting from Kevin Spacey) was phenomenal and both actors did their part to carry‚Ä¶

A well-written thriller/drama with a Hitchcockian feel. Although I stupidly read reviews that led me to guess the ending twist a little over halfway into the film I still ended up enjoying everything that led up to it. I sort of wish it had ended differently, partially because I wish I had been surprised and partially because I liked the concept of the women teaming up to kill their abusive lover better than the inevitable actuality of the situation, but I don't really fault the film for that.The ending 'notice' not to tell your friends about what happened is cute.

With all of its twists and turns and melodrama this could easily pass for a Lifetime original movie based on script alone, but the casting and screen-driven visuals really elevate it to something more. Although I found it to be very predictable towards the end with a lot of glaringly obvious hints peppered throughout, I still thought it was super enjoyable.I hope this paves the way for more screen-driven narratives outside of the horror genre.

It‚Äôs ..alright. The characters were likable enough, but there was a lot I didn‚Äôt find that funny and most of the ‚Äúemotional‚Äù moments felt very forced and awkward. It doesn‚Äôt help that a lot of the main parent plot was shown in the trailers which I saw a million times at the beginning of this year, which definitely made me biased against it going in.It‚Äôs nice that this was a wide release prom comedy that had a lesbian as‚Ä¶

I was more than a little disappointed with this. While the concept is unique and, for the most part, well thought-out, it wasn't utilized enough for me to enjoy the movie as a whole. Although I understood that the overuse of tropes was the point of the film's first half, it was a chore to get through because of it. I wish more of the film had been like the unrepentant insanity of its ending.Really loved the clip we‚Ä¶
This was alright. Obviously nothing fantastic but the nods to the cartoon were cute even though they weren't always executed in the best way.

There are a few moments where it seems like it could become great and others where it almost is, but in the end it just doesn‚Äôt get there. The final act is especially convoluted right down to the final audio cue.

Although it obviously wouldn‚Äôt have been relevant/possible at the time this was made, something like this would translate really well into a Netflix (or similar streaming service) series. The houses and people who lived in them were very interesting but the segments felt very episodic and I wanted to know more about each home and the people around the immediate owners.

movietitle: How to Talk to Girls at Parties
review: This is a movie that wants to be silly and weird but doesn‚Äôt quite push it far enough for me to fully enjoy the silly weirdness. The coloring and costuming in this movie are both phenomenal, and the visuals during the main song were pretty great but the visual stylization isn‚Äôt consistent enough throughout the movie to make it ‚Äústyle over substance‚Äù good.Not as bad of a movie as I‚Äôve seen some people make it out to be, but‚Ä¶

Starts out kind of slow, but ends up a pretty great low budget thriller/sci-fi. I'm honestly not sure how I feel about the ending - although with everything going on I understand that the open-endedness was really the only waytoend it - but overall it was a good watch. Interesting idea with a lot of creative details that help set it apart from similarly themed narratives.

One could go on for hours about all of the issues this movie has, and they'd probably be right in doing so, but it's just sointoxicatingto me. This is a movie about repression and sexual freedom but, perhaps more importantly, it's a movie that knows how to have fun. This past summer I went to a convention that had Patricia Quinn (Magenta) as a guest and she basically confirmed what I had always hoped was true - that‚Ä¶

This was fine. I liked the tension/build-up once it started happening, although I do think the wait for the plot to begin was a little too long. It's definitely not my favorite Hitchcock, but I did really enjoy the evolution of the relationship between Lisa and Jeff and the whole concept of protagonists peering through windows/acting as amateur detectives. Sort of wish it had had a different ending, but I'm not upset with the one it does have.
this felt like it was four hours long

My fandor subscription is ending in a few days so I thought I'd rewatch this. Super silly operatic short film about two immortal women whose powers come from roller blades trying to get two mortals to fall in love. Probably the lightest and most fun Hartley film I've seen. Surprisingly impressive singing from Parker Posey.

I want to rewatch this sometime soon after looking into and/or reading the short story that it's based on. I don't think it will be all that relevant to the film itself, but I think it'll help to rewatch in general and context couldn't hurt.I really enjoyed a lot of the visuals in this and the occasional play with the actors and camera, but the director's acting is unfortunately very weak and often comes across as wooden and monotone. Parker is fun though, and it‚Äôs cool to see her in such an early role.

Basically an over-glorified SyFy original with a blockbuster budget, but it was fun. A lot of monster movies fall into the trap of focusing too heavily (in my opinion) on the human researchers/discoverers of the monster, presumably because it's cheaper to do so than to focus on the monster itself. While this movie definitely follows that same path, the acting/characters were interesting enough that I didn't mind as much. Love story was sort of unnecessary and the plot was super‚Ä¶

Like Stillman'sDamsels in DistressI didn't think this was anything spectacular, but I did really enjoy the writing - especially the banter between characters. The two lead female characters were great, and I personally loved the moment with the guy who collected old Scrooge McDuck comics/art. Looking back, I realize the scene is supposed to be a sort of ironic joke given the fact that the character was a yuppie, but I was too amused by the inclusion of‚Ä¶

I‚Äôve had theDazedCriterion for a while now but just got around to looking at the special features on it. It‚Äôs not surprising that this mini doc is effectively just a DVD special feature, but the abundance of footage they had and were able to use from the original shoot really elevated it and imo makes it worth a watch.Obviously it‚Äôs cool to see the cast all making friends and hanging out, but it was also interesting and‚Ä¶

AlthoughWhat Rats Won't Dois incredibly predictable in every move it makes, it's also incredibly charming. Not a must-watch for sure, but a very lovable film and one that I'd suggest to anyone who has any kind of genuine enjoyment for easy to watch romantic comedies.

God...up until the last episode I was ready to give this miniseries a 3.5 but a lot happened in those last forty minutes - most notably, the series' only black character (played by a black actress) was revealed to be a white woman who took pills to darken her skin.Prior to that big reveal, I was going to say that despite the series' need for more racial diversity it was actually pretty great for its time at representing other‚Ä¶

It's horrifying that forty years after the events ofBlackkkklansmana film can be made that not only tells the story of Ron Stallworth but also works as a viable commentary on race relations in the country today. It's horrifying that almost thirty years afterDo the Right ThingSpike Lee can make another film with similar themes that still resonates with current events. The ending footage is stomach-turning and incredibly uncomfortable to watch. Gone are Lee's nicely set up‚Ä¶

I didn't likeInherent Vicewhen it came out and I've never been a huge fan of Adam Sandler so this movie was a pleasant surprise. Someone needs to force both Sandler and Jim Carrey to only do serious movies because they're really not cut out for comedy acting but they do surprisingly well in dramatic roles.

This was worse than I thought it was going to be. Just a bunch of SNL skits strung together with barely any plot to connect them.A full star instead of a half star because Parker Posey and Joey Lauren Adams were looking cute as daughter conehead's friends for the one minute that they were in the movie.

I would like a nice, powerful, mind-altering substance. Preferably one that will make my unborn children grow gills.The first time I watched this movie I was multitasking and moving in and out of the room so I thought it deserved a rewatch but I was honestly mostly right in myoriginal review. It is "weirdly charming" mindless entertainment, though definitely better than the average mindless entertainment if only because of Parker Posey being in the lead role.As a‚Ä¶

My name'sRico, not Little RicoI started this last night but had to finish the last ten minutes today because I was falling asleep ...not necessarily because of the movie, but it certainly wasn't helping. I've never seenBreathless, which the poster claims this film is referencing, butUnmade Bedsfeels like a student film utilizing every gangster film trope that exists, only in the context of a camera / photographer instead of a gun / gangster. The writing‚Ä¶

movietitle: What We Do in the Shadows
review: I'd seen a few stills of this on tumblr and other websites and knew I probably wouldn't be into the comedy from them, but I did really enjoyHunt for the Wilderpeopleso I thought it deserved a fair chance. Unfortunately my original inclinations about it were right.Humor is a funny thing (ha.) because something that can make someone die laughing can have little to no effect on someone else. In the case of this movie I was the‚Ä¶

The first half of the movie is good fun, but after that it sort of loses its charm (and...for some reason, stops being a musical?) and just sort of meanders on without much purpose. I was glad that it ended the way it did though. Between 2.5 and 3 for this, but it gets the extra half for the sheer fact that I'll definitely be listening to the songs a few more times over the next week.
nice, cozy and personal documentary about a pet cemetery and some of the beloved pets who were buried there. really loved all of the stories told from reminiscing owners.

This could have worked so much better as a short film - thirty minutes max. While it's an interesting idea to show peoples normal, average lives in the day to day before their inevitable death there's no reason for them to drag out as long as they do here. Looked nice though.

Sometimes the best things are made on the lowest budgets. This holds true forDr. Horrible's Sing-Along Blog, a self-funded project from Joss and Jed Whedon during the writer's strike of 2008 made to be uploaded onto the internet and available to people around the world for free. Although it's not technically impressive, the writing is some of Whedon's strongest and almost all of the songs are fantastically written and performed.This is the best movie Joss Whedon has ever laid his hands on and thatincludesboth of hisAvengersmovies.

I feel like I could have/would have appreciated this a lot more if I was more familiar with Giallos, but I still ended up really enjoying it for its sound and visuals.The third story in the protagonist's life (which I have read is the most heavily based on common themes in Giallos) was definitely the hardest for me to wrap my head around, I enjoyed the core concepts of it and how they played out but I was uncertain‚Ä¶

And Marco.‚Ä¢ Alex should have been here, even if only in short cameo‚Ä¢ Degrassi somehow tore Paige's character apart within the hour runtime of this film and then spit out a semi-decent version of her in the last few seconds of the movie,‚Ä¶
I can't believe this masterpiece not only lost toThe Incrediblesat the Oscars but wasn't evennominated. A disgrace.

I really loved the set-up of this world and the entire first half was interesting to watch, but the tension building/long chase in the last ten or twenty minutes didn't work for me. Wish George Lucas had made a few more films like this alongsideStar Wars; would be interesting to see what other science fiction worlds and concepts he could've explored.

With the exception of Sofia Vegara (whose role is marginal at best) I usually love all of the big names in this cast when I see them. Unfortunately, this script didn't give them much to work with. Maggie Q was pretty good as Uma Thurman's scorned lover and Parker Posey's character was delightfully insane enough to keep me entertained but neither role was prominent enough to save the movie.I hesitate to even call this a comedy because..nothing was really‚Ä¶
.....stupid.the first act was decently funny but it went downhill fast.

Jesus Christthis movie is uncomfortable. I'm not just speaking to the car scene, which seems to have gotten a lot of attention on here as a reason to dislike this movie, but almost the entire hour and thirty minutes of this was just pure secondhand embarrassment for me. It's like a watered downWelcome to the Dollhousebut somehow made me feel worse thanDollhouseever did.There's a few glimpses of what this could have been within the‚Ä¶

A transcendental whirlwind of punk rock music and heightened reality with a complicated and flawed protagonist at its center. review: Compiling a variety of footage from over the years,I Just Wanted to Be Somebodychronicles the short-lived fame of former Florida Orange Juice spokeswoman Anita Bryant and considers in the form of a letter how her stance against homosexuality led to one of the strongest public pushes for equality in the United States.Having not recognized the name I thought I was going into this short blind, but actually ended up having contextual backing from Pardon Our Dust's recent video on theHistory of Disney's Orange Birdwhich is a similarly interesting and more directly informative video on the situation.

movietitle: Captain Underpants: The First Epic Movie
review: Possibly the most accurate children's book to movie translation ever made. Everything about this was perfect, especially the art style and its ability to go back and forth from CGI to traditional 2D animation to show George and Harold's comic books and flipograms. I would haveLOVEDseeing this when I was a kid and obsessed with reading the books. As it stands now it's a little too heavy on the toilet humor for my tastes, but I'm so glad children today have this adorable and fun movie to watch. A good way to end 2017.

Although somewhat underwhelming in its first half,Colossalmore than makes up for its more disappointing scenes with its absolutely fantastic ending. Simultaneously poignant and funny, it's a breath of fresh air amongst all of this summer's reboots, remakes, and sequels, with an intensely likable (albeit deeply flawed) main character and wonderful underlying commentary on power and toxic masculinity.I'm super glad it finally came to a theater close enough for me to see it on the big screen.

movietitle: Walk Hard: The Dewey Cox Story
review: I had no interest in this movie but then I was playing Comedy Scene It with a friend and one of the clues was the scene right after he cuts his brother in half. Obviously I had to watch this after seeing that, but unfortunately that's the funniest scene.Don't watch the unrated director's cut if you haven't seen the original before. Don't make the same mistakes that I did. The extra half star I gave it is acknowledging that this would be better if it was shorter.

movietitle: Tiny Toon Adventures: How I Spent My Vacation
review: This was good, but it ended up feeling way longer than it actually was because of all the stories it has going on at the same time. If this had been an episode of the show confined to the usual thirty minute runtime I feel like I would have enjoyed it a lot better. Some of the jokes (i.e. the bad car trip) got stale after the first twenty minutes, and other stories (i.e. Elmyra's entire existence) I would have rather avoided entirely.There are some legitimately funny jokes within this, but as a whole it's just sorta....meh.

movietitle: Grandma Got Run Over by a Reindeer
review: Imagine hearing a song about a grandma drinking too much and getting hit and killed by santa's reindeer and thinking "Hey..! That sounds like it'd make a great kid's cartoon!"...Now imagine tweaking that song for your story so that the grandma lives and a member of her family tries to sue Santa. Also it's September for whatever reason. Add in some unnecessary songs - including one about the grandma partying with dead celebrities in heaven - and you have the 2000's classicGrandma Got Run Over by a Reindeer.

This (roughly) eight minute long pilot episode of Courage the Cowardly dog isn't nearly as creepy as some of the shows episodes that would follow it, but its style made me enjoy it better than I do most of those episodes. Whereas the show is more-clean cut, the animation in this is broader, sketchier and, in my opinion, better suited for its subject matter.The story and visuals of this also sort of match up with the"everything is happening in courage's head"conspiracy, which I appreciate as someone who has been wasting hours of my life watching cartoon theory videos lately.

movietitle: Seeking a Friend for the End of the World
review: As predictable and cliche as this film is overall, it has a lot of heart. I genuinely felt for the characters and cared about where they would be and what they'd be doing by the end - even though there was the impending doom of the apocalypse hanging over them all.It's very sweet while simultaneously being bittersweetly realistic.This is my first time seeing it, but I can already tell it'll be a good film to rewatch when I'm not feeling anything too deep or heavy. ...which is probably ironic given the subject matter.

movietitle: A Nightmare on Elm Street Part 2: Freddy's Revenge
review: Although I'm sure there are those that swear by the original, I felt likeFreddy's Revengewas much better than its predecessor...even if it doesn't really make sense to call it a "revenge" when none of the original cast of teens are involved. Jessie's almost complete lack of knowledge surrounding Freddy really helped the story, and the scene of Freddy bursting from Jessie's skin/chest was just the right amount of campy-creepy.
