movietitle: Scooby-Doo! and KISS: Rock and Roll Mystery
review: I started this movie Thursday night, but on Friday I spent the day watchingRocky Horrorwith my film club, and then yesterday I spent the day in thrift shops and the night at a Halloween party. This is relevant to the film at hand because I went as Velma Dinkley.Trivia for the day: one of the girls at the party was an exchange student from Denmark and she said Velma's name in Danish is Vera. I can't confirm‚Ä¶

The Blair Witch Projectwasn't the first "found footage" film, but it's definitely one of the most well-known. I really appreciate the commitment to the idea that it (and, later,Paranormal Activity) shows through hiring relatively unknown actors who have done little to nothing prior and making their "character names" the same as their real names. It really helps add to the realism and overall fear factor of it.I guess my only issue with this is that I expected‚Ä¶

This can be added to the pile of movies I watched expecting to love but in the end just thought were alright. I think it would have worked a lot better for me had I not known it was a horror film. The slow build-up of obsession would have been much more interesting, and the film's climax more surprising. I almostwantthis movie to be rebooted, just because I think the core story is so interesting but I was‚Ä¶

"Your legs are crooked." / "Don't you know that's just what I based my personality on?"I was so tired when I woke up this morning and I've seen this before/have access to rewatch it easily...but I still put on a flower crown and went to class this morning to watch it on a big screen.That's commitment.

movietitle: The Rocky Horror Picture Show: Let's Do the Time Warp Again
review: I want to start out by saying that this wasn't nearly as bad as I thought it would be or as a bunch of people would have you believe. It's mediocre and I truly believe it didn't need to be made but, more often than not, it was at least entertaining.Brad's actor annoyed me in the beginning, but I think his purposefully campy acting grew on me ...if only because the actual acting of pretty much everyone else felt‚Ä¶
The one star is because it looked nice sometimes and there was a dog.

movietitle: This Film Is Not Yet Rated
review: ‚Ü†Documentaries RankedThe ratings system is wild, y'all. How hasnothingchanged since this movie was released..

It's wild to me that people are giving this one and one and a half stars... like, what exactly were you expecting from a movie calledBadMoms? Did you watch the trailer or did you just walk in expecting some high brow cinematic #experience?Maybe it's because I saw this at a free showing, but I thought it was pretty good. Better than I thought it'd be. A lot clich√© and a little over the top, but a nice‚Ä¶

This got some bad reviews but I really loved it. There were some obnoxious dialogue choices (I never need to hear the word "basic" again) and the nazi subplot was wholly unnecessary, but a lot of the stuff that was funny was genuinely hilarious.I'm more than a little upset that Justin Long was in this and NOT as a walrus man though. To put him in the cast as another character after establishing that the film is post-Tuskis just......wrong.

This film has never been released on DVD in the US and that is genuinely a shame, especially since the conversations it brings up are still very much relevant today. What our class ended up watching was a rip of a VHS tape; if you're interested, I believe a copy of similar quality can currently be found on YouTube.Despite the fact that there's not a whole lot to be happy about at the end of this movie, I could‚Ä¶

No offense but I didn't watch a film calledThe Gingerdead Manto hear a girl whine about her dead brother and the fact that he didn't get to go to the titty bar for his 21st birthday like he'd always wished. I watchedThe Gingerdead Manto see Gary Busey as a serial killer trapped inside the body of a gingerbread man.Ten minutes of this movie's hour and ten minute runtime is credits and I'm...definitely not complaining about that.

It's strange, but I think it was more weird to me that I hadn't seenChild's Playthan classics likeThe ShiningorThe Exorcist. I feel like I knew so much more going into this movie than I did going intoThe Shiningearlier this year - and I couldn't tell you one thing aboutThe Exorcistbeyond the obvious implications that can be made from the title.I understand whyChild's Playis such a culturalthingthough.‚Ä¶

This was a very aesthetically pleasing movie, but I feel that its metaphors were much too heavy-handed. Based on the description, I was sort of going into this hoping for a pretty mindless straight-forward movie about deadly children - but at its core, this is primarily a movie about teen pregnancy told in a fantastical way rather than one about demon kids.

When this was on Netflix it sat in my watchlist for what felt like forever and my hesitance to watch it was always with this poster ..which might literally be one of the worst poster designs I have ever seen in my life. I guess to some extent it's aesthetically appealing, but as far as conveying what the movie is about? It's absolutely terrible. I don't know what Iwantthe poster to be, but...not this.This movie is trashy, it's ridiculous, and it has enough plot twists for a month's worth of a soap opera ..but I loved it.

I'm starting to feel about Illeana Douglas the same way I do about Janeane Garofalo in that I don't necessarily have any desire to watch their entire filmographies but I love them when they're in a movie I watch. Also both of them have names I always manage to misspell.

I feel like after reading some of the theories as to what's going on in the movie and giving it a second watch it definitely made more narrative sense. Notcompletenarrative sense, but enough to make me appreciate it more as a whole.

Cameron Diaz and Jude Law's half of this movie is so irritatingly clich√©... I'm literally not sure if I've ever seen something more predictable and so thoroughlyrom-com. Kate Winslet's plots were a little more interesting though..possibly because of my bias towards Winslet, but also because of her side plot with Arthur (Eli Wallach).

This is significantly less good than its predecessor, (Elvira: Mistress of the Dark) but it still manages to be entertaining. Unlike the first film, which sees a modern day Elvira in a conservative town, this film plays out more like Elvira is stuck in one of the films she makes fun of on her show. It's a painfully cliche plot with Elvira pointing this fact out every step of the way. ...and that's not necessarily awful, but it's not great either.

This came out when I first started watching Disney Channel and I loved it then and I still love it today. It's cheesy and the effects are awful, but it's cute. Exactly what you'd want from a tv movie about teen witches.The girls' guardians are faves and I won't ever forgive the sequel for switching out Ileana with no explanation.
Best soundtrack. Best product placement. Best breaking of the fourth wall. Best tomatoes. ...Truly an iconic film.

In case you don't know,Roarwas a film that was intended to be a family drama, but relied mostly on improvisation and survival when the 150 real lions started attacking the cast ...and the cameras kept rolling.Re-release trailers touted this as "a snuff version of Swiss Family Robinson" and "a live action Lion King where Mufasa holds a switchblade to your throat" but, honestly, it seems like a lot of the worst of it was off-screen. Even though‚Ä¶

I was going to switch out my "unconventional monster" film for this one because I knew the antagonist was a haunted flashlight/lantern, but I honestly don't have a strong enough opinion about this movie nor did I pay consistent enough attention to justify using it. If you've seen literally any movie about teens in the woods being killed off one by one you don't need to see this.

This is something that has been in my watchlist for a little while now based on some of the posters' aesthetics and the description alone, then I realized it was by the same guy who didExcisionand that sort of cemented my need to watch this movie.Unfortunately, while Richard Bates Jr.'s brand of horror is everything I could ask for, he should stick to horror/dramas and not try to dabble in comedy. Every line in this film that‚Ä¶

I'm always so conflicted when it comes to mumblecore films, especiallyimprovisedmumblecore films.With this particular film, there are some scenes that have such an intense realism to them that I genuinely don't think could ever be achieved with a scripted studio film. ...but then, on the flip side of that, there are just as many scenes where the banality and randomness born from an entire film of improvisation makes this feel like a student film made on a‚Ä¶
I love movies that are meta/break the fourth wall. I love horror. I love this movie.

I absolutely love this brand of ridiculous, over-the-top 1980's comedy (i.e.Airplane!,Return of the Killer Tomatoes)I wish all parody films could be this good and this consistently funny. It was rare that ten minutes went by in this without me laughing at something. Forget theScary Movies andEpic Movies and give me more of this - although preferably without any of the "edgy" potshots at minorities.

The director ofThe Girlfriend Experience, Steven Soderbergh, won an academy award for his filmTrafficin 2001. He was also nominated forErin Brockovichthe same year and nominated for the screenplay ofSex, Lies, and Videotapeeleven years earlier. With this kind of a record, one could assume thatThe Girlfriend Experiencewould be a good movie. That'd it be well shot and engaging. -- This is not the case.A movie about a call girl should not be this boring and it should not devote so much time to talking about the most recent presidential election.

This is a movie that ended up being pretty much exactly what I wanted it to be. It's female-centric with a female murderer and a gay character who not only lives but helps save our protagonist. ..Wild, I know.My only complaint is that I'd rather not have had the attempted rape by Allie's boss followed by his almost "redemption" when he came to her rescue at the end. The film didn't let him save her, and it could be‚Ä¶

I was really underwhelmed by this movie. I'd had a lot of people telling me how good it was with some saying it was better thanThe Conjuringand its sequel (two other films by James Wan) but...I don't know, this just didn't connect? The main "monster" of this film is so colorful and over stylized that it seems silly rather than scary, and the copious amount of jump scares didn't really do anything for me. I was zoning in‚Ä¶

While large parts of this consisted of pretty predictable "family movie" tropes - unnecessary romance plotline, kids meddling in an adult's life, etc. - there were so many scenes of this where I hadnoideawhat was going to happen. The logic was so far removed from the film's world that everything was a surprise. Including what is probably one of the most unintentionally depressing endings I have ever seen in my life.It's so bad it's almost good. And I wasn't even drunk!

American Splendoris probably one of the best biopics I have ever seen in my life. It's so wholly unique and entertaining - even if the main character is played by Paul Giamatti who I can never unsee as ascript-stealing blue man. Intercutting typical dramatizations with documentary-style talking heads of the real people that the film is based on seems like such a crazy idea and yet it works here. It's like watching a commentary track within the movie‚Ä¶

There's a reason that this is obscure. Keep it hidden. I don't even really have anything to say about it because it's just so boring and then when it stops being boring it's just...simply not good. It honestly might deserve the 0% it has on rotten tomatoes.It somehow still manages to be better thanRatterthough.

Although it took me a while to actually watch, I was certain I was going to loveTo Die For....But I don't know, despite everything about it seeming to be exactly what I want in a film this was really justalright. It was funny in parts and the plot was engaging but parts of it just felt tiresome. That and I wasn't a fan of the psuedo-mockumentary style. It was somewhat ...I don't want to say disorienting, but..weird‚Ä¶
this sure was A Wild Ride..

Before I even talk about anything regarding the narrative/acting etc., I want to acknowledge the fact that this obviously isn't a perfect film. Although not nearly as exploitative as earlier films focusing on trans individuals, this isn't a perfect model of representation. The people in charge of it, for example, cast Hilary Swank - a woman - as opposed to a trans man for the lead role and, right before the credits roll, the film deadnames Brandon in parenthesis...almost completely‚Ä¶

I think I judged this film too harshly when I watched itearlier this yearfor a scavenger hunt based on nothing more than my own biases. ...which is definitely something I need to work on.When Marie Antoinette is sobbing behind a door and then the scene cuts to her spending excess money on a ridiculous amount of unnecessary, lavish things set toI Want Candy... that was a call out. Too relatable.Despite being set in 1700s Versailles and‚Ä¶
I can't believe this literal masterpiece in filmmaking has just been sitting on Netflix waiting to be watched and I've just been ignoring it.

I considered doing Hoop-tober or hayley's October list along with the scavenger hunt for next month, but both of them had tasks that I knew I wasn't going to want to watch. So..I'm just recording the horror movies I do watch into one convenient list.Much likeThe Shining, this was a lot less scary/creepy than I thought it would be. UnlikeThe Shining, the acting and the script didn't always make up for it.Somehow though, despite all of‚Ä¶

I will be conferring with other world leaders as time goes on and rest assured that, working together, we will soon come out at a very real...outcome..This was another one of those movies that I knew about for a while but put off watching for no reason in particular and then ended up loving when I finally got around to watching it. It's funny, it's whacky, it's ..pretty much everything I want from an alien invasion film.I think‚Ä¶
.....did the people giving this four star reviews actually see the same movie that I did?

A well-done creepy little found footage film that I think would make anyone stop and reconsider the idea of having kids, even if only for a second.There are a few questions I have about the story in regards to the found footage aspect of the film and who is controlling the film at what points, but those are small concerns.I'm currently watching HomeMovies- the adult swim show - so that my dreams are based on the antics of eight year old jerks instead of ten year old murderers.

How much do you think that Ferdinand stuffed animal would be worth today if you could get your hands on one...? I just spent the last twenty minutes looking for it on eBay/Google and I couldn't even find a picture of it.

Isowanted this to be good but it just couldn't live up to the hype I'd built up for it. The film itself felt like a lot of build-up for an ultimately weak end.If there was an Oscar category for most graphically disgusting scene in a film a few scenes in this would win by a landslide.
the dog didn't deserve that

Mindless weekend entertainment while I do laundry and make a million aesthetic boards on pinterest.I really have no reason for loving Parker Posey as much as I do. She's so over the top it should be annoying but instead it's sort of ..weirdly charming.

I didn't write a review for this film directly after watching it because I feel like there's nothing much to say. It's a good subversion of a typical romance "chick flick" and it has a lot of heart but ultimately it's pretty a average film in the grand scheme of things. I guess I was just expecting more from it.

Like Popeye says, "I am what I am," right?Night on Earthis an unexpectedly great little character study of forced conversations/relationships.¬†I initially added this to my watchlist and then to my scavenger hunt list for Winona, who was as great as ever, but I ended up really loving almost all of the other stories as well.California and France were the best moments of the film, Italy was funny in a dark and awful way, and Helsinki was a nice,‚Ä¶
The two stars are for Lizzy Caplan who needs to choose better movies to be in.
Don't test me.. I'd still marry Winona Ryder or Greta Gerwig right now...

I just went through this show in two days while doing a bunch of schoolwork and I can't believe it's already over. I wasn't the biggest fan of some of the early episodes, but season 3 and this prequel short are so Good. Give me more of this! And with longer runtimes...!!Side note: I love the quote from the Adult Swim guy on this short's poster... "smart, amusing, but not really funny." Same.
Every single frame of this film is a cursed image.
Woah woah woah -- you know whoSupermanis? ..Are you aware of Garfield?

I could watch a two hour long movie of Shirley MacLaine sitting in a room doing nothing and I'd probably still be charmed.That's not to say that the extras and side characters weren't also amazing - some of the funniest scenes are the reactions the citizens of New York have to Charity in the beginning of the film, and some of the best songs were those sung with the other girls in the dance hall.That being said, I've‚Ä¶

The first line of dialogue in this film is Alfred saying "Can I persuade you to take a sandwich with you, sir?" to which Bruce replies "I'll get drive-thru." Which, only two minutes in, already speaks to the quality one should be expecting from this film...After two genuinely great films, this Batman franchise lost both Tim Burton and Michael Keaton ...and, boy, does it show. It's clear that the crew here didn't grasp what worked inBatmanandBatman‚Ä¶
dir. Ricky Fitts (1999)
The scene at the end with the old lady's alternate lives is so unnecessary but it's also one of the most relatable and hilarious parts of the entire movie so I'll allow it.

I'm not going to deny that the visuals and social message of this were great and worthy of the 4-5 stars people are giving it, but that doesn't change the fact that thisisjust a visual album and if you're not a big fan of Beyonc√©'s music it's hard to be a big fan of this.In defense of Beyonc√©,FormationandSorrywere pretty good music-wise. I just wishSorrydidn't have my name in it.

It feels weird to be talking about a zombie movie as a warm and light-hearted comedy, but that's exactly what this film is. I love this film's aesthetics and I think its concept was executed perfectly. It's exactly the film it set out to be.The only thing I wasn't a fan of was the shrugging off/complete dismissal of the fact that the neighbor's zombie girlfriend that he presumably has sex with is ...a literal teenager. Even if it was‚Ä¶

You can't believe her! Look at the hair, the clothes, ...the constant cheerfulness!I've never seen the first Brady Bunch movie nor have I ever seen the original series that this is parodying, but that didn't effect my enjoyment of this sequel at all. Even though I had seen more than a few of the scenes from this back when it was a tumblr meme I was still laughing throughout. And it's understandable that scenes from this movie became a‚Ä¶

About a year ago I watchedWelcome to the Dollhouse, a movie which, on the surface level, seems like something I'd love. It was the second of Solondz' films I'd seen, the first beingHappinessabout a month before. ..I didn't like either of them. I liked aspects of them both, but as a whole I they left a bad taste in my mouth. They were to me what I have seen a fair amount of people calling this movie‚Ä¶

Only marginally more happy than Solondz'sHappiness, and sickeningly bittersweet.Le Bonheurwas beautiful visually and tells an interesting story, but was ultimately too slow-paced and flat for me to personally see it as anything more than an average film.

It was such a strange experience to watch a mockumentary biopic. I know it shouldn't have been so off-putting because it's technically a technique that can be employed in any genre, but this is the first mockumentary I've seen without a hint of comedy and it felt so wrong and weird.This is also pretty melodramatic and at times even bordering on cheesy, but I have a huge soft spot for movies with (1) alternative teen girls who think they're tough and (2) cute domestic gays.
There was so much potential here but ultimately it's¬†too obvious watching this that this is a "feminist" sorority movie written by a team of all men.

This was a fair amount better than its predecessor. I still left the movie with too many basic questions about the world and all of the little details of it, but, at the very least, I enjoyed myself. ..Not enough to have any interest in reading the books or finishing the film series, but I was entertained.
kid with rat tail - Where Is He Now?

Are you food...or are you sex?Myinitial reviewfor this film didn't delve into my opinions of it at all, but I suppose since this has become the most divisive movie to ever come across my letterboxd feed I should throw in my two cents about it.This isn't an original story. I don't really think anyone is vehemently arguing that fact. The script is a rehash of so many stereotypes and films about modeling. Some scenes play like‚Ä¶

I want to preface this review by saying that hulu provided me with the dubbed version of this film and I didn't feel like digging around for the sub, so I suppose the version I watched could have factored into my enjoyment some. ...I have serious doubts abouthow muchit factored into my enjoyment of this movie as a whole, but I feel like it's significant to mention regardless.My primary issue with this film is a lack of‚Ä¶

Buffy the Vampire Slayeris the campy predecessor of the hit television series of the same name and ultimately reads like a very rough draft of what the tv series would eventually become. It's fun and it's bright and it's very early 90's. The dialogue sounds like Whedon watchedCluelessonce and decided to amplify that and run with it.I liked it for what it was, but not enough to ever want to rewatch it. I'm glad whatever studio‚Ä¶

Television is reality and reality is less than television.VHS-based horror AND Debbie Harry? This movie really seemed like a dream come true and it's really no surprise that this is a movie that I have been wanting to watch ever since I heard it existed. But now, moments after I've actually finished it, I feel like I need to watch it again. I feel like, despite paying full attention throughout, I had to have missed something because it honestly‚Ä¶
Imagining what this movie would be like based on the poster was about 20x better than the actual movie. I hate the main character.
But is the dog okay..? Didhesee a ladybug?

After a very limited release, Paramount attempted to buryWhite Dogdue to criticism the film received from the NAACP in pre-production. It wasn't until 2008 - a full 25 years after it was intended to be released - that it saw a nationwide release as part of the Criterion Collection.With the film's plot following an animal trainer as he attempts to retrain a dog who has been raised to brutally attack and kill black people, it's not hard‚Ä¶

The biggest unintentional scare in this movie is in the beginning when the spooky shit keeps happening and at one point one of the old British men the girls likes is peering over her shoulder on their poster. Who even is he?

A "messed up man" is redundant!...I was dreading watching this. The reviews are less than stellar - as is the general vibe the poster gives off....and yet it was actually pretty good! Don't judge a book by its cover and all that. I mean, it's definitely not without its faults, but it made me care about a straight couple in a romcom so it must have some worth.

This wasn't great, but I wouldn't necessarily say it was disappointing either. It was about what I was expecting from a movie whose main plot is about Ethan Hawke having an affair.This would have been a better movie if Maggie had given up on Hawke's character earlier and just lived with Julianne Moore and the kids. Although the time we do see them interacting together sort of calls into question how Moore's character could have ever taken care of‚Ä¶

This was a comedy whose main downfall was trying to be more. Near the start of the film when the focus was on Melissa McCarthy's badass Girl Scout troupe at war with Kristen Schaal's troupe I had a hard time imagining why so many people were disappointed in this. It was perhaps a little unoriginal, but it was fun and the characters were just ridiculous enough to be enjoyable.And then this decided to go down the route of a‚Ä¶

movietitle: What Ever Happened to Baby Jane?
review: You mean all this time ...we could have been friends?I don't know that this should be considered as much of a classic or feat in cinema as it oftentimes is, but it definitely deserves to be a part of the AFI Heroes & Villains list. "Baby" Jane Hudson is so wonderfullyeviland vindictive. She's a grown-up Darla fromCats Don't Dance- the nightmare of what a child star could potentially become.I think what was ultimately a let-down‚Ä¶
Clever, but to a fault. The ending is weirdly ambiguous and unsatisfying despite some decent lead up. Itlooksabsolutely gorgeous though.

Well, that was..ridiculously depressing.At face value, this sounds like one of the trashiest, most ill-advised and politically incorrect plots of the century - a Jewish lesbian falling in love with the wife of a nazi general - and yet it's so well done. It's so beautiful both in storytelling and from a cinematography standpoint. Heartbreaking, but unquestionably beautiful.While at times a little melodramatic and reminiscent of a soap opera in staging and dialogue, for the majority of its‚Ä¶
People are reviewing this as if it's some kind of deep, impactful filmmaking and not just a cute/fun gimmick.

Just yesterday, in the year of our lord 2016, my European lit professor said abortion was murder. She said it was an acceptable form of murder. But murder all the same. She said this while comparing the moral ambiguity of murder to incest.Anyway... the message of this movie is bs. It was progressive for its time and I guess I appreciate that aspect of it, but... I'm not sympathetic to the husband at all really. ...even though I guess I was supposed to be.

Like pretty much everyone else who watched this movie I watched for the cute gays but I'm disappointed that I haven't seen anyone talking about how Good Dominique and Max are. They're the true faves here.tbh this wasn't that great at all, especially in terms of the dialogue and acting, but I guess it's nice to have what basically amounts to an age appropriate Kim Possible/Shego fanfic in movie form.

"Sorry to bother you again, is there trash in here?""Yes, I'm right here."I watched this primarily because I loved Alex Ross Perry and Elizabeth Moss working together inQueen of Earthand was hoping that same feeling would be repeated here. Kristen Ritter being involved was really just an added bonus. Unfortunately, despite the fact that I loved both of them in their respective roles neither of these ladies could really take this movie above "average" for me.I‚Ä¶

I wasn't expecting this to be some fantastic movie, but it was way worse than I thought it would be. The dialogue is cheesy and forced and the plot often slow-moving. I guess this was probably a sweet quirky story in real life, and I can see how one would think it'd make a good movie, but it just doesn't translate well to film.Scarlett Johansson looked good though. That extra half star is completely for her.

You know when the camera goes really big and it comes up out of the roof, and you just know that it's gonna end? I hate that. I used to cheat on that when I was a little girl back in Czechoslovakia. I would leave the cinema just after the next to last song, and the film would just go on forever. It's lovely, isn't it?This is genuinely one of the saddest movies I have ever seen in my‚Ä¶
Trevor saying "mall" and then rolling away when a cute girl complimented his shoes is literally me.

"Human?" / "Yeah. ...Is that optional?"With my last review, me logging this should not come as a surprise to anyone. The Doctor says "August is rubbish, stay indoors" inGirl in the Fireplaceso apparently, in BBC America's eyes, that justifies a Christmas in August Doctor Who marathon....Anyway. Remember whenDoctor Whowas actually a good show?

"Don't you think she looks tired?"I can't believe I can log this and feel productive. BBC America is playing all of the DW Christmas specials for whatever reason and I'm going back to Raleigh for school tomorrow so I'm avoiding packing.

I want to start this by saying that I have not seen the second or third Alien movies. This was free on IFC on demand and I was taking advantage of seeing this in HD before I went to school and lost having on demand channels as an option. Basically all I knew going in was that Ripley died with a queen xenomorph inside of her and some scientists were resurrecting her. Also that Winona Ryder would be involved. This‚Ä¶

I hate that all the aliens speak in the same broken English but still seem to have some basic knowledge of some cultural references. Their knowledge of humans and Earth before landing is so arbitrary and seems to only exist to create more Jokes‚Ñ¢. That, and Jim Parsons' voice drives me up the wall.I can't imagine having the misfortune of going to the theater to see this with a child and them falling in love with it and mimicking‚Ä¶

I feel like I...missed something? I don't know, I heard a lot of mixed reviews on this, but from what I can tell a majority of people loved it. Then again, those same people seemed to really enjoyIt Followsas well, which I didn't like at all beyond the visuals.This had some pretty good storytelling, and I was invested in the relationship between the mother and son but as a horror/thriller movie I thought it was pretty average.‚Ä¶

Wow what a nice and pure feel-good movie!!! Cher was so so good in this and, as always, I love Winona Ryder. She is truly a Flawless Angel. Every time I watch anything with her in it I sit and wonder why I haven't watched her entire filmography already.The ending of this is the cutest thing I have seen in a long time. I want to live in that scene.

I really wish they would've done without the fantasy elements? I don't know, I guess the end note was sweet and it didn't detract too much from the story as a whole, but it seemed sort of gimmicky in a movie that otherwise had so much heart.I loved Ellen Page and Alisson Janney in this. A great, though not groundbreaking, movie by a woman and starring women.

There are people legitimately ripping this thing apart in their reviews and. maybe I just have low standards but, this..isn't that bad. This is pretty much exactly what I'd expect of a Cartoon Network TV movie about the Mystery Gang meeting for the first time in high school.Some people, I guess, have a big problem with this because they're big Scooby-Doo fans. It's "tarnishing the brand" or something ridiculous like that. I'm..not a big Scooby-Doo fan. Although I loved‚Ä¶

"Adam & Eve were naked in the Garden of Eden, weren't they? When they sinned they put on clothes."According to the documentaryBettie Page Reveals All, Bettie Page herself decried this film and yelled "Lies! All Lies!" at the screen when it was shown to her. According to the IMDB trivia page, she enjoyed the film and only took issue with the word "notorious." Since I can't find any source for the trivia and I can't find any other accounts‚Ä¶

An inoffensive little film about the music industry.Keira Knightley is great, as expected, and the songs are nothing short of spectacular ...but, as a whole, it's nothing special. Pretty predictable but not necessarily in a bad way.

Two notes: (1) Isn't it weird how Gideon and Figaro exist together in the same movie? What's that about? (2) One of the official scene selection titles on the DVD is "Lampwick Makes a Jackass of Himself" and I feel like everyone should know.But, anyways, ..wow! What a jump in quality fromSnow White! And for the better, in my opinion. It's so much nicer visually, with a larger array of color and more unique character designs ...andit's‚Ä¶

movietitle: The Hitchhiker's Guide to the Galaxy
review: Apparently some people really like this movie? I don't know, I readHitchhiker's Guidewhen I was in high school and I remember really liking it, to the point that I intended to eventually read the rest of the series but...I just wasn't feeling this. Maybe it's the adaptation itself or maybe I've effectively "grown out" of it.That being said, there are definitely some scenes/jokes and characters that are four/five stars. I was a little disappointed by this overall. I liked it, but I've been wanting to watch it for a while and I guess I just wanted it to be better. movietitle: The Lion Guard: Return of the Roar
review: Although this was better than expected due to the fact that this is a prequel movie to a Disney Junior show, I was more than a little unsatisfied with all of the unanswered questions and plot holes that are present due to the fact that this film allegedly takes place during the same time as the first half of TLK 2.All of the weird plot stuff is especially frustrating because there's no GOOD reason for Kion to be around the same age as Kiara when they could have easily made him Kiara's son or a much younger sibling born afterSimba's Pride.

The beginning of Megan is Missing is a prime example of everything not to do in a movie. It's simultaneously boring and over-the-top while obviously having been written by a 40 year old man. Still, the latter half of the movie is laughably bad enough for it to earn its star and a half.As a side note, I could watch the silent zooming in of the security tape all day.
Despite its loose plot designed only to fit as many ABBA songs as possible into the film's 109 minute runtime, Mamma Mia! is truly a blessing upon this Earth.

It was so bad that I barely managed to sit through the whole thing. So when my buddyBrundleasked for a bad movie rec to quell his boredom, this was the first thing that came to mind. And like, I‚Ä¶

I gather that the story here is the sort of thing many would consider problematic these days. I worry about that, you know? That we've perhaps lost the ability to discern reality from fantasy. See, I don't subscribe to the notion that films influence behavior. I mean, where was the epidemic of serial killers afterSilence of the Lambscame out, huh? It's exactly the kind of reasoning used by the misguided individuals who tried to censor or outright ban‚Ä¶

This kinda shit is the reason I watch films, you know. Pure fantasy. Abstraction. A dark fairy tale world conjured from the realm of the imagination. Stylized. Surreal. Visually stunning.The whole thing feels like some lost Roald Dahl novel, filtered through Tim Burton, Terry Gilliam, and maybe even a dash of David Cronenberg. The sets look fantastic and the overall aesthetic feels like it surely must have been an influence on the Bioshock games. And, of course, it's always great seeing Ron Perlman turn up in anything. Can't believe I didn't watch this sooner.

This 80s sex comedy is as dumb as they make 'em. So, naturally, Jozlyn and I had a blast watching this together. Put your brain in hibernation mode for this one. You won't be needing it. Cornball jokes, video games, and way more tits than I remember ever seeing at the arcade.

An absolutely bonkers slice of pinku eiga from the guy who has since won an Oscar (Best Foreign Language Film) for the filmDepartures. He's also the guy who directedWhen the Last Sword is Drawn, which I watched way back in the mid-to-late 2000s and remember liking. Anyway, this thing is seriously bugnuts. It's like the Marx Brothers directed a softcore flick... in Japan!

Obscure little pinku thriller from the guy who directed a bunch of Ultraman episodes.A husband hires a PI to catch his wife cheating, only for the PI to turn around and start blackmailing the wife, who's consequently forced to work in the sex trade. There's a twist of sorts, but the description on LB kinda spoils it.If you're watching for the sex, it's slow to arrive and infrequent, but what you do get is actually pretty decent. No‚Ä¶

All I'm gonna say about this film is that I tried to stare at that shit for as long as I could. And the longer I stared at it, the more beautiful it became. But it's akin to staring at an eclipse. Gaze upon its terrible beauty for too long and you risk irreparable damage. And sure enough, after a few minutes, the eye pain set in, followed by dizziness and nausea. I was forced to look away. But like‚Ä¶

Since watching Guy'sThe Sound of Summer‚Äîwhich I loved, btw‚ÄîI've been itching to check this out. And I'm glad I finally got the opportunity, cuz this was great. It's raw and pulsating, like an open wound‚Äîinfected and oozing puss. Undercut with an utterly claustrophobic creeping dread. A mesmerizing descent into agoraphobic madness that gets under your skin and causes your pulse to quicken. The vibe was giving me flashbacks toSilent Hill 4: The Room. A swirling vortex of paranoia‚Ä¶

This may be a sacrilegious opinion, but I think this beats outSuspiriafor me, earning it the top spot in Argento's esteemed oeuvre. A haunting and gorgeous somnambulant fairy tale. Oneiric excursions, beautiful architecture, buggy friends, maggoty corpse pits, malformed freaks, and vengeful chimps. Oh, and the soundtrack is friggin' sublime. Goblin and Iron Maiden? Yes please. And then, of course, there's a fantastic performance from a young Jennifer Connelly, who just fits the vibe so perfectly. Man, I fuckin' love this shit. Definitely earns its place on mylist.

I was all ready to give this more stars‚Äîright after that one hallway scene (iykyk)‚Äîbut then this kinda falls off in the back half. The realism evaporates and the whole thing veers intoEight Legged Freaksterritory, while still straining to not have any fun with the now ridiculous premise. You can't have a spider the size of a Saint Bernard and still maintain a serious tone. I don't make the rules.I loved the quarantined building angle and the‚Ä¶

You could argue that this film is wildly far-fetched, but I think you'd be missing the point. I don't think realism was ever the goal here. It's clear from the aesthetic and overall vibe, that the whole thing is intended as more of a dark fairytale. Is it obvious to anyone with two brain cells to rub together, that this kid would never exist in the real world? Absolutely. I mean, you've got a boy genius who lives‚Äîalong with his‚Ä¶
Yo, this got themAuditionvibes.Check it outhere.
Not gonna lie. I kinda want to see this turned into a series.GetSnake Dick'd!

Watched this at the encouragement ofRepoJackandJozlyn.Anyway, y'all know I love me some Vantablack comedy, and this fits the bill. I felt like it dragged a little in the middle, but it mostly stuck the landing. I say mostly, because I did feel they could have got a little more absurd towards the end, but that's just me. Dances around in the space between anxiety-inducingly tense and absurdly funny. The premise may disturb some, but it's the kind of thing I wish we'd see more often. Go hard or go home, as someone said to me recently.

Haunted video game creepypasta nightmare. Scuzzy lo-fi gore and pulsating meat. Bubblegum-headed zombies and facial mastication. Tentacle clowns and the grungy, blasted out, skeletal remains of abandoned buildings. Necrotic sludge and toxic goop. Wriggling worms and rectal reapers. How did this Meredith guy get access to my apocalyptic dreams? Fun stuff.

Do I wish this had some more gore in it? Sure. But like, I wish that of every film. Name a movie, any movie, and I'd be of the opinion that it could only be improved with the addition of some blood and viscera strewn about. But I digress. The point is, that while it's true I love me some gore, I'm not a one note Johnny. I'm a multifaceted lunatic, or some such. I swear. I mean, I'm actually‚Ä¶

And it's about 40 minutes into this thing before you can even tell you're watching a horror film. But hey, Jozlyn and I actually quite enjoyed this. It's like a cheesy 80s take on the rage virus from28 Days Later. Don't expect to see a lot of the baboon on the poster, though.

Back in 2018, I watched 21 films with Amityville in the title andrankedthem. This was in the number 2 spot, afterAmityville II: The Possession. After revisiting this with the remastered version that's on Shudder (which I believe is the print from the Vinegar Syndrome box set), I'm wondering if this may actually be my favorite Amityville film. It's delightfully cheesy and fun, in the way late 80s/early 90s horror films usually are, and I still dig the whole proto-Oculusschtick. Anyway, Jozlyn and I had a friggin' blast watching this together.You can read my original reviewhere.

Well, it seems I'm late to the party yet again. And man, what a friggin' party. Scientists that talk like the dad inNo Retreat, No Surrender, zombie heads launching out of fridges, zombie birthing shenanigans, zombie DJs, dry ice fog and gel lighting all over the damn place. And what in the ever-loving fuckwaffles is up with that damn kid? I don't know, this movie is just kinda mesmerizingly awful, in a bizarrely charming way.

movietitle: Trancers II: The Return of Jack Deth
review: There's this sappy, tearjerker moment, near the end of this, involving some wibbly wobbly, timey wimey love triangle nonsense. Jack Deth gives his late wife a second chance, but they can't be together, because he loves Helen Hunt now. Anyway, while they're having this whole big sappy moment, his late wife (currently in the body of some teenage girl) is getting into a time machine that's so cheap and shoddy looking, it may as well be a cardboard box with‚Ä¶

Look, the movie is not spectacular or anything, but this is absolutely the kind of post-apocalyptic setting I wish we got more of in movies. It feels so much like the setting fromWasteland(the classic PC game), or the Deathlands novels, or even the Fallout games (if you removed the whole 50s retrofuturism aesthetic). I mean you've got glowing green skies, giant mutant scorpions, killer cockroaches stripping the flesh off people, rapey weirdos with sores all over their face,‚Ä¶

Well, my expectations were thoroughly subverted. This was absolutely not the teen sex comedy that poster led me to believe it was. If you dig 70s exploitation films, I highly recommend you go into this blind, like I did. You won't be disappointed. What a crazy ride, man.

Oof. This shit was rough. Poor ol' Charlie really went downhill, huh? Not even Gary Busey could save this shit. I mean,Evil Bongwas more fun. Hell, I might even preferOoga Boogato this nonsense. But hey, I've seen much worse, so...

Fuck it. 5 stars. Yeah, that's right. Lot of nostalgia for what's probably the best thing ol' Charlie Band ever directed. I mean how could I not love some crazy mashup ofBlade Runner,Terminator, and friggin'Quantum Leap? Tim Thomerson absolutely kills it as the Marlowe-esque future man, Jack Deth, and he and Helen Hunt have such great chemistry together. Do I wish the film spent more time in the 23rd century and less in 80s LA? Sure, but I'll take what I can get. This still holds up pretty well. Can't wait to dig into the sequels.

Holy shit! This was pretty fucking great!SuspiriaandInfernovibes for days! Does Argento better than post-1990 Argento. Slap a Goblin score on this bitch and you'd have an instant classic. There are some gorgeous shots in this, as well as some fantastic practical effects (spider baby will haunt your nightmares). I suspect the lower ratings on here are due to people having watched the old VHS quality version, rather than the spiffy new remaster. If you like dreamy‚Ä¶

Why the hell hasn't Richard Elfman directed more? I mean sure, the storytelling is a bit uneven here. It is, after all, a Full Moon film. But I really can't help but love its distinct aesthetic. A Charles Band production that predates Empire and Full Moon. The kind of dreadful B-movie nonsense that feels like it was made to be featured on MST3K. And, in fact, it actually did get an MST3K episode. And I wish I'd watched it that way, because it's largely kinda dull on its own, aside from the delightful stop-motion aliens (which didn't get nearly enough screen time). Pastel-colored suburban nightmare fuel acid trip. A film spewing forth abstract satire that holds up a cracked mirror to the face of the American Dream. The soccer mom is an unnervingly alien creature, utterly foreign to this material plane. The road to hell is lined with white picket fences. Be careful when gazing into the abyss...

"No beast so fierce but knows some touch of pity.""But I know none, and therefore am no beast."‚Äï William Shakespeare, Richard IIIWatched this at a fairly young age, because of my dad (it was his turn to pick the movie). My boredom is a disease, and Stallone is the cure.Man, I grew up watching this filth-encrusted action classic and I have yet to tire of it. Stallone pushing Dirty Harry even further than Eastwood (Filthy Harry, as Gene Siskel called it). A perfect marriage of loose cannon cop tropes and slasher flick atmosphere. Stallone taking out an army of psycho trash. Hoo boy, this is one odd duck of a film, to be sure. A cinematic misfire if there ever was one. A film Hitchcock didn't want to make and which he considered to be a disaster. And yet, a film I found weirdly entertaining. Oh, certainly not for the story, which is headache inducing and strains credulity to its very breaking point. I mean, I looked up the summary of the plot after watching and I'm still not bloody sure‚Ä¶

Like Star Wars and Conan had a weird, animated baby together. And that baby turned out gay. Really, really gay. And maybe neurodivergent.So much fun.Watched withJozlyn
Man, they sure pissed Santa off.He's makin' a list. He's checkin' it twice. Gonna find out who's Nazi or nice...

I can't believe I've watched ten of these Bad Ben films.In this one, we get to see some lost footage (discovered posthumously) of Tom Riley's adventures in paranormal investigation. Loved the bit where he accidentally summoned a demon in a home that had no activity prior to him showing up. And all the interviews with people who say he was an asshole or a moron. I'm legit looking forward to watching more of these. They're terrible in such a cozy and charming way.Watched withJozlyn

review: You know, I go back and forth on this one. It's all down to the mood I'm in when I get around to a rewatch. I've never liked it as much as the first seven films. Hell, there were times when I even wanted to pretend it didn't exist. Well, fuck all that, cuz this thing is actually pretty fun when you get out of its way and just let it happen. Sure, it's not perfect. Maybe it's even downright‚Ä¶

These movies are some goofy shit and I can't get enough. They're theTroll 2of Paranormal Activity knockoffs, and I'm here for it.Amityville schmamityville. This dude has battled with ghosts, demons, a Jersey devil, killer dolls, a killer clown, and perhaps even a witch.‚Ä¶

movietitle: Friday the 13th Part VII: The New Blood
review: I've always been kind of conflicted on this one. I mean, on the one hand, it has one of the best incarnations of Jason in the entire series. Kane Hodder really nailed the physicality of this undead terminator from hell. And I love the design, with Jason being all torn up from the previous film. I particularly love the little details, like the bits of exposed ribcage, spine, and teeth.On the other hand, I've never been overly fond of‚Ä¶

movietitle: Bad Ben 5: The Crescent Moon Clown
review: I'll never understand what Nigel Bach was thinking with this one. I mean, he course corrected after the second film in the series, when fans complained about the lack of Tom Riley. So, why he made this entry, in which 90% of the movie is just some annoying girl reacting (in the dumbest way possible) to the weird shit going on around the house, is beyond me. However, I did laugh out loud when Riley shows up at the very end and proceeds to fall down the damn stairs. If it wasn't for that scene, I'd have given this half a star.Watched withJozlyn
Tom Riley slapping an evil doll across the room and calling her a whore is the kinda thing I watch nonsense like this for.Watched withJozlyn

movietitle: The Hitchhiker's Guide to the Galaxy
review: Time! Time can, on occasion, alter one's perspective. A thing, once detested, is cast in a new light. Fragments of our personality drift, over time, shifting beneath the surface like tectonic plates. We are thus reconfigured. The world is seen anew.Sometimes, however, a thing is just terrible and shall always remain so. The passage of time will have no effect, here.My perspective on a lot of films has changed over the years. Some films, once beloved, eventually lose‚Ä¶

movietitle: The Hitchhiker's Guide to the Galaxy
review: Life. Don't talk to me about life.Threw this on to show Jozlyn, after a recent re-read of the books.Seen this more times than I can count, over the years. A timeless classic. Its dated effects and shoddy BBC production are all part of its charm, in my opinion. Always loved David Dixon as Ford, and Peter Jones is brilliant as the voice of The Guide.The books are better, of course, but this adaptation has a lot of heart.Would it save you a lot of time if I just gave up and went mad now?Watched withJozlyn

I found the first half of this to be a thrilling orbital drop into a hellish, anxiety-inducing nightmare, while the second half becomes more experimental and meanders at times. Yeah, no. This is not the sexy, BDSM fun that the cover promises. I don't know what it actually is, but it's not that. This kinda felt like a demented Goosebumps episode, with a distinctly Hooperish edge to it. The dilapidated mortuary setting is pretty great, and the story heads in a vaguely Lovecraftian direction. Fun stuff.

This has surprisingly good cinematography for porn, as well as a bizarrely downbeat ending. What else is there to say? It's porn. You want a damn essay about this shit? Fun stuff.Watched withJozlyn

Oh, and just one more thing.I put this on to introduce Jozlyn to Columbo.It still amazes me how much tension you can wring out of a murder mystery where there's no mystery. movietitle: Beavis and Butt-Head Do the Universe
review: Step aside, please. We have white privilege.Maybe I'm just an easy-to-please kinda guy. I mean, the amount of 4 and 5-star reviews I toss out would seem to suggest so, no? Or, maybe that's just a function of me mostly watching things I know I'll like.Maybe I'm just stuck in the 80s and 90s, gorging myself silly on memberberries to the point that I'm mentally regressing to an earlier incarnation of myself. I guess I'm just a sucker for these phantasmagorical Rollin jams, cuz I was really vibing with this. A surreal, gothic treat that feels simultaneously artsy and sleazy, with huge swaths of its runtime eerily devoid of dialog and bordering on being a silent film. A tale of two lost girls wandering into one of Anne Rice's wilder dreams, filled with dilapidated cemeteries, crumbling chateaus, rapey vampires, and cunnilingus bats, apparently (yeah, that's a new one for me). Kind of reminded me ofThe Demoniacs, except with a more haunting and dreamlike quality (which is saying a lot, actually).Watched withJozlyn

It may be a sign that my sanity is hanging by a thread but I didn't actually hate this. Sure, the lead is a bit insufferable and the house looks all wrong for the story this is attempting to tell, but the dream sequences and cheap-looking but ambitious effects won me over.Loosely (and I mean very loosely) adapted from Lovecraft'sThe Dreams in the Witch House, this Polonia-produced schlock starts off feeling like one of those unofficial Amityville sequels‚Ä¶

Robocopis one of those films that was hugely integral to my experience growing up in the 80s. I mean, this sucker is bonded with me at a molecular level. And it's interesting how I kind of fell in love with these dark, R-rated films at such a young age, propelled by an obsession with robots, androids, and cyborgs.‚Ä¶

Around three years ago, I marathoned the twenty Amityville films that had been released at the time. You see, roughly half of those are no-budget trash that have Amityville in the title because it's not something you can copyright. Droplets of swirling chaos plummet through the void until they collide with the membrane, shattering consciousness. Shards, like broken glass, spiral through the vortex of perception. Thoughts, razor-sharp, slice through the mind. A cacophony of fragmented imagery at the periphery of awareness, stretched thin and then looped back on itself like a M√∂bius strip. Thus the seeds are sown, from which order is birthed. Screaming into being with violence and fury. Discordant resonance, spasms of the stirring beast. Echoes of that which has yet to be, rippling backward in time. The serpent consumes its tail.Watched withJozlyn

Does anyone rememberBen-Hur? No, I don't mean the 2016 remake. I'm talking about the 1959 version that was (at the time) the most ambitious and expensive undertaking Hollywood had yet attempted. I mean, this sucker was the 50s equivalent of Peter Jackson'sLord of the Ringstrilogy. With a whopping budget of $15.2 million (yeah, it doesn't sound like much today), the largest sets ever constructed for a film, roughly a hundred people churning out costumes, and hundreds of‚Ä¶

There are several aesthetic flavors that I find myself uncontrollably drawn to, like a weeb to hentai and body pillows. From old, black-and-white, gothic horror films, with imagery inspired by German Expressionism, to the audiovisual splendor of Ridley Scott's holy trifecta (Blade Runner,Alien, andLegend), along with many other flavors that fall within that spectrum. What shouldn't fall within the spectrum of my particular taste, however, is the twee insanity of Wes Anderson. And yet, for reasons I can't‚Ä¶

A gang of bad bitches (consisting of a deranged mother and her two daughters) exploit and abuse a literal man-baby until they run into a social worker who's an even badder bitch.All I could think, as I watched this nonsense unfold, is how much I want a Rob Zombie remake that cranks the fucking knob to eleven.This was fun though, and the ending melted my brain.Watched withJozlyn

It's something that's been taught in every film school sinceJawswas released. A lesson that almost every aspiring filmmaker learns (or, at least, should learn). That less is more. Saunders) that appeared in the 1979 anthology,Amazons!, this features an Amazon warrior named Dyala, who quests for a legendary‚Ä¶

Ninkyo eiga (chivalry films) is a yakuza subgenre that I'm only partially acquainted with. Films that revolve around 'good guy' yakuza who grapple with honor and strict moral codes while their enemies often play by a much looser set of rules. It's a bit like watching someone play poker against opponents who are all cheating. As you can imagine, this frequently fails to work in the favor of our honorable protagonists.This is worth watching for Ken Takakura alone, who‚Ä¶

Creaky old house, stormy nights, howling wind, power outages, and a shed full of Egyptian sarcophagi for some reason. I just want to curl up with some tea and crumpets and marathon a bunch of these.

Nhadiep is a name attributed to an elusive serial killer (responsible for a string of brutal ritualistic murders) who was active in Namibia in the early 1980s. movietitle: Halloween: The Curse of Michael Myers
review: I always used to hate this one. I prefer my boy, Michael, to be mysterious, you know? It was all so vague and undefined in the beginning. He's pure evil. He's the boogeyman. What more do you need to know? It leaves you with so many questions. Carpenter subtly suggests that he's something more than just a man, but it's just that. A suggestion. You could buy into Loomis' hyperbolic rants and accept that Michael is something we've never seen‚Ä¶

This is some sleazy Nikkatsu trash, with nuns that apparently keep bondage gear on hand for torturing members of their own order when they have relations with men. There's a priest who, after a nun confides that she was gang-raped, responds by raping her himself. There's a nun death squad, dressed all in black and looking like nun ninjas, or nunjas if you prefer. It's a crazy little film that's bound to entertain to some degree, if you're into this kind of thing. The rest of you should probably have nun of this. *ducks*Watched withJozlyn

movietitle: Halloween 5: The Revenge of Michael Myers
review: Can we just take a moment to appreciate that Loomis goes full-on nutballs in this one, endangering and traumatizing a little girl in order to use her as bait? Ahab has to catch his whale by whatever means necessary, as he's got a serious case of Michael madness. Hell, he even goes one-on-one with Michael in a final showdown for the ages and it's hard not to love that just a little bit. Unfortunately, the cracks are starting to show‚Ä¶

It blew the damn doors off the room and Michael stumbled out, engulfed in flames, and collapsed to the floor. Yet, at the start of this entry, Michael has been in a coma for the last ten years, while Loomis is walking around with nothing but a‚Ä¶

movietitle: The Lair of the White Worm
review: This is only my second Ken Russell film, and the first,Altered States, I saw so long ago that it barely counts anymore. Can someone tell me if Russell was just walking around with an IV drip feeding weapons-grade LSD into his bloodstream all the time? Cuz there's like this weird, sexy horror comedy in here, about a snake lady, that‚Ä¶

So, I wasn't particularly interested in checking this one out. It's not in Technicolor and it doesn't have Vincent Price. Sacrilege, I say! But Jozlyn got the Vinegar Syndrome Blu and wanted to watch it together. And, while I felt like I was cheating on Vincent Price a little, I decided I would give‚Ä¶

If you go into this expecting a horror film, it's quite possible that you'll come away disappointed. There is an ever so slight trace of folk horror delicately draped over this, and, at times, it feels more like a straight period drama with the faintest touch of magical realism. It drags at times when it veers away from its strengths as a surreal and atmospheric mood piece with some stunning imagery. It's a very seasonally appropriate film, with some strong‚Ä¶

Man, what a way to close out the night, after watchingPiranha IIandDeep Space. An 80s take on 50s killer brain and bodysnatcher movies, with an 80s version of Dr. Phil, played by David Gale, using his show to brainwash people. There's a goopy giant brain with a face and hallucinations that feel like something out ofA Nightmare on Elm Street. And it's friggin' Canadian. I don't know how I managed to avoid this for so long.‚Ä¶

Charles Napier hunts an off-brand Xenomorph in this buddy cop bug hunt from Fred Olen Ray. Schlocky B-movie fun that feels like a 50s creature feature updated for the 80s. The creature effects are surprisingly decent and I found the whole thing to be rather charming. I mean, they establish this thing as some practically indestructible biological weapon, so, of course, Napier goes after it armed with a shotgun and a hunting knife. He also uses bagpipes to seduce women.‚Ä¶

How do you not love a movie where genetically engineered killer fish flap around like the rubber bats in old Dracula movies? This is James Cameron doing a silly B-movie with surprisingly good gore effects and an angry Lance Henriksen. Ok, it's a bit of a stretch to say it was Cameron's film, even though his name is on it. The reality is that, while he shot some footage for a couple of weeks, it was really directed by Ovidio‚Ä¶

You know how inAlienknockoffs, especially the cheaper ones, they often have to avoid showing the creature much, in order to hide the shoddy effects? Either emulating Spielberg's approach fromJawsor keeping it constantly obscured by shadows? Well, it seems they found a solution here. You just have a woman possessed by some alien intelligence, and granted superpowers, running around and slaughtering everyone while screaming her damn head off half the time. This is toFriday the 13thwhatYoung Frankensteinis to the James Whale Frankenstein films. Both witty parody and loving homage. Went in blind and, man, was this a find. A supernatural pseudo-slasher that feels likeThe Exorcisttook a wrong turn at the corner ofFlatlinersandThe Crow, ending up on Elm Street. Gnarly green-eyed vengeance from beyond, served up with some delectably gruesome kills. The tone is utterly bonkers, feeling like a psychological thriller most of the time but occasionally exploding into some full-on 80s cheesetastic horror moments that approach almostEvil Dead IIlevels of crazy. The whole thing ends up feeling like a long episode ofTales from the Crypt. Loved it!Watched withJozlyn

This currently has a 14% on Rotten Tomatoes, which proves that site is utter garbage. This may just be a new favorite giallo for me. It has all of the slick style you'd expect from the genre, set against the seedy, filth-encrusted backdrop of New York. Despite some late 70s made-for-TV vibes, it manages to include most of the ingredients you'd expect from an early 80s slasher. There's at least one satisfyingly bloody kill and some suitably mean-spirited moments. I could have used a bit more atmosphere and some more blood but, overall, a trio of soulless, homicidal kids makes for a fun time.

Ok, I admit that I was a tad bit skeptical when everyone was saying this was the best superhero movie ever. Well, I was wrong. This is, indeed, the best freakin' thing ever. Made me feel 10 years old again. Spider-man has always been my favourite superhero and, while I have liked some of the film adaptations, they never truly had the same energy as the comics... until now. They better be planning a sequel to this. Hell, just scrap the MCU and start doing every Marvel movie like this going forward.

"Resolve is never stronger than in the morning after the night it was never weaker."- JohnnySardonically delivered dialogue so sharp you could shave with it. Nihilistic philosophizing spewing forth from our anti-hero like a broken faucet. A savagely bleak odyssey, peppered with moments of genuine humanity. A fiercely compelling tale of existential angst, bitter loneliness, sex, and violence, set against the backdrop of post-Thatcher London. An unbelievably powerful performance from David Thewlis. A provocative, gritty slab of dark humor. Grim and poetic.What's not to love?  Ö(¬∞_¬∞) É

I don't know why this one was necessary if that's all they were gonna do with it. The series had a conclusion already. Oh well, this was still fun at least. I mean, it's really just more of the same ingredients that we're already familiar with, but those ingredients still produce a tasty cake if baked just right. I think I still prefer the over-the-top insanity ofVIandVII. To its credit, however, this does seem like a more‚Ä¶

This is definitely a step down from the last one, but there's still a lot to like here. We get Hoffman at his most villainous. Some delightfully over-the-top gore. A fun death trap that takes out a gang of neo-nazis. A pretty decent end to the whole Hoffman arc. And, we finally get to see the reverse bear-trap kill someone.What's not to love?  Ö(¬∞_¬∞) É

So, just when I was starting to think these were going to decline in quality with each new entry,Saw VIcomes along and blows my friggin' mind. The tension is back in full force. The emotional stakes are raised. Questions are answered. The main escape room game was one of the best so far.This just flat out exceeded all of my expectations for the sixth entry in such a divisive franchise.Also, don't forget to watch the post-credits sequence, if you haven't already.

Jigsaw 2.0 plays a game of musical chairs. When the music stops somebody dies a gruesome death, but only because they're playing the game wrong. So, we learn a nice fluffy lesson about the value of co-operation. Too bad most people would rather stab each other in the back to survive.I liked this one more than I expected to. Jigsaw's understudy is becoming an interesting villain. The new escape room game in this one is possibly my favourite so‚Ä¶

I'm starting to notice a trend with these films. Any holes in the plot that you might notice, after watching one of them, will likely be addressed in the following film. It's almost as if the writers listened to all the criticism the films received, and then wrote the next entry specifically to correct any issues that were raised. I mentioned, in my review forSaw III, that it was a bit of a stretch to think that John and‚Ä¶

You can start to see the cracks creeping across the foundation of this franchise here. One could argue that the emphasis on increasingly brutal death traps/torture contraptions, that seemingly exist only so the effects department can serve up a heaping helping of creative and satisfying gore effects, is possibly robbing the franchise of one of the key ingredients of any good horror film. That essential ingredient is tension. In the first two films, there was an element of hope. It‚Ä¶

If I had to sum this film up in one word, that word would bemore. More kills. More crazy death traps. More whacky escape room hijinks. More Tobin Bell. More brick to the face twisty ending. Just... more. I mean, if you liked the first one, there's no reason you shouldn't like this. Sure, it'smoreof the same, but what's wrong with that? That's what horror franchises do, isn't it? If I wanted something fresh, I wouldn't be watching sequels in the first place.

A gritty, grimy, and grungy aesthetic. An electro-industrial score composed by Charlie Clouser, who previously worked with Trent Reznor. Fiendish death traps. A central mystery, filled with twists and turns, that will keep you guessing right up till the end. And, most importantly, an ending that hits like a brick to the face.What's not to love?  Ö(¬∞_¬∞) ÉA lot of people come down hard on this franchise for ushering in the era of "torture porn" style horror. I think‚Ä¶
Did anyone else think this was hilarious?...No?...*backs away slowly*

movietitle: VHS Massacre: Cult Films and the Decline of Physical Media
review: I certainly possess a lot of nostalgia for the 80s and 90s, especially when it comes to horror films. The age of the video store. The age of enticing box art. The age of cheap direct-to-video horror films flooding the market. And, while I can see the appeal in maybe collecting VHS for the box art, I don't get people who still prefer to watch VHS. Lloyd Kaufman even states, in this very documentary, that "there's nothing beautiful about VHS."‚Ä¶

I remember liking this when it came out but, for whatever reason, I haven't watched it again since. It's one of the many films that just slipped through the cracks in the floorboards of time. There was always new horror movies to watch, and the ones I did re-watch were the absolute classics that stood out in my memory and demanded to be seen again. Lately, however, I find myself waxing nostalgic with regards to the horror films of the‚Ä¶

Necro Lives Matter!I'm ashamed to admit that I used to think Necrosapiens were just mindless, shambling monsters, that consumed human flesh. I'm guilty of using the Z word with little to no regard for the history behind it, or the feelings it evokes in the walking dead. After watchingWhat Doesn't Kill Us, however, I have been forced to check my privilege as a living, breathing human. It has caused me to re-examine my views on our rotting brethren.‚Ä¶

Do you like buddy cop action films from the 80s, likeLethal Weapon,48 Hours, orRed Heat? How about over the top, practical effects driven horror comedies from the 80s, likeThe Return of the Living Dead,Night of the Creeps, orRe-Animator? What if I told you that you could get all that in just one movie? That's right folks,Dead Heatis the mashup you didn't know you wanted. Act now and we'll even throw in a‚Ä¶

Watched director's cut.I really struggle with my feelings on this one. I don't know whether I love it or hate it. Like all Rob Zombie films, there are moments of brilliance, and then there are moments where you just can't figure out what the hell he was thinking. I hated this the first time I saw it, and I was one of the people who actually liked the first one, even though it completely missed the point of Michael‚Ä¶

The nostalgia factor is high on this one. I went to see this in the theatre when I was ten years old, along with my dad, my uncle, and my cousin. My cousin and I laughed hysterically as Kevin tortured Harry and Marv. Having grown up on Buster Keaton, Charlie Chaplin, Laurel and Hardy, and The Three Stooges, I've always been a sucker for some slapstick humour. In fact, Harry and Marv remind me a lot of Laurel and Hardy‚Ä¶

From Rick Sloane, the director who brought usHobgoblins, we get a film that feels like a live action remake of an 80s cartoon that, itself, was a parody of 50s sci-fi films. This even feels tonally reminiscent, at times, of the LucasArts adventure games,Maniac MansionandDay of the Tentacle, except with the kind of trashy aesthetic you'd expect from a Rick Sloane film. If that sounds like a fun time, then this is probably for you. If,‚Ä¶

Looks like Christmas came a little early this year. Well, I hope it was good for you honey.- Jack FrostI've avoided watching this for ages because I thought it would be unbelievably stupid... and I was right. This is, indeed, a stupid film. However, it's stupid in a way that still manages to be very entertaining. It turns out that watching a killer snowman dispatch people with cartoonish violence, while spouting one liners, is actually a ton of fun. Sure, the effects are pure cheese, the acting is over the top, and the plot is ridiculous, but... killer fucking snowman!

I'm kind of glad that I put this one off as long as I did. Watching this on Shudder, with Joe Bob Briggs in the mix, was the best way to see this for the first time.I ended up having a lot more fun with this than I expected. Of all the obscure horror films being revived, thanks to Blu-ray remasters, this is one of my favorites. I honestly like this better thanPiecesandThe Mutilator. Louise Lasser‚Ä¶

Mr. Cosmatos, please show us, on the doll, where the new age self-help guru/cult leader touched you.Seriously, I'm sensing a theme in his films.Anyway, this is the kind of movie that you need to just give yourself over to. Don't try to make sense of it. Just let it happen. Experience it. Let it wash over you in waves. Immerse yourself in its acid fueled, nightmare aesthetic. Feel the vibrations of the droning synth score in your bones.‚Ä¶

Calling this a pitch black comedy doesn't cut it. There's a material called Vantablack (Vertically Aligned carbon NanoTube Array), which absorbs 99.6% of light. It's uncomfortably black. Three dimensional objects coated with Vantablack appear to have no discernible surface features. They just appear to be a black void in space. A pure black silhouette. Bob Balaban'sParentsis darker than that. The sense of creeping dread is almost overwhelming, and Randy Quaid seems impossibly creepy.Parentsexpertly captures the essence‚Ä¶

A dark, phantasmagorical, neon tinted fever dream. A haunting and tragic love story. An abstract examination of the destructiveness of grief, particularly when that grief is due to the loss of a soulmate. Someone who completes you, and who gives your life purpose and meaning. A blacklight rainbow nightmare. Dark, pulsating synth drones over a visual aesthetic that feels like a Frazetta painting mated with a black metal album cover. A movie that feels like someone splattered my soul across a cinematic canvas.

Is it just me, or does anyone else want to see a slasher franchise with the little girl in the yellow dress (played by Sara Moore)? I'm kind of sad that she was wasted onChildren of the Corn. Though this film is a tad light on kills, there's some scenes here where this innocent looking little girl slaughters people with a gleeful brutality. I wanna watch a whole movie, or several movies, filled with scenes like the one where‚Ä¶

Like the laterHellraisersequels, this feels like someone tried to shoehorn an unrelated spec script into theChildren of the Cornfranchise. There's some interesting ideas on display here, but it just isn't cohesive enough to pull it off. I especially didn't find the protagonists very likeable.This almost reminds me of theTwilight Zoneepisode, "It's a Good Life", with some vagueChildren of the Cornreferences tossed in, except we don't get to see the creepy kid‚Ä¶

So, I like that they were trying to be more true to the original short story. In fact, this follows the original story almost dead on. That makes it all the more disappointing that this falls flat despite its faithfulness to the source material. Maybe adaptingChildren of the Cornalmost verbatim doesn't actually work, or maybe this was just poorly directed.I'd complain that Vicky is one of the most insufferably irritating characters I've ever seen, but then she‚Ä¶

This may very well be a bad movie, objectively. Surprisingly, however, I didn't totally hate it. Yeah, it drags for the first half, it looks pretty cheap, and the gore is a bit lacking, but the kids are creepy ghost kids this time, and it's more atmospheric than most films in this franchise. I actually prefer this overIsaac's Return.Michael Ironside even has a brief cameo in this, which classes things up a tad. I just wish he was in this a bit more.With all that said, this is still pretty bad. Manage your expectations accordingly.

movietitle: Children of the Corn 666: Isaac's Return
review: Ok, I just watched the originalChildren of the Cornagain, recently, and I'm pretty sure Isaac is definitely dead at the end. But who cares right? Somebody thought it would be a great idea to rejuvenate the franchise by bringing him back. So, apparently, he's just been in a coma since the first movie, and now has two teenage sons. One of those sons, according to prophecy, is destined to impregnate Hannah, the first born of "the children," who‚Ä¶

movietitle: Children of the Corn V: Fields of Terror
review: Yet another of these that I forgot having watched back when it came out.Lacking the atmosphere of the previous instalment,Children of the Corn V: Fields of Terrorfeels a bit flat. Sure, we've got David Carradine this time around, as well as Eva Mendes. Hell, we even get Kane Hodder making an appearance as a bartender. None of them can save this from being horrifically boring for long stretches, and at times feeling like an after school special‚Ä¶

movietitle: Children of the Corn IV: The Gathering
review: With its brutal kills and dark, foreboding atmosphere,Children of the Corn IVis actually better than I expected, though that isn't saying much. I went in with the lowest of expectations and was pleasantly surprised when it wasn't total dog shit. It's still a DTV sequel in a franchise that had no business turning out sequels, but as long as you aren't expecting miracles here, this is actually pretty decent.I like that the story departs from the usual‚Ä¶

movietitle: Children of the Corn III: Urban Harvest
review: Another one of the myriad of horror films I watched in the 90s and then completely forgot about. Revisiting it after all these years, I'm left wondering why it didn't leave a more lasting impression when I first watched it. Sure, the story is a bit corny, the acting is nothing to write home about, and the overall quality is exactly what you'd expect from a direct-to-video horror sequel released in 1995. However, this is much more entertaining if you‚Ä¶

movietitle: Children of the Corn II: The Final Sacrifice
review: "These kids watch too many horror movies."- Frank RedbearThere's nothing final about this sacrifice. There's still seven more sequels.As for the film itself, someone drops a house on an old woman. A freakin' house. Nuff said."Koyaanisqatsi. It means life out of balance. My ancestors would have told you that man should be at one with the earth, the skies, and water. But the white man has never understood this. He only knows how to take. And after a while, there's nothing left to take. So, everything's out of balance. And we all fall down."- Frank Redbear

I used to likeChildren of the Cornback when I was a kid. In fact, I pretty much liked any Stephen King adaptation that came out in those days. Watching it now, however, it doesn't seem to have aged very gracefully, and is beginning to look a bit long in the tooth. It has an almost made for television aesthetic, as well as some pretty dated looking visual effects. Furthermore, the happy ending bothers me a lot more than‚Ä¶

Except this has nothing whatsoever to do with Amityville. This isn't even a haunted prison movie. There's a threat, sure, but it isn't a ghost. I couldn't even find this anywhere asAmityville Prison. The Amityville franchise has a number of films in which the plot involves cursed objects removed from the original house. This allows the films to take place in new locations. We've had a haunted lamp, a haunted clock, a haunted mirror, and even a haunted toy monkey. Now, we can add haunted lumber to the list. Yeah, that's right, someone took some wood from the Amityville house and used it to build new houses.This is another of the unofficial‚Ä¶

So, we're back to found footage again with this one. This time we get two movies in one.The Blair Witch ProjectandParanormal Activity, or rather cheap knockoffs of those films. This alternates back and forth between a group of people who decide to take a trip to Amityville and go camping in the woods, in order to learn about fear, and an old VHS tape containing a video diary of a woman who had just moved into the‚Ä¶

Wow! I'm shook. This actually looks like a real movie, as opposed to some drunk teenagers screwing around with their new digital camcorder. After the first six of the unofficial Amityville films, this is a significant step up in quality. Hell, it's even better than some of the official Amityville sequels, though that's a pretty low bar to clear. The actors may not be winning any awards for their performances, but at least they can act, which is more than‚Ä¶

This opens with a shot of the original house that looks like it might be a model or something, and then we get yet another recreation of Ronald DeFeo murdering his family, in order to establish that a toy monkey was present that night. This is theNew Nightmareof the Amityville series. A meta horror film that takes place in the real world where the other films are mentioned. It's a bit disappointing that there isn't more haunted house tropes here. They seem to get those out of the way fairly quickly, focusing instead on George Lutz, played here by Ryan Reynolds, and his rapid descent into madness. Reynolds goes full on Jack Nicholson,‚Ä¶

Bad enough I had to worry about moving into a haunted house, especially since I moved frequently throughout my childhood, but now I had to worry about evil entities infiltrating perfectly ordinary homes.
