Even though I suffered many sleepless nights as a kid, and was constantly plagued by nightmares when I did sleep, I couldn't resist watching horror films. I didn't even have to watch a film to lose sleep over it. I was always drawn to the horror section at the video store and loved looking at the box covers, as well as reading the back of the box. This would send my already overactive imagination into terror-inducing overdrive, but I couldn't‚Ä¶

Sometimes, when you want something bad enough, and for long enough, you find yourself lowering your standards. For example, when I was desperate for a film adaptation of William Gibson's cyberpunk novels, I settled forJohnny Mnemonic. I even loved it when it first came out, and watched it repeatedly. Looking back through a more objective lens, it's likely that my judgment was clouded to some degree by my desire for any film adaptation that brought that sweet Gibsonian cyberpunk‚Ä¶

Given how many horror franchises shit the proverbial bed when it comes to continuity and mythological consistency, I must give this franchise the credit it's due. Each film in the Child's Play/Chucky franchise picks up where the previous film left off and continues to tell a consistent story that builds on what has happened before. While this doesn't seem like it should be a big deal, it's surprisingly rare in long running horror franchises (Hellraiser, I'm looking at you). Each‚Ä¶

Hooptober 5.0: Film 33/33Perhaps drawing inspiration from Evil Dead II (assuming time travel is involved somehow), as well as Motel Hell (which Hooper almost directed), this follow-up to the immortal classic eschews gritty realism in favor of over-the-top insanity and dark humor. With an almost comic book aesthetic, much more gore, cannibalism as a business endeavor, the addition of Dennis Hopper as an unhinged former Texas Ranger wielding dual chainsaws and out for revenge, and a climactic chainsaw duel‚Ä¶

review: This was a lot more fun than I was expecting it to be. Not one, not two, but three scream queens. We get Linnea Quigley as a punk chick with an attitude. So, like, no surprise there. And we also get Brinke Stevens and Michelle Bauer as sorority initiates Taffy and Lisa.There's even an imp named Uncle Impie, portrayed by a cheap looking puppet and voiced by Dukey Flyswatter. I swear when they gave this guy direction for voicing‚Ä¶

Leave it to a Canadian to direct the bleakest zombie film ever, and cast a porn star for the lead. This film is cold and frigid like Canadian winters. Does Cronenberg even know what a happy ending is? Not that I'm complaining. I hate happy endings. Especially in horror movies.

Canadian Giallo? Maybe.Crazy kills? Indeed.Batshit insane Scooby-Doo ending? Fo' shizzle.Best corpse display scene ever? Quite possibly.Creepy end credits song? It has one, yeah.Final tally: Not bad for a Canadian slasher from 1981.Fun fact: This was directed by J. Lee Thompson, who also directedThe Guns of NavaroneandCape Fear.

Hey... Have a nice day!- Alison ParksLike a poor man's Johnny 5 with ED-209's winning personality. And there's three of them. Easily the best 80s horror movie about killer mall security robots. And it was even filmed at Sherman Oaks Galleria, where they filmed the mall scenes for Commando.

I feel bad for what happened to Taylor Hickson during filming. I'm just gonna get that out of the way first.That aside, I enjoyed this. It was reminiscent ofHigh Tension, but without the nonsensical twist. It's dark. It's brutal. It's unforgiving. And the tension is high (forgive me) when it gets going.This is by Pascal Laugier, who also directedMartyrs. Comparisons between the two films are inevitable. Is this as good asMartyrs? No. But I don't think it's as terrible as some are making it out to be either.

I'm not spoiling a damn thing. Just watch it. Or don't. I don't care. But no spoilers for you.

I don't have words. Not yet anyway. I need time to reflect on what I just watched. Perhaps watch it a few more times.The originalBlade Runnerhas been my favorite film for as long as I can remember. I was terrified to watch this up until now. I believed that some things were better left untouched.Prometheusdidn't help with that. But I felt something watching this. It felt something akin to the first time I watchedBlade Runner. That's all I can say at the moment.

review: Clocking in at 400 minutes, I felt this could have run longer. No seriously, that wasn't a joke. The Blue Underground Blu-ray for this looks amazing.It's another horror sequel that ups the action at the expense of horror, likeAliens, but I loveAliensand I thoroughly enjoyed this.

Slick cinematography and enough artfully placed shadows to satisfy even the most demanding chiaroscuro enthusiast. And a great poster too.This charming little picture is apparently the first supernatural horror film. The original haunted house movie.Cold spots, candles going out, seances, a glass being hurled across the room, disembodied voices, ghostly apparitions. It all started here folks.It‚Äôs more lighthearted than creepy, but it remains engaging throughout, with a satisfying story that twists and turns.It ends with a line that, depending on your disposition, will either be a knee slapper or a groaner.

Why the hell did no one tell me about this?This movie has balls for something that came out in 1980. Big, slimy, fish man balls. I freakin' love it. Great looking fish men. Fantastic gore effects. A plot that would feel right at home in a 50's monster movie, like some wonderful mash up ofThe Creature from the Black LagoonandThe Beast from 20,000 Fathoms.This is great stuff!

The gripping tale of a man who just wants to bone his wife, but she isn't dtf, so he starts having visions of creepy chauffeurs. And a vampire house... or something. I dunno.It's not the Shining, but it's certainly better than The Amityville Horror.

Cahn, a stalwart of 1950s Westerns and Creature Features, Invisible Invaders is a lot of Science-y dialogue and portentous narration. I think the reviews of The Comedy of Terrors are exceptionally kind. Personally, I found the film a real chore after the first 25 to 30 minutes. It has a threadbare plot, the curiously reanimating Macbeth spouting Basil Rathbone is a nice idea, but for 45 minutes it was beyond my tolerance. Vincent Price and Peter Lorre are an amusingly tall/short combo, but the film gives them no jokes. Boris Karloff Karloff's about, and Joyce Jameson sing opera and displays cleavage. A horror comedy that isn't funny, and barely begins to touch on horror. I found it quite tedious.

The most striking thing about Mr. Scorsese is I never realised how flinty Scorsese is, and how likeable De Niro would seem. I thought they'd be the other way around.The documentary is a fun watch, even at 5 hours. But it is more anecdote than incisive. I don't think Rebecca Miller asks one interesting question about any of the films Scorsese made. She is quite intrigued by his childhood and his drug habit, but has only nominal interest in exploring his professional work.

A brilliantly filmed atmospheric horror film, which eschews any plot or character for lengthy scenes where a vengeful cat wreaks bloody revenge. The second half is slowing building horror and works as attack after attack, all while the soundtrack is a mix of screeching and unusual instrumentation. It is mostly staged in one setting, but the film does a lot with shadows, and camera angles, to be visually really interesting.Though, let's be honest, The Haunted Castle may look like a classy product, but it is a cat slasher.

Not since Jacques Tati's Playtime, have I thought "well, someone is going to have to explain to me how he made this film".A film of remarkable visual acuity, moments of heart-stopping beauty, and striking melodrama. Love interrupted war was a hackneyed plot even by 1957, but this film raises it to a rare artistic level with the sheer filmmaking craft.I think I need to revisit Sean Connery's The Red Tent.

It is impossibly well crafted, and it is clearly one of the inspirations for modern-day masterpiece Phantom Thread. It has a sickly quality,‚Ä¶

The Ride Back is a very good, rather sparse western with solid performances from Anthony Quinn and William Conrad. It is a stark two-hander that shares quite a lot with 3:10 to Yuma.Produced by Robert Aldrich, the film has a hard-edge, and treats you to some unusual touches. The Mexican characters actually speak in Spanish. The film is shot by Aldrich regular Joseph F. Biroc and has a menacing quality. It is a brisk 80 minutes with a nice‚Ä¶

A messy noir starring Alan Ladd and Veronica Lake, which has an outsized reputation due to it being from a Raymond Chandler credited script, and for its connection to the Elizabeth Short, Black Dahlia, murder.The Blue Dahlia is almost a good film, but I find it quite an underwhelming watch. It is quite poorly directed, as it shuffles through its post-war mystery of adultery and murder.It has atmosphere and a few really good scenes. I always find Ladd‚Ä¶

If I was making a film in 1965, I would also cast Juliet Prowse.I'm not sure if Who Killed Teddy Bear? is a good film, but it might be a great one. A film of obscene phone calls, a DJ looking like Prowse, Sal Mineo's body, all sorts of psychological trauma and unease, and noirish dialogue that might not know it verges on parodic.Sleazy, hard-edged, and unpleasant, but with a 1950s sensibility smuggled into the 1960s. As if‚Ä¶

I like the ever prolific Guy Ritchie. I think his best film was released only a couple of years ago, Guy Ritchie's The Covenant (to give it its rather clunky full title), and I am happy to watch whatever he puts out. I think we have two films to look forward to him from the next 12 months, In the Grey and Wife & Dog. He doesn't have what you'd call quality control, but in his rush to release film there‚Ä¶

Well, I absolutely loved Highest 2 Lowest.It is easily the best film I have seen at the cinema since January. Perhaps, Spike Lee's best film since He Got Game.It is a thrilling mix of moral conundrum, filmmaking style, and political conservatism. It looks great, sharp colours and lush rich production and comes with a traditionally insisent Spike Lee soundtrack. Howard Drossin soundscape is thrilling. Almost all of Lee's films are musicals, and this is a big orchestral New‚Ä¶
Beware of all enterprises which require new clothes.Words to live by.

Honey Don't! is much closer to a good movie than Drive-Away Dolls, but I think it is fairly clear who is the Coen Brother with most of the talent.Margaret Qualley is great. Chris Evans and Aubrey Plaza very much aren't. The film kind of dies due to the variability of performance, the lack of complexity to the mystery, and the really leaden editing.But, there is something there. You can almost see the person who made Fargo and No‚Ä¶

Directed by Burt Balaban (Bob's cousin) Lady of Vengeance is a curiously static affair. The big set-piece is the authentification of a stamp. A British crime film, which at least nods at the American film noir aesthetic, has a intriguing plot -21-year-old Melissa Collins (Eileen Elton) commits suicide, her guardian, the domineering American newspaper publisher William T. Marshall (Dennis O'Keefe), searches (in flashback) for a reason.There is no real reason given to why O'Keefe has a ward (he's‚Ä¶
I ain't gonna go Bulgarian

Night of the Big Heat is a film that really understood why its plot had potential for being a hit with Jane Merrow embracing the Big Heat in every scene. She is variously bursting out of her buttoned shirt, or swanning about in a bikini.Peter Cushing, on the other hand, probably enjoyed making this film more than anything he made. His whole performance is sitting in a pub, drinking bitter, and not speaking. He just saunters down the Swan‚Ä¶

I watched Bar Mitzvah Boy last night, and it was really wonderful. A 1976 BBC Play for Today. It is a beautifully observed bittersweet comedy written by the great Jack Rosenthal. It properly made me laugh, while providing a really good look at a lower-middle class London Jewish family haphazardly preparing for their son's Bar Mitzvah. The acting and dialogue are basically perfect, and I wasn't at all distracted by the Play for Today functional visuals."...and don't just lie‚Ä¶

The House and the Brain is the fourth of five television movies from the 1970's in "The Classic Ghosts" series. It is an attempt at an romantic gothic thriller, with a neat circuitous plot device.A pretty young woman lures male victims into boarding house in New Orleans, at the behest of a local warlock, who seemingly wants to relive a love triangle endlessly. It is a good plot, with a good ending.The TV movie has the cheap aesthetic, as all the "Classic Ghosts" series does, but I found myself fairly taken with this entry.

A writer (Perry King) takes a room in a boarding house and finds himself haunted by a menacing invisible presence that may be the ghost of a previous tenant or that of his long-lost love. He also spends 66 the minutes hooking up with the widowed boarding house owner, a horny Gwen Verdon. There is plenty sexual insinuations (the way they tie the ghost up...) and an oddly vague and unclear supernatural haunting. Probably the best of the Classic Ghosts series that I have watched so far.

I guess I thought I would like True Stories more. It never recovers from the Wild Wild Life. It is the highpoint never again to be reached. I guess I found it too twee. Too particular. David Byrne having a bit of fun at the expense of the Texans, though he doesn't go over the top. It is a pleasant film, with lightly quirky touches, but little else. More Northern Exposure than Twin Peaks. I found myself tiring of it before the 90 minute mark.David Byrne has to be the most talented person ever live in Dumbarton.

There is a line in The Evacuees, which is so good that I had to pause it to write it done. A kid complains, during a long walk, that "(he has) a headache in his legs." Brilliant. Perfect dialogue for a child actor.Jack Rosenthal is one of the greats (and I found out about him a month ago).I thought The Evacuees was a really good piece of television. Set during the Blitz. It was apparently loosely based on‚Ä¶

The Screaming Skull is the second entry in the Kino Cult "Classic Ghosts" set. It is about David McCallum, a doctor of craniology (the man loves a skull!), and his really annoying wife played by Carrie Nye. Her son just died and she mostly blames her husband, so I suppose she probably has just cause to be nippy. McCallum's brother comes for a visit. He is played by Vincent Gardenia. Presumably, the brothers are adopted, because they look and sound‚Ä¶

Have you ever wanted to see Darren Aronofsky's Lucky Number Slevin?At its best moments, Caught Stealing is great. At its worst moments, it is baseball Guy Ritchie. I liked it a lot and I usually don't like Aronofsky. But it works as a grimy, grim, and funny film. New York Elmore Leonard. Glances at George V. Higgins.I guess I forgot Darren Aronofsky is post-Quentin Tarantino, and this is him getting there 30 years late.Austin Butler is the‚Ä¶

I liked this more than it probably deserves, but it has a crackerjack premise. A man is wrongly convicted for murder and the jury are now dying in suspicious accidents. Sounds like Agatha Christie (Ordeal by Innocence), but it plays with an American newspaperman as the lead. And all that you'd expect from that. When did journalists stop being there heroes of films?The film is a quickie mystery with a fairly obvious reveal, but I found it charming and‚Ä¶

I Aim at the Stars is like The Wind Rises and Oppenheimer, but directed by J. Lee Thompson who keeps asking people if it is five o'clock yet.The film is curiously conflicted. It is a biography of Wernher von Braun, which cannot decide whether he deserves respect of condemnation. The film covers his rocket experiments in Germany, his¬†V-2 development efforts at¬†Peenem√ºnde¬†during World War¬†II, his postwar missile work with the¬†U.S. Army, and the launch of¬†Explorer¬†1, America's first satellite. It ends‚Ä¶

More effective as a romantic comedy than as a horror. The funny scenes are amusing, the horror scenes are weightless. I don't really like how modern slashers look; everyone is impaled rather easily. But, mostly, it was fun. Or at least fine.

What everyone else* thinks about Night of the Hunter, I think about Cape Fear.Brilliant film. A menacing thriller with an all-time performance by Robert Mitchum. His Max Cady is so evil. The way he targets women in the film is really something else. Pure horror. A serial rapist. Who takes such psychotic pleasure in it. I think the film is an utter masterpiece, and I don't know why it isn't widely considered as such.J. Lee Thompson directs it‚Ä¶

movietitle: Ready When You Are, Mr McGill
review: I had to watch this through my fingers. The increasing levels of frustration and cringe are occasionally leaven by comic asides from the supporting cast of wannabe actors and extras, but writer Jack Rosenthal and director Mike Newell leave you to stew with Mr McGill (Joe Black) and his ability to conjure comic chaos out of his Englishness.From the DVD of Jack Rosenthal at ITV.

I have been reading the Continental Op short stories off-and-on, and I thought I'd watch a Hammett adaptation I'd never seen before. The Fat Man is based on a radio series created by Dashiell Hammett. Directed by William Castle, starring J. Scott Smart, Julie London, and Rock Hudson.It is a fun little mystery. With a few nice scenes - J. Scott Smart dancing, Rock Hudson doing deep voiced naivety, and dentists and clowns. It probably isn't worth watching, but‚Ä¶

Portrait of Jennie starts with quotes from Euripides AND Keats and ends with a mad tinted three-strip Technicolor fantasia. It shouldn't work. But the film is hazily suspended between dreams and reality and comes together wonderfully despite the odd touches - a mural of Michael Collins, nuns, and the trapeze parents...The film is a timeless and out-of-time love story. The refain being wait for me. Captured in painting, love stuck in amber. It is a beautiful unrequited idea, which‚Ä¶

The Onion Field has an amazingly tense and brilliant first act which segues into a slightly dull court case. I assume Joseph Wambaugh was trying to write his In Cold Blood, and I can see where it would work on the page, but the film never recovers from the murder.The first act is so brilliantly constructed, cutting between the two cops and the two criminals, and their inevitable meeting, that I think the whole film could have been this.‚Ä¶

I thought I would like The Brothers McMullen. I recently watched The Groomsmen and Millers in Marriage, a mid period and late period Edward Burns film, respectively, and liked both quite a bit despite any reservations I had.The Brothers McMullen is still Burns's most famous effort behind the camera, and I just didn't think it was very good. You don't expect subtle dialogue from Burns, but even counting that, McMullen is a real clanging effort. The film is completely‚Ä¶

I'd give anyone 100 quid if they could guess the final villain of this film at the 30-minute mark. Absolute bananas.An okay attempt to recapture the spirit of Amblin films. A bit of Monster Squad, or The Goonies, but with one-eye on Strangers Things.Except, and this is the curious point, the main co-star with the child-lead, is Mel Gibson. The perfect Amblin actor? Yeah, I am not sure about that. However, Gibson is kind of great in the‚Ä¶

A film without any artistic merit. I quite liked it.The Thursday Murder Club could have (and might have) been directed by AI. Key prompts - Twee, British, pensioners and murder. If you had set it in Autumn, it would be the perfect Facebook algorithm film.Richard Osman strikes me as a man who has written more books than he has read, and that is how this overlit film feels. It has no plot, then too much. A structure without‚Ä¶

I guess Paige Darcy: Reluctant Detective is the film that people The Kid Detective was going to be before The Kid Detective dropped an all-timer downer on its audience.I thought this was mostly fun. A slightly silly mystery film, obsessed with the 1990s, about a former precocious tween sleuth who has grown into an underachieving millennial¬†works to solve a murder. It is brightly lit, full of post-Joss Whedon dialogue, and committed to its mystery.It is the kind of film that has the main character dressed as 90s Britney Spears for an absurdly long amount of time.I'd watch another.

What a strange film!Deadly Circuit is a comic mystery that ends with a real emotional punch to the face. It's an erotic thriller with Isabelle Adjani in a variety of sexy outfits, while Michel Serrault follows her completely conspicuously, covering up her murders. It is played straight but filmed with an air of silliness. Serrault is knowing, but his grief seems real. Adjani is a cypher that really means nothing.It shouldn't work, but I really liked it. It‚Ä¶

movietitle: If It's Tuesday, This Must Be Belgium
review: I spent about 45 minutes waiting for John Cassavetes to show back up before I went to Wikipedia to learn it was a cameo (along with a million other cameos). As such, I didn't give this Americans-in-Europe-on-tour film a real chance. I wasn't focused on what it is.Suzanne Pleshette is a delight as the lead, and Ian McShane spends the whole film trying to sleep with her (and anyone else). It is very late-1960s, quite broad, and confusingly (to‚Ä¶

Where the Wind Blows is about the best looking Hong Kong film in 20 years. At least since everyone started embracing the fairly shoddy HD look. It is really expertly filmed, with a number of surprising bouncy and upbeat song and dance moments. It suggest that Philip Yung is the real deal, particularly as it came after Port of Call.Obviously, the problems around the release of Where the Wind Blows suggest that Yung is going to struggle to release‚Ä¶

Hou Hsiao-hsien is a remarkable filmmaker, and A City of Sadness is a remarkable film. Yet, it being a Hou Hsiao-hsien film, it is also rather impenetrable and filled with a distracting level of visual and storybuilding detail.He excels with composition and drifting long takes, and in A City of Sadness he takes a steely long look at the story of a family embroiled in the "White Terror" carried out¬†by the¬†Kuomintang government¬†(KMT) after their arrival from¬†mainland China¬†in the late‚Ä¶

The Life of Chuck really is the full Stephen King experience. Corny, saccharine, occasionally inspired, lightly unsettling, and emotional. I simultaneously really liked it and thought it was really quite bad.It is utterly sincere and nearly reaches an Amblin level of enjoyment. It has a three act structure and a rather obvious set of callbacks. Every act makes the act preceding it better, but it never really feels like a coherent whole. It doesn't feel like a real life.‚Ä¶

As a writer and director, Cliff Robertson makes a fine actor.I bought a film written, directed and starring Cliff Robertson, despite regularly saying the worst three words in the English language are "...starring Cliff Robertson" - explain that? Because I can't.At least I like, checks notes, rodeo.However, to be fair to JW Coop, there really is something there. It is a rather slackly made film, where actors are giving way too much time to act, and scenes‚Ä¶

Is The Inquisitor a great film or merely a good? Does the ending of the film work in concert with the rest of it, or does it undermine it? I am not sure I can answer either of these questions.The Inquisitor is a feature-length police interview, somewhat in the mould of The Offence (though, it lacks the really sinister edge of the Sean Connery performance), where Lino Ventura and Michel Serrault go back and forth over Hogmanay about the‚Ä¶

I've seen Fearless before back in the early 2000s, and I have had it on bluray for a bit. The last time I tried to watch it, I tapped out in the first act at the line, "Hold on to your baby."Returning to it today, and yeah, well, that film holds up and some.There aren't many films as open-hearted and unsentimental. It is deeply moving but really clear-eyed. The film is heightened in everything but execution. I remembered‚Ä¶

I am prone to hyperbole, but I genuinely think Vincent Cassell gives the single worst acting performance I have ever seen in Black Tide.It isn't so much he fails to convince a maverick alcoholic cop, he fails to convince me that he has ever had a drink before. Any drink. Water.He is all hair and beard and a suit that is too big for him. He stumbles and shouts and acts up a storm. It is a real‚Ä¶

Well, that was a lot harder to watch at 41 than it was to watch at 19. Fucking hell. Everything feels much more painful the further I am removed from my own time at school. The cruelty, the violence, the secrecy.The filmmaking remains richly disorientating and artistic; the characters are hazy and disturbed, and the visuals still look great. The HD camera captures everything in attenuated light or sickly sharp greens.The film perhaps lacks the right tonal shift,‚Ä¶

Peter Sellers is so much better than the film around him. His Brummie accent is a masterpiece.I thought Heavens Above! was a really confused satire, with the occasional nice jab and a spectacularly misjudged ending. I guess it is about the dangers of over-generosity and a plea for a sympathetic hearing of Tory Christianity.Or maybe it isn't. Maybe it is about socialism. I have no idea. You can make up your own Malcolm Muggeridge.However, I don't think‚Ä¶

"Charles and I are going to see a Chabrol film, Le Boucher. Want to come?"Moseby grimaced under his moustache "I saw a Chabrol film" he said, lying "it was like watching paint dry."My world has been thrown off its axis seeing what the Alan Sharp line in the Night Moves novel(isation) originally was...A line so good about Rohmer is devastating about Harry Moseby when applied to Chabrol.The novelisation is absolutely wonderful. Sharp writes some very good prose.

I didn't remember L.627 being quite as jaunty as it is. At least for the first hour or so. I remembered it being a really tough, hard-edged crime procedural about a low-level drugs task force. Our main character fighting against apathy, bureaucracy, and criminals, and slowly going mad.And it is that, except it is mostly filmed in daylight. The rest of the police squad are basically fine, and fairly relaxed about their jobs, and are happy to arse about.‚Ä¶
Sorry, Frank

movietitle: Neither the Sea Nor the Sand
review: I was really rather taken with Neither the Sea nor the Sand. An elemental folk horror, which leans heavily towards despairing romance. I was impressed by the sparse script, the howling winds of Jersey (and Scotland) and tumult and longing which propel the story through a fascinatingly bleak series of events and landscapes.Neither the Sea nor the Sand is undoubtedly a strange intimate film, that is most often presented as a romance in reviews, but that I found effectively‚Ä¶

Sidney Salkow‚Äôs B-movie western feels a lot more epic than the other Salkow films I have seen. It shot in Cinemascope and really tries to tell a wide-ranging historical story. It isn't necessarily better than Salkow's other leaner oaters, but it is definitely more ambitious.Salkow weaves a story of the war between¬†Sitting Bull¬†and the American forces, leading up to the¬†Battle of the Little Bighorn¬†and Custer's Last Stand. It makes the right choice in presenting Custer as a total arsehole,‚Ä¶
